ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Written exercises
MaterialDescription: OLAT
FurtherInfoDescription:
This course will take place in BLU-003 (Blümlisalpstrasse 10, 8006 Zürich).
If you wish to attend this course, please send an e-mail with your student ID number (Matrikelnummer) to cornelia.schnyder@econ.uzh.ch Students should bring their own notebook - if available - as we will be doing programming exercises in class (software will be provided).
CommonDescription: Collection, analysis and visualisation of neuroeconomic data crucially depend on proficiency in dedicated computer programmes and programming environments (e.g., MATLAB, COGENT, Psychtoolbox). This course is aimed at researchers and students with little expertise in these areas, but will also contain valuable tips for students who already have some programming experience. The course will provide a hands-on introduction to and exercises with this software and programming environment, which are necessary for conducting and publishing neuroeconomic experiments. The first part of the course will provide a general introduction to programming in MATLAB, ranging from basic data conversion to more sophisticated data analysis and visualisation in publication-ready figures. The second part will focus on programming principles that will facilitate efficient use of MATLAB for all aspects of scientific work. The third part will introduce the MATLAB toolboxes COGENT and Psychtoolbox which were specifically developed to conduct behavioral experiments and synchronise data acquisition with external devices (fMRI scanners, eye trackers, etc.). Taken together, in this course, the students will learn how to efficiently program their own experiments and analyse and present their data within a single programming environment.

TestsDescription:

Written examination on: Tuesday, 14.01.2025, 10:00-12:00
SmText: Econometrics for Research Students Part I (Ph.D.) (L+E)
FurtherInfoDescription: This module will not be podcasted or recorded.
CommonDescription:
This course covers foundations of basic asymptotic econometric theory.
This is then applied to regression models, instrumental variables models, generalized method of moments, penalized and nonparametric regression models.
Emphasis is placed on understanding sampling distributions and how asymptotic theory translates into practical understanding of common estimation and inferential techniques. The topics are illustrated using theoretical, simulation, and empirical examples.

SmText: Macroeconomics for Research Students Part I (Ph.D.) (L+E)
MaterialDescription:
N.L. Stokey, R.E. Lucas, and E.C. Prescott. Recursive Methods in Economic Dynamics.
Harvard University Press, 1989
This is the main book for dynamic programing.
Lars Ljungqvist and Thomas J. Sargent. Recursive Macroeconomic Theory,
3nd Edition.
The MIT Press, 2012
This book has more emphasis on applications.
Daron Acemoglu. Introduction to Modern Economic Growth.
This book covers economic growth.
FurtherInfoDescription:
External students who cannot register via the modul booking tool at UZH are asked to register at zurichgse@econ.uzh.ch

This module will not be podcasted or recorded.
CommonDescription: This course is an introduction to macroeconomic theory at the PhD level. We develop tools that are commonly used in macroeconomics but also other areas of economics, notably recursive methods and discrete and continuous time dynamic optimization. We apply these tools to some of the most important topics of macroeconomics, including general equilibrium with complete and incomplete markets, consumption-savings problems, investment, dynamic contracts, fiscal policy, economic growth and climate macroeconomics.

SmText: Microeconomics for Research Students Part I (Ph.D.) (L+E)
MaterialDescription: Course Material will be provided on OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription: This module will not be podcasted or recorded.
CommonDescription: This course is the first part of the first-year micro sequence that prepares beginning doctoral students for their career in research. Specific topics of Part I include Choice Theory, Demand Theory, Stochastic Choice, Choice under Uncertainty, and General Equilibrium Theory. The course covers both advanced textbook material and recent research contributions.

PrecognitionDescription: Good knowledge of microeconomics.
ObjectiveDescription: Learning about research, primarily, corporate finance theory.
MaterialDescription: See the syllabus for a detailed list of references.
CommonDescription: This course is a doctoral level introduction into corporate finance. It covers the major themes of corporate finance, including investment policy, capital structure, payout policy, and corporate governance. It also covers important concepts in the economics of information.
AudienceDescription: Primarily doctoral students, but the course is also open to interested students in the MSc UZH ETH in Quantitative Finance program.

TestsDescription: Participation, discussion and presentation of own research project.
SmText: PhD Seminar in Quantitative Marketing Research (S)
CommonDescription: This seminar is a collaboration between ETH and UZH; marketing groups from both sides will participate. It is open to PhD students attached to the UZH Chairs of Prof. Algesheimer and Prof. Natter as well as the ETH Chair of Technology Marketing of Prof. von Wangenheim. To be prepared for the seminar, students need to read up on central topics in the related literature. They are invited to present "work in progress". The work to be presented should be in a state that allows for submission to an international peer-reviewed journal in the not too distant future.

SmText: Business Administration for Research Students: Theory (L+E)
MaterialDescription: "Mas-Colell, Whinston and Green: Microeconomics Theory", Oxford University Press, and Lecture Notes. Course material may be found on OLAT (see module DOEC0381 "Microeconomics for Research Students Part I").
FurtherInfoDescription:
This course takes place together with "Microeconomics for Research Students Part I".

Venue: see module DOEC0381 "Microeconomics for Research Students Part I"

This module will not be podcasted or recorded.
CommonDescription:
Ph.D. Course for Ph.D. program Finance and Economics.
This course is the first part of the first-year micro sequence that prepares beginning doctoral students for their career in research. Specific topics of Part I include Choice Theory, Demand Theory, Stochastic Choice, Choice under Uncertainty, and General Equilibrium Theory. The course covers both advanced textbook material and recent research contributions.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place onsite.
Written examination on: Tuesday, 14.01.2025, 10:00-12:00
SmText: Business Administration for Research Students: Empirical Methods (L+E)
PrerequisitesDescription: This course is specifically designed for students interested in a research-oriented career.
MaterialDescription: see DOEC0379 "Econometrics for Research Students Part I"
FurtherInfoDescription:
This course takes place together with DOEC0379 "Econometrics for Research
Students Part I"

Venue: see module DOEC0379 "Econometrics for Research Students Part I"

This module will not be podcasted or recorded.
CommonDescription: This course covers foundations of basic asymptotic econometric theory. This is then applied to regression models, instrumental variables models, generalized method of moments, penalized and nonparametric regression models. Emphasis is placed on understanding sampling distributions and how asymptotic theory translates into practical understanding of common estimation and inferential techniques. The topics are illustrated using theoretical, simulation, and empirical examples.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
• capital cost calculation
  • oral presentation
  • presence and active participation during the seminar
SmText: Market-Based Research in International Accounting, Part I (S)
ObjectiveDescription: The objective of the course is to develop your ability to critically evaluate and conduct empirical research in an international context. In particular, you should get (1) an appreciation for the role of theory in applied work, (2) an understanding of research designs commonly used in international accounting and finance research, and (3) the necessary skills to design and conduct empirical research in a cross-border setting. Overall, this course provides an overview of this fast evolving area, and discusses economic hypotheses, research methods, data issues, and limitations to this type of research.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of seminar participants is limited. Interested UZH doctoral students are kindly asked to register for the course at www.dar.uzh.ch before booking the module no later than August, 15, 2024.
Contact: Dr. Peter Steffen Schmidt (peter.schmidt@business.uzh.ch).
CommonDescription:
Market-based research in international accounting uses cross-border comparisons and within-country analyses exploiting the unique features of the local institutional environment to study how public and private institutions affect the properties and uses of accounting Information. More recent studies go beyond descriptive analyses and attempt to better understand how economic institutions affect the role of accounting information in capital markets, financing decisions and corporate governance. The course consists of two parts: in Part I, we cover the foundations and discuss some of the basic concepts of international accounting research. Specifically, the topics of Part I cover voluntary disclosure, the relation between disclosure and cost of capital, real effects of financial reporting, and CSR reporting. In Part II, we apply these concepts to specific areas (e.g., IFRS adoption, regulation and enforcement).
Note that it is suggested but not required that students attend both parts of the course in sequence.
Events_1_EStext: Market-Based Research in International Accounting, Part I (S)

SmText: Econometrics for Research Students Part II (Ph.D.) (L+E)
FurtherInfoDescription:
Attention, re-examination! Registration is only allowed to make up for a cancellation or to retake the exam if failed on first try. Retakers may not fail again. Students who wish to take the re-examination must email zurichgse@econ.uzh.ch at least three weeks before the re-examination takes place.

Exam takes place in room SOF-E-09
CommonDescription: Topics covered in Part II include estimation and inference in mis-specified regression models, linear and non-linear panel data models, as well as methods for program and policy evaluation, with a focus on causal inference and estimation of treatment effects.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Oral report, written summary, regular active attendance (whereby each make up one-third of final grade)
PrecognitionDescription: Basic knowledge of the brain and neuroeconomics / cognitive neuroscience
ObjectiveDescription: The aim of this course is to familiarize the students with these techniques so that they can start planning experiments that employ these techniques to address questions about causal brain-behavior relations.
MaterialDescription: OLAT
FurtherInfoDescription:
This course will take place in BLU-003 (Blümlisalpstrasse 10, 8006 Zürich).
If you wish to attend this course, please send an e-mail with your student ID number (Matrikelnummer) to cornelia.schnyder@econ.uzh.ch
CommonDescription: This course will introduce the non-invasive brain stimulation methods commonly used in neuroeconomic and cognitive neuroscience research. More specifically, the course will introduce transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS), and other forms of transcranial electric stimulation through a series of lectures and practical demonstrations. We will cover the basic physical principles of each technique, common forms of usage in empirical research, some landmark findings, and safety aspects.
AudienceDescription: Doctoral students in economics, neuroscience, and psychology with an interest/focus in interdisciplinary research; postdoctoral researchers

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: 3-4 Exercises (Problem sets or referee reports), one final examination or final project.
PrecognitionDescription: Good knowledge of microeconomic and econometric theory at the level of the first-year PhD sequence. Very good knowledge of English.
ObjectiveDescription: Students who have completed this course will understand the principles of structural estimation in empirical IO and will be able to implement structural econometric models in a handful of settings that commonly arise in the field.
MaterialDescription: Reading materials will be provided electronically or will be available from the university library.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Lecture with integrated exercises. Attendance of lecture is mandatory.

Venue: SOF-E-09

Exercise: Thu 08:00-09:45
Lecture: Thu 10:15-12:00
CommonDescription: This course introduces students to the empirical analysis of research questions in Industrial Organization (IO). IO analyzes competition between firms in all its guises, but takes as inputs an understanding of consumer demand and firms' costs and productivities and is itself used as an input into sector and competition policymaking. Each of these topics will be covered. Following that of the academic literature, the focus of the course will be on structural econometric methods. Those methods that constitute the canon in empirical IO (demand estimation, productivity estimation, single-agent dynamic behavior, etc.) will be introduced, as well as applications that rely on these to build customized econometric models designed for the industry and research question being studied. A working knowledge and comfort with microeconomic theory and econometric methods at the level of the first- year economics PhD sequence is required. The course emphasizes how structural methods combine theory and econometrics with a given dataset to answer research questions of economic interest. Structural methods are only learned well if they are programmed on a computer, so there will be a number of empirical problem sets during the course. These will cover the core material as well as present additional optional material allowing motivated students to spend the time necessary to implement the models covered in lecture on sample data.

SmText: Microeconomic Foundations of Economics of Education (S)
PrerequisitesDescription: Doctoral students enrolled at the University of Zurich & Leading House
MaterialDescription: www.business.uzh.ch/de/research/professorships/emap/teaching.html
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of participants is limited. Course registration until 1 September, 2024 is mandatory. Please send your application (including a one-page CV) to Aranya Sritharan (aranya.sritharan@business.uzh.ch).

Check our homepage:
www.business.uzh.ch/de/research/professorships/emap/teaching.html
CommonDescription: The human capital of the population is a key determinant of labor-market success and economic growth. This brings the economics of education to the core of understanding individual and societal economic prosperity. This course will analyze the microeconomic foundations of the economics of education. We will study the efficiency and equity of educational production. The focus will be on the school system, but the broader lifecycle of education policy will also be covered. While studying recent applied research on education policy, we will also cover up-to-date econometric methods for the empirical identification of causal effects in the economics of education.
AudienceDescription: Doctoral students interested in economics of education.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place onsite.
Written examination on: November 1, 2024 14:00-16:00
PrerequisitesDescription: Admission to an economic doctorate at UZH (economics or neuroeconomics)
PrecognitionDescription: Students should have a basic knowledge of economic choice models that are taught in advanced master and in doctoral courses. Prior knowledge of the brain's basic neural architecture is useful but it is also possible to follow the seminar by reading a few basic articles.
ObjectiveDescription: Students will increase their understanding of the processes involved in decision making.
MaterialDescription: Articles on decision theory, recent empirical results in experimental and neuroeconomics and on recent theoretical advances.
LanguageDescription: The course will be taught in English.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Students should be interested in the active, critical discussion of recent scientific insights in the domain of individual and social decision making.

This module will not be podcasted or recorded.

Room: BLU-003
CommonDescription:
This course is intended for second year PhD students.
Neuroeconomics is a new academic sub-discipline at the intersection of economics, psychology and neuroscience. It is a foundational discipline, similar to physical chemistry - which led to important advances in chemistry - and biochemistry - which led to important insights into the chemical underpinnings of biological processes. The goal of neuroeconomics is to provide a microfoundation for how the mind works and how animals and humans make decisions in terms of the underlying neural and psychological processes.
Therefore, neuroeconomics aims at contributing to a deeper and more solidly grounded understanding of the the human mind and human behavior.
The purpose of this course is to present a selection of key insights that have emerged in neuroeconomics over the last 15 years and derive their implications for the economics of individual decision-making. The course will be focussed on the attentional and perceptual processes that are likely to influence human decision-making, how these processes can be mathematically modelled, and how they help us better understand salient patterns of choice.
AudienceDescription: Doctoral students interested in the foundations of economic and social decision making.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
For this seminar, there are no ECTS points.
Students must make their own presentation in class.
PrerequisitesDescription: Completed MA in economics, enrollment in either the Zurich Graduate School of Economics or the Marlene Porsche Graduate School of Neuroeconomics.
PrecognitionDescription: The student should have advanced knowledge in his or her field of study.
ObjectiveDescription: After attending the course, the student will have a clear understanding of the thought processes involved in all stages of a research project, and will be in a position to plan and conduct a research study on his/her own.
MaterialDescription: Any teaching materials will be made available to students.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Attendance in the course is limited. Please send a short email outlining your motivation for attending the course to sally.gschwend@econ.uzh.ch.
The course instructors will inform you if you may attend.

Venue: BLU-003
CommonDescription:
Research projects go through many stages. They begin with evaluating the importance of a specific research question; they then need a suitable research design that answers the question. Data then needs to be collected, analyzed, and interpreted. Finally, a coherent story based on the findings must be developed
that shows what was learned and where there are weaknesses.
This seminar gives graduate students, post-docs, and professors the opportunity to present their research projects - regardless of the stage they are in - and to receive feedback from an interested audience of peers and experts.
Please note that no credit points can be earned for attending this course.

CommonDescription: This course is intended for second-year Ph.D. students who want to obtain advanced training in behavioral economic methods, theories and results. The course will focus on important areas of research in behavioral economics and will cover early behavioral findings in each area, current research, and current theories for interpreting behavioral phenomena. The goal is for students to obtain a great deal of familiarity with research in important areas of behavioral economics, including the methods employed and theoretical advancements.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Lecture presenting one Topic (or real world Application) to all other course participants.
PrecognitionDescription: Fundamentals of Probability Theory
ObjectiveDescription:
• Characteristics of learning in its various forms (Supervised/Unsupervised/Reinforcement, Regression/Classification, Parametric/Non Parametric, Discriminative/Generative)
  • Unifying probabilistic approach to the various forms of learning (Over fitting, Model Complexity, Model Selection, Bias vs Variance, Decision Theory, Maximum Likelihood fitting, Bayesian Prior/Posterior learning)
  • Selection of fundamental algorithms to handle specific learning tasks
MaterialDescription:
Slides:
Will be available prior to lectures

Literature:

  • Christopher Bishop. Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning. Springer, Jan. 2006.
  • Kevin P. Murphy. Probabilistic Machine Learning: An introduction. MIT Press, 2022.
  • Kevin P. Murphy. Probabilistic Machine Learning: Advanced Topics. MIT Press, 2023.
  • R.S. Sutton and A.G. Barto. Reinforcement Learning: An Introduction.

Adaptive Computation
  and Machine Learning series. MIT Press, 1998.
FurtherInfoDescription:
For registration please send an e-mail to: sigg@ifi.uzh.ch

Lecturer: Weinmann Thomas
CommonDescription:
The course will introduce basic concepts and distinctive algorithms of the field of machine learning.

In the first few sessions the lecturer is presenting some fundamental concepts and later the participants are going to present selected topics and applications.

Fundamental Topics include: Basic Concepts, Models for Regression, Models for Classification, Latent Variable Models and EM.

Selected Topics include: Graphical Models, Gaussian Process, Neural Networks and Deep Learning, State Space Models, Reinforcement Learning.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
SmText: digital social sciences: AI, Text2Data and Applied Economics (S)
PrecognitionDescription:
Basic notions of microeconomics and econometrics are essential.
Familiarity with the field of political economy and development economics is a plus.
ObjectiveDescription: The reading group will allow all participants to: (1) read the most recent contributions to the literature of political economy and development; (2) propose new research ideas in the are, and receive feedback on them from the group and (3) develop collaborations with other students or researchers interested in the topic.
MaterialDescription:
Relevant working papers will be distributed before every reading group.
Participants are expected to propose papers for discussion.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Post-docs and professors are free to join. Exceptional Master students are welcome.

Venue: SOF-G-21 except on 20.11.2024 the course will take place in room SOF-E-09.
CommonDescription:
In this seminar aimed at PhD students of all years, we will introduce new AI and text2data methods in economics. We will experiment with a "lab model", where groups of students explore research ideas with new tools and data under the instructors' guidance. The aim is explore a wide set of strategies and methods in parallel. In the end, we hope that participants complete one joint paper - with the entire group including the instructors as authors. We will proceed in three steps:

Day 1: Introduction, Overview, and Assignments (Corpora, Methods, Tools).
Student presentation of hallmark papers in Text2data meets Applied Economics

Day 2: Presentations of methodological choices and preliminary results. We discuss as a team and provide feedback.

Day 3: Presentation of final results. We pick most promising results and discuss strategies for producing a paper.
AudienceDescription:
Every Ph.D. student is welcome, along with exceptional Master students.
Professors and post-docs are free to join (and usually do!).
AppointmentsDescription: Oct 30 (WED): 10:00 am - 12:00 noon and 2:00 pm - 4:00 pm; Nov 20 (WED): 8:00 am - 12:00 noon; Dec 5 (THU): 2:00 pm - 6:00 pm

SmText: Programming Practices for Research in Economics (L)
ObjectiveDescription: (i) enhancing students' programming efficiency and (ii) providing the tools to make analysis and computation reproducible
FurtherInfoDescription:
For more information about the course, please visit pp4rs.github.io/current-uzh/

Please refer to the syllabus for the exact schedule.
CommonDescription: Much of modern economics and business research involves the researcher spending their lives in front of a computer - analysing data or simulating theoretical models. Exposure to programming languages in the current graduate curricula is most often limited to the simple use of Stata and Matlab to solve 'toy' examples designed to illustrate a theoretical result or implement a method with known properties and ex- ante known results. These skills do not scale up in a straightforward manner to handle complex projects that make up research papers, PhD theses or typical work in government or private business settings. As a result, graduate researchers in economics and business spend too much time wrestling with the software required to produce their research.

TestsDescription:
• discussion session leadership (60%)
  • discussion session participation (40%)
ObjectiveDescription: Students will learn the basic principles of cognitive and systems neuroscience across the lifespan. Students will gain experience leading and participating in discussion sessions.
MaterialDescription: OLAT
FurtherInfoDescription:
This course will take place in BLU-003 (Blümlisalpstrasse 10, 8006 Zurich).
If you wish to attend this course, please send an e-mail with your name and student ID number (Matrikelnummer) to cornelia.schnyder@econ.uzh.ch.
CommonDescription:
This course will cover basic principles of cognitive and systems neuroscience across the lifespan. Examples of topics include attention, cognitive control, emotion, learning, memory, and social cognition. In most cases, the first part of each course meeting will be a lecture on a given topic. The second half of each course meeting will be a
group discussion of current and/or classic papers related to the lecture topic in the previous week. For some topics, the entire meeting will be used for the lecture and demonstration of analysis methodologies. Each student will lead 1-2 discussion sessions over the course of the term. All students not leading the discussion in a given week will submit a short summary and list of pros, cons, open questions for each paper discussed.
Grades (pass/fail) will be based on discussion session leadership and participation.

ObjectiveDescription:
Synergistic combination of basic facts, theoretical viewpoints, and data analysis techniques from economics, neuroscience, and psychology (i.e.
neuroeconomics).
MaterialDescription: The list of journal articles will be distributed via OLAT before the first meeting in the first week of courses.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This course will be held on Tuesdays from 16:00-17:30 in the 1st,

Students are expected to have read each article in depth before each meeting. They should come prepared to ask questions about the articles themselves and/or how they relate to neuroeconomics in general.

This module will not be podcasted or recorded.

Venue: BLU-003
CommonDescription: In this course, students are expected to practice and demonstrate thoughtful combination of knowledge and skills learned in the separate compulsory courses within the Doctoral Program in Neuroeconomics. Specifically, students read and discuss a series of research articles that relate to the material covered in the other, previously completed compulsory courses. There is a written examination that tests how well students can interpret and critically evaluate the content and conclusions of the articles in light of what they have learned in all other compulsory modules.
AudienceDescription: Students enrolled in the Doctoral Program in Neuroeconomics

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Individual presentation or in groups, depending on the number of participants, scheduled on Thursday,12.09.2024, 10:00-18:00 hrs. Deadline for written report: 27.09.2024
ObjectiveDescription: The students acquire knowledge on recent results in cultural finance and learn how to conduct own research in this field.
MaterialDescription: Research papers
FurtherInfoDescription:
Max. 20 Students

Students need to apply to participate in the seminar. Application (CV) is possible until Friday, 16th August, 2024, at the latest to banking@uni-trier.de. Should there be places left after the deadline, later applications will be considered.

This module takes place on site.
CommonDescription:
The world is a diverse place, even considering today's globalized economy.
Cultural differences are still considerable. This also affects financial decision making which is influenced by economic as well as cultural differences. Differences in financial decision making, however, lead to differences between financial markets. In this class, we are discussing recent research on these cultural differences, and also how they can sometimes be used to test theories in behavioral finance. The basis for the class are research papers. The class will also include some small research project that participants will conduct in groups.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on 9.1.2025 from 8 - 10.
PrecognitionDescription: Fundamentals of algebra, geometry, matrix calculus, and Matlab programming.
ObjectiveDescription: By the end of the course you will know how to implement the fundamental computer vision algorithms used in mobile robotics, in particular: image formation, filtering, feature extraction, multiple view geometry, dense reconstruction, object tracking, image retrieval, event-based vision, visual-inertial odometry, and deep learning.
MaterialDescription:
1] Computer Vision: Algorithms and Applications, by Richard Szeliski, Springer, 2010.

[2] Robotics Vision and Control: Fundamental Algorithms, by Peter Corke
2011.

[3] An Invitation to 3D Vision, by Y. Ma, S. Soatto, J. Kosecka, S.S.
Sastry.

[4] Multiple view Geometry, by R. Hartley and A. Zisserman.

[5] Introduction to autonomous mobile robots 2nd Edition, by R. Siegwart, I.R. Nourbakhsh, and D. Scaramuzza, February, 2011 rpg.ifi.uzh.ch/teaching.html
FurtherInfoDescription:
This module can be credited towards either the Master's or Doctoral level. (Please note that this module can be credited towards a degree only once.) A failed attempt will be credited towards the level at which the student is enrolled at that time. Lectures will take place from
8 to 9:45. Exercises will take place from 12:15 to 13:45.
CommonDescription: Have you ever been curious to learn the perception algorithms used in today's self-driving cars and drones and what they have in common with virtual and augmented reality? Then this course is for you! This course introduces you to the key algorithms behind Apple ARKit, Google Visual Positioning Service, Microsoft Hololens, Magic Leap, Oculus Quest, Oculus Insight, and the NASA Mars rovers. In particular, we course will cover these topics: image formation, filtering, feature extraction, multiple view geometry, dense reconstruction, tracking, image retrieval, event-based vision, visualinertial odometry, and deep learning. Each lecture will be followed by a lab session where you will learn to implement the building block of a visual odometry algorithm in Matlab. By the end of the course, you will integrate all these building blocks into a working visual odometry algorithm.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Group project (a small research piece showcasing the skills learned) to be submitted and defended in person via online-presentation (20.12.2024
12:00-14:00)
PrerequisitesDescription: A bachelor's degree, basic computer skills and and previous attendance of research seminars.
PrecognitionDescription:
• very basic understanding of computer science: what an operating system is, how virtual differs from physical or local from remote, what commands are etc.;
  • intermediate knowledge of Python, Julia or R: how to write a function, plot a chart, format string values, read to and write from text files etc.;
  • previous exposure to research projects and/or passion for science.
ObjectiveDescription:
• Project management
  • Open science concepts
  • IT skills for research:

-- Version control
-- Environments
-- Containers
-- LaTeX
-- Data management
-- Visualization techniques
-- Cloud computing
MaterialDescription:
Lecture notes (github.com/ipozdeev)
Web resources (stackexchange.com etc.)
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place on site and online (podcast)
CommonDescription:
This course teaches IT skills useful for pursuing serious-level, reproducible research projects from idea to publication. The course covers the following topics:

  • Command line;
  • Project management;
  • Prompt engineering for research;
  • Version control;
  • Coding environments;
  • Docker containers;
  • Data management;
  • SQL databases;
  • Web APIs;
  • Writing with LaTeX and Markdown;
  • Visualization techniques;
  • Interactive apps and code notebooks;
  • Reproducibility and open science;
  • Cloud computing for research.

Students will demonstrate the usage of these skills by working on a small research piece in groups, submitting it for the final exam, and defending it in person. The course schedule is designed to mimic the workflow of a research project, enabling students to implement the topics one by one as they are discussed in class, while working towards the completion of the project by December.
AudienceDescription: PhD students and MA students, as well as everyone with strong interest in serious research.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: The assessment will be by a practical project to be agreed with the module coordinator. Each student will give a presentation on their project followed by questions.
SmText: Introduction to Data Science for Doctoral Students (L)
PrerequisitesDescription: Introductory courses on continuous mathematics, linear algebra, probability theory, such as: WWF courses Mathematics I, Mathematics II, and Statistics.
PrecognitionDescription: Familiarity with a programming language is necessary for the practical project.
ObjectiveDescription: This course introduces supervised and unsupervised learning. Students will learn the algorithms that underpin popular machine learning techniques. They will also develop an understanding of the theoretical relationships between these algorithms. The practicals will concern the implementation of machine learning algorithms and applications of machine learning to various datasets.
MaterialDescription:
Lecture notes, lecture slides, and code will be provided during the semester.
Main book references:

  • C. M. Bishop. Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning. Springer 2006.
  • I. Goodfellow, Y. Bengio, A. Courville. Deep Learning, MIT Press 2016.
  • K. P. Murphy. Machine Learning: A Probabilistic Perspective. MIT Press

2012.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This module takes place in the same room as "Foundations of Data Science (MI0005)"

If you have already taken the course "Foundations of Data Science (MI005 or MINF4566) you are not allowed to book this course.
CommonDescription: Introduction to data science and different paradigms of machine learning; Linear prediction, Regression; Maximum Likelihood, MAP, Bayesian ML; Regularization, Generalization, Cross Validation; Basics of Optimization; Linear Classification, Logistic Regression, Naïve Bayes; Support Vector Machines; Kernel Methods; Neural Networks, Backpropagation; Convolutional Neural Networks; Unsupervised Learning, Clustering, k-means; Dimensionality Reduction, PCA.
Events_1_EStext: Introduction to Data Science for Doctoral Students (L)
Partof_1_ScText: Doctorate Informatics (PVO08)
Partof_2_ScText: Doctorate Informatics (PVO08)

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: The basis of assessment will be a portfolio of biweekly written assignments. For each assignment, participants will be expected to revise their first drafts on the basis of the feedback they receive. Only the second draft will count in the final assessment.
SmText: Scientific Writing II: Publishing Papers in Computer Science (S)
PrecognitionDescription: This course is meant for PhD students who are relatively advanced in their studies and have a high level of English (C2 and above). Doctoral students at the beginning of their studies or with a lower level of English are encouraged to first take the course "Scientific Writing for PhD Students (Computer Science)".
ObjectiveDescription:
After finishing the course, participants will be able to

  • tailor their writing to particular readerships and journals,
  • draft and revise all sections of a scientific paper according to the disciplinary standards and conventions,
  • identify strengths and weaknesses in writing, and
  • write clearly, cohesively, and in a reader-friendly manner.
MaterialDescription:
Handouts will be provided before classes.
Recommended reading:
Zobel, Justin. Writing for Computer Science. Springer, 2014.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Students are expected to attend regularly and to participate actively in class. The number of participants is limited to 15.

For registration please send an e-mail to: sigg@ifi.uzh.ch.
CommonDescription:
This course aims to help you identify and comply with journals' requirements for paper submission and write papers suitable for publication. The main focus is on the structure and language use of the diverse sections of research papers. Working individually, in pairs and in small groups, instruction will be based on text analysis, writing exercises, collaborative writing, peer review and discussions of best practices. The lecturer will provide individual feedback on your writing samples. This course is particularly suitable if you have a more advanced command of English language and vocabulary and would like to focus more on the conventions, stylistics, and organisation of scientific articles. To benefit from the course fully, you should be in the process of writing scientific documents or articles.

This course can be taken in conjunction with the course "Scientific Writing for PhD students (DINF4001)" (usually offered in spring semester) or as a stand-alone course.
AudienceDescription: This course is for PhD and Fast-Track Masters students at IFI, who intend to write or work with scientific texts in English, either during their studies or in their future careers.
Events_1_EStext: Scientific Writing II: Publishing Papersin Computer Science (S)
Partof_1_ScText: Doctorate Informatics (PVO08)
Partof_2_ScText: Doctorate Informatics (PVO08)

TestsDescription:
Die Prüfung zum Modul findet am 17.12.2024 zwischen 08:00 und 11:00 Uhr als «Bring Your Own Device (BYOD)» Onlineprüfung in der «Messe Zürich» Oerlikon statt.

Um die Prüfung absolvieren zu können, müssen Sie Ihren eigenen Laptop (Windows oder MacOS) mitbringen. Die Prüfung kann nicht auf Tablets absolviert werden. Für die Teilnahme an der Prüfung kann die Installation des Safe Exam Browser (SEB) erforderlich sein. Ausserdem ist eine Online-Prüfungsaufsicht (Proctoring) möglich und wird mit Buchung des Moduls zugestimmt.

Um zur Prüfung zugelassen zu werden, muss im Vorfeld ein Funktionstest sowie ein Testlauf vor Ort in der Messe mit Ihrer individuellen technischen Ausrüstung absolviert werden. Genaue Informationen zur benötigten SEB-Version und sonstigen Details erhalten Sie im Laufe des Semesters.

Der Funktionstest der Wirtschaftswissenschaftlichen Fakultät findet vom 7. Oktober bis 25. Oktober 2024 statt und wird remote durchgeführt. Das Absolvieren des Funktionstests ist obligatorisch.

Der Testlauf der Wirtschaftswissenschaftlichen Fakultät findet am
28. Oktober 2024 zwischen 18.00 und 20.00 Uhr vor Ort in der Messe mit Ihrem eigenen Laptop statt. Die Teilnahme am Testlauf ist obligatorisch.

Studierende, die nicht am Funktionstest und am Testlauf teilgenommen haben, werden nicht zur finalen Prüfung zugelassen und haben nicht bestanden. Falls Sie aufgrund Krankheit oder Unfall nicht am Testlauf teilnehmen können, wenden Sie sich mit einem Arztzeugnis per E-Mail an support@oec.uzh.ch.

Es findet ein gemeinsamer Testlauf für alle Module des Assessment sowie des gemeinsamen Pflichtprogramms OEC und des gemeinsamen Pflichtprogramms INF statt. Sie müssen also für diese Prüfungen an einem Funktionstest und einem Testlauf teilnehmen.

SmText: Einführung in die empirische Wirtschaftsforschung (V+Ü) (Introductory Econometrics)
PrecognitionDescription: Statistik
MaterialDescription:
R. C. Hill, W.E. Griffiths and G.C. LIm (2018). Principles of Econometrics, 5th Edition, Wiley. Gratis download E-Book unter: uzb.swisscovery.slsp.ch/permalink/41SLSP_UZB/rloemb/alma99117590
670405508 (nur im UZH Netz)
FurtherInfoDescription: Dieses Modul wird nicht aufgezeichnet/kein Podcast.
CommonDescription:
Zielsetzung der empirischen Wirtschaftsforschung ist es, ̈ökonomische Fragestellungen mit Hilfe empirischer Methoden zu beantworten. Empirische Methoden in diesem Zusammenhang sind aber nichts anderes als statistische Methoden. Teilweise sind es Methoden, die wir in der Vorlesung "Statistik" schon kennengelernt haben, teilweise sind es neue Methoden, die es erst noch zu besprechen gilt. Allgemein formuliert, untersuchen diese neuen Methoden die Beziehung von zwei (oder mehreren) Zufallsvariablen. Existiert eine solche Beziehung? Falls ja, wie kann diese Beziehung quantifiziert werden und welche Einsichten können daraus gewonnen werden? Die angebrachten statistischen Methoden zur Untersuchung der Beziehung von Zufallsvariablen hängt von deren Natur ab, d.h. davon, ob kategorische oder numerische Variablen vorliegen.
Methoden für die Behandlung von kategorischen Variablen können unter der Rubrik "Kontingenz-Tabellen" zusammengefasst werden und werden schon im der Vorlesung "Statistik" behandelt. Diese Vorlesung befasst sich mit der Behandlung von numerischen Variablen; die zugehörigen Methoden können unter der Rubrik "Regression" zusammengefasst werden.

TestsDescription:
Die Prüfung zum Modul findet am 20.12.2024 zwischen 11:30 und 14:30 Uhr als «Bring Your Own Device (BYOD)» Onlineprüfung in der «Messe Zürich» Oerlikon statt.

Um die Prüfung absolvieren zu können, müssen Sie Ihren eigenen Laptop (Windows oder MacOS) mitbringen. Die Prüfung kann nicht auf Tablets absolviert werden. Für die Teilnahme an der Prüfung kann die Installation des Safe Exam Browser (SEB) erforderlich sein. Ausserdem ist eine Online-Prüfungsaufsicht (Proctoring) möglich und wird mit Buchung des Moduls zugestimmt.

Um zur Prüfung zugelassen zu werden, muss im Vorfeld ein Funktionstest sowie ein Testlauf vor Ort in der Messe mit Ihrer individuellen technischen Ausrüstung absolviert werden. Genaue Informationen zur benötigten SEB-Version und sonstigen Details erhalten Sie im Laufe des Semesters.

Der Funktionstest der Wirtschaftswissenschaftlichen Fakultät findet vom 7. Oktober bis 25. Oktober 2024 statt und wird remote durchgeführt. Das Absolvieren des Funktionstests ist obligatorisch.

Der Testlauf der Wirtschaftswissenschaftlichen Fakultät findet am
28. Oktober 2024 zwischen 18.00 und 20.00 Uhr vor Ort in der Messe mit Ihrem eigenen Laptop statt. Die Teilnahme am Testlauf ist obligatorisch.

Studierende, die nicht am Funktionstest und am Testlauf teilgenommen haben, werden nicht zur finalen Prüfung zugelassen und haben nicht bestanden. Falls Sie aufgrund Krankheit oder Unfall nicht am Testlauf teilnehmen können, wenden Sie sich mit einem Arztzeugnis per E-Mail an support@oec.uzh.ch.

Es findet ein gemeinsamer Testlauf für alle Module des Assessment sowie des gemeinsamen Pflichtprogramms OEC und des gemeinsamen Pflichtprogramms INF statt. Sie müssen also für diese Prüfungen an einem Funktionstest und einem Testlauf teilnehmen.

TestsDescription:
Bestehen der Übungen (d.h., Erreichen von 50% der Gesamtpunktzahl aller Übungen) sowie der Abschlussprüfung. Für ein erfolgreiches Bestehen des Moduls müssen zwingend sowohl die Übungen, als auch die Abschlussprüfung bestanden werden. Die Endnote ergibt sich aus dem Ergebnis der Abschlussprüfung.

Prüfungsrelevant sind alle in der Vorlesung angegebenen Inhalte, insbesondere die Vorlesung selbst, das Skript, die assoziierten Filme, sowie allfällig angegebene weitere Literatur. Eine genaue Spezifikation findet sich im Syllabus.

SmText: Informatik und Wirtschaft (V) (Informatics and the Economy)
ObjectiveDescription:
Um die heutige Gesellschaft und Wirtschaft als Ganzes zu begreifen, muss man verstehen, wie Computer funktionieren und wie sie unser wirtschaftliches Umfeld verändern. Ziel der Vorlesung Informatik für Ökonomen ist es, diese zwei Bereiche zu beleuchten.
Zunächst beschäftigen wir uns also mit der Frage wie Computer und Informationssysteme funktionieren. Dabei werden wir ergründen auf welchen Prinzipien die Geräte basieren und wie diese programmiert werden können.

  • Wie funktioniert ein Computer wie z. B. mein Smartphone?
  • Was sind die technischen Grundlagen für die Vielzahl von Informationen
    auf dem Web?
    Als weiteres wollen wir verstehen, wie sich Informationssysteme auf unser wirtschaftliches Umfeld auswirken.
  • Weshalb lohnt es sich in Computer zu investieren?
  • Welchen Mehrwert leisten diese für eine Firma?
  • Wie, wo, und mit welcher Zielsetzung werden und sollen Computer demnach in Firmen und Organisationen eingesetzt werden?
  • Warum haben Supermarktketten und Warenhäuser moderne Scannerkassen eingeführt?
  • Welche Besonderheiten haben Digitale Güter -- also Produkte, die nur aus einer Ansammlung von Daten bestehen, wie Musik, Filme, oder Software -- und wie wirken sich diese auf deren Handel aus?
MaterialDescription: Skript
FurtherInfoDescription: Sämtliche Angaben zu den Vorlesungen werden in OLAT publiziert. Die wichtigsten Informationen sowie Hilfestellungen zur Anmeldung in OLAT finden sie in der Kurzversion des Syllabus.
CommonDescription: Computer haben unser Leben tiefgreifend verändert. Um die heutige Gesellschaft und Wirtschaft und deren stetigen Veränderungen zu verstehen, muss man wissen, wie Computer funktionieren. Das Ziel der Vorlesung Informatik und Wirtschaft ist es, Ihnen eine Basis zu vermitteln, um unsere informationstechnisch gesteuerte Welt zu verstehen und darin erfolgreich zu sein.
AudienceDescription: Für Assessmentstufe Bachelor Inf und Oec sowie entsprechende Nebenfachstudierende.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Students may participate in a voluntary bonus system by successfully completing the assignments throughout the semester and by passing the midterm exam (Monday, 4.11.2024 between 18:00pm - 20:00pm, BYOD on site). The bonus system will be explained in the first lecture.

The exam for the module takes place on 19.12.2024 between 11:30 and 14:30 as a "Bring Your Own Device (BYOD)" online exam at "Messe Zürich" in Oerlikon.

To take the exam, you must bring your own laptop (Windows or macOS). The exam cannot be taken on tablets. To take the exam it may be required to install the Safe Exam Browser (SEB). Furthermore, online examination supervision (proctoring) is possible and is agreed upon booking the module.

In order to be admitted to the exam, you must complete a functional test as well as a test run on site at "Messe Zürich" using your individual technical equipment. Exact information on the required SEB version and other details will be provided to you during the semester.

The functional test of the Faculty of Business, Economics and Informatics will take place from 7 October to 25 October 2024 and must be completed remotely. Completion of the functional test is mandatory.

The test run of the Faculty of Business, Economics and Informatics will be held on site at "Messe Zürich" on 28 October 2024 between 18:00 and
20:00 with your own laptop. Attendance in the test run is mandatory. 

Students who have not attended the functional test and the test run will not be admitted to the final exam and fail the course. If you cannot attend the test run due to illness or accident, you must email to support@oec.uzh.ch with a doctor's note.

There will be a joint test run for all assessment modules as well as common compulsory program OEC and common compulsory program INF modules, i.e., for these exams, you have to take part in one functional test and one test run.
PrecognitionDescription: Basical mathematics knowledge from the general qualification for university entrance (Matura) and a firm grasp of using a computer running a common operating system (MacOS, Linux or Windows) are required. No pre-existing programming skills are expected.
ObjectiveDescription:
By successful participation, the students obtain competence in the following areas:

* Analyzing problem statements towards writing software

* Designing programs and algorithms

* Writing software

* Basic concepts of hard- and software
MaterialDescription: Check the course page (www.ifi.uzh.ch/seal/teaching/courses/info1.html) and the associated OLAT course (Link on the course page above) for more information about how the course is conducted and to obtain the materials used in the lecture and exercises.
LanguageDescription: The primary lecture language is English. All materials (slides, exercises, and exams) are in English.
FurtherInfoDescription:
See the course website:
www.ifi.uzh.ch/seal/teaching/courses/info1.html
CommonDescription:
The lecture gives an introduction to programming. The students learn to use the computer as a tool for creating software. Based on the programming language "Python", basic concepts in programming, such as variable assignment, control structures, classes and objects, as well as advanced subjects such as inheritance and polymorphism are taught.
The theoretical concepts taught in the lecture are augmented with numerous examples, demonstrating the practical application of the presented concepts.
The students also receive regular assignments to practice writing programs individually throughout the semester.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Performance in the course will be assessed based on a final examination (60%) as well as two project assignments (20% each). Students must pass the exam in order to pass the course.
The exercises and assignments will help students to develop collaborative problem-solving skills. The final exam will cover the entirety of the material covered in the course.

The exam for the module takes place on 16.12.2024 between 15:00 and 18:00 as a "Bring Your Own Device (BYOD)" online exam at "Messe Zürich" in Oerlikon.

To take the exam, you must bring your own laptop (Windows or macOS). The exam cannot be taken on tablets. To take the exam it may be required to install the Safe Exam Browser (SEB). Furthermore, online examination supervision (proctoring) is possible and is agreed upon booking the module.

In order to be admitted to the exam, you must complete a functional test as well as a test run on site at "Messe Zürich" using your individual technical equipment. Exact information on the required SEB version and other details will be provided to you during the semester.

The functional test of the Faculty of Business, Economics and Informatics will take place from 7 October to 25 October 2024 and must be completed remotely. Completion of the functional test is mandatory. The test run of the Faculty of Business, Economics and Informatics will be held on site at "Messe Zürich" on 28 October 2024 between 18:00 and 20:00 with your own laptop. Attendance in the test run is mandatory.

Students who have not attended the functional test and the test run will not be admitted to the final exam and fail the course. If you cannot attend the test run due to illness or accident, you must email to support@oec.uzh.ch with a doctor's note.

There will be a joint test run for all assessment modules as well as common compulsory program OEC and common compulsory program INF modules, i.e., for these exams, you have to take part in one functional test and one test run.
PrecognitionDescription: As course materials and the exam will be primarily in English; students should have a good command of spoken and written English.
ObjectiveDescription: Students should gain familiarity with various topics related to people- oriented computing, including important challenges and questions relating to computing at the human, group, organizational, and societal levels. They should have an understanding of connections between technological and human issues.
MaterialDescription: Materials and assignments will be distributed and collected via OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription: Materials and assignments will be distributed and collected via OLAT.
CommonDescription:
Developments in technology have had a profound impact on people and the world in which we live, work, and interact. These developments are simultaneously enabling and challenging, and the co-evolution of computing and people's use of it has led to important issues for the design, development, adoption of technology, as well as the understanding of its impact on how we live.
This course provides an introduction to human-oriented aspects of computing, and serves as a foundation for further study in people- oriented computing. Fundamental human issues of technology will be covered at the level of individuals, groups, organizations, and society.
The course will provide a general introduction to key areas in people- oriented computing, and also touch upon relevant topics such as roles and potential careers in computing, methods and approaches employed in these areas, and future directions for technology.
AudienceDescription: BSc students in the first semester of study

TestsDescription:
Leistungsüberprüfung durch schriftliche Klausur für den Teil Management (50%) und für den Teil Marketing (40%) sowie Zwischentests während des Semesters für den Teil Marketing (10%).

Die Prüfung zum Modul findet am 17.12.2024 zwischen 11:30 und 14:00 Uhr als «Bring Your Own Device (BYOD)» Onlineprüfung in der «Messe Zürich» Oerlikon statt.

Um die Prüfung absolvieren zu können, müssen Sie Ihren eigenen Laptop (Windows oder MacOS) mitbringen. Die Prüfung kann nicht auf Tablets absolviert werden. Für die Teilnahme an der Prüfung kann die Installation des Safe Exam Browser (SEB) erforderlich sein. Ausserdem ist eine Online-Prüfungsaufsicht (Proctoring) möglich und wird mit Buchung des Moduls zugestimmt.

Um zur Prüfung zugelassen zu werden, muss im Vorfeld ein Funktionstest sowie ein Testlauf vor Ort in der Messe mit Ihrer individuellen technischen Ausrüstung absolviert werden. Genaue Informationen zur benötigten SEB-Version und sonstigen Details erhalten Sie im Laufe des Semesters.

Der Funktionstest der Wirtschaftswissenschaftlichen Fakultät findet vom 7. Oktober bis 25. Oktober 2024 statt und wird remote durchgeführt. Das Absolvieren des Funktionstests ist obligatorisch.

Der Testlauf der Wirtschaftswissenschaftlichen Fakultät findet am
28. Oktober 2024 zwischen 18.00 und 20.00 Uhr vor Ort in der Messe mit Ihrem eigenen Laptop statt. Die Teilnahme am Testlauf ist obligatorisch. 

Studierende, die nicht am Funktionstest und am Testlauf teilgenommen haben, werden nicht zur finalen Prüfung zugelassen und haben nicht bestanden. Falls Sie aufgrund Krankheit oder Unfall nicht am Testlauf teilnehmen können, wenden Sie sich mit einem Arztzeugnis per E-Mail an support@oec.uzh.ch.

Es findet ein gemeinsamer Testlauf für alle Module des Assessment sowie des gemeinsamen Pflichtprogramms OEC und des gemeinsamen Pflichtprogramms INF statt. Sie müssen also für diese Prüfungen an einem Funktionstest und einem Testlauf teilnehmen.
ObjectiveDescription:
Das erfolgreiche Absolvieren dieses Studienmoduls versetzt Sie in die Lage:

  1. Herausforderungen des Managements mit Hilfe managementwissenschaftlicher Theorien zu erfassen.
  2. Managementwissenschaftliche Theorien auf Basis ihrer wissenschaftstheoretischen Position zu hinterfragen.
  3. Den Gründungsmanagementprozess in dessen spezifischen Managementherausforderungen zu verstehen.
  4. Die Denkweise und Aufgaben des Marketing in seinen Grundzügen nachzuvollziehen.
  5. Die Methoden der Datengewinnung zu verstehen.
  6. Die wesentlichen Marketinginstrumente zu kennen und anzuwenden.
MaterialDescription:
Die Unterlagen werden auf OLAT bereitgestellt.

Siehe auch Websites der beteiligten Lehrstühle:
* Grundlagen des Managements (Prof. Dr. Scherer): www.business.uzh.ch/de/professorships/as/teaching/overview.html
* Grundlagen des Marketing (Prof. Dr. Natter): www.business.uzh.ch/en/professorships/marketing2.html
FurtherInfoDescription:
Dieses Modul findet vor Ort und online (Podcast, Livestream SWITCH) statt.

Die Übungsgruppen finden vor Ort statt, wobei die erste Übungsgruppe (Di, 08:00
- 09.45 Uhr) aufgezeichnet wird und als Podcast auf OLAT abrufbar ist.

Der Durchführungsmodus (online oder onsite) der Prüfung wird noch bekannt gegeben. Eine Online-Prüfungsaufsicht (Proctoring) ist möglich und wird mit Buchung des Moduls zugestimmt.

Nähere Angaben zur Prüfung und zum Durchführungstermin finden Sie unter: www.oec.uzh.ch/de/assessment


Siehe Websites der beteiligten Lehrstühle:
* Grundlagen des Managements (Prof. Dr. Scherer): www.business.uzh.ch/de/professorships/as/teaching/overview.html
* Grundlagen des Marketing (Prof. Dr. Natter): www.business.uzh.ch/en/professorships/marketing2.html
CommonDescription:
Das Studienmodul BWL I besteht aus zwei Teilen:

Der Vorlesungsteil "Grundlagen des Managements" (Prof. Dr. A. G. Scherer) führt in wesentliche Fragestellungen des Managements, der Managementwissenschaften und deren wissenschaftstheoretische Grundlagen ein. Begleitend findet hierzu die Übung "Gründungsmanagement" statt, welche die Herausforderungen des Managements am Beispiel des Gründungsprozesses eines jungen Unternehmens veranschaulicht.

Der Vorlesungsteil "Grundlagen des Marketing" (Prof. Dr. M. Natter) führt in Grundzüge des Marketing ein, befasst sich mit der Entwicklung des Thema Marketings, der Marktforschung, den vier Marketinginstrumenten sowie dem Marketing-Management. Begleitend dazu findet eine Übung zu den behandelten Marketingthemen statt.

ObjectiveDescription: Kennen und verstehen der Grundlagen sowie der wichtigsten Grundbegriffe und Konzepte der Finance.
MaterialDescription: Die Unterrichtsmaterialien (inkl. Skript) werden auf OLAT bereitgestellt.
FurtherInfoDescription: Bei Fragen zum Modul wenden Sie sich bitte an assessment@df.uzh.ch.
CommonDescription: Diese Vorlesung ist eine Einführung in die Finance. Sie soll den Studierenden grundlegende Kenntnisse und Fähigkeiten in diesem Bereich vermitteln und auf die nachfolgenden Veranstaltungen im Bachelorstudium in Banking und Finance vorbereiten. Der Kurs gliedert sich in unterschiedliche Themenbereiche: Das Hauptaugenmerk wird auf die Corporate Finance gelegt. Behandelt werden verschiedene Verfahren der Investitionsrechnung sowie die Grundlagen der Unternehmensfinanzierung und der Unternehmensbewertung. Die Themenblöcke Banking und Versicherungen runden die Veranstaltung ab.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
There will be mandatory homework exercises and a mandatory written final exam.
To pass the module, students must pass the homework exercises and the final exam. The final exam of the module will take place onsite on Friday, 10.1.2025,
13:45 - 16:45. The exam itself will take 2 hours and 30 minutes.
PrecognitionDescription: It is recommended that students take the module "Foundations of Computing I" offered each Spring term, before taking this module.
ObjectiveDescription: The goal of the course is to familiarize the student with formal methods of computing and their value for computer science and related disciplines, and to provide basic training in applying formal methods to many different kinds of problems. Students should learn the fundamental limits of computation and extend their knowledge on formal languages as well as on formal programming models. Principles of interference, deduction, induction and contradiction should regularly be applied to demonstrate the formal correctness of models and limits.
MaterialDescription:
Automata Theory, Languages and Computation, 3rd Edition. John E. Hopcroft, Rajeev Motwani, Jeffrey D. Ullman. Addison Wesley.
Additional material (not obligatory): Theoretical Computer Science: Introduction to Automata, Computability, Complexity, Algorithmics, Randomization, Communication, and Cryptography. Juraj Hromkovic. Springer.
CommonDescription: Required second-year course covering topics from discrete math and formal methods building the foundations of computing. The material of this course is pervasive in the areas of algorithms, data structures and programming but appears virtually in all areas of computer science as well. The course will cover topics such as, but not limited to, proof methods, formal languages, deterministic and nondeterministic finite automata, grammars and pushdown automata, Turing machines, computability, decidability and complexity, P and NP, NP-completeness.
AudienceDescription: Recommended for students in BSc from 3rd semester and also for students in NF from 3rd semester.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
To complete and pass this course, the participation and completion of several paper or online exercises is required. The final written exam determines the final grade, given the necessary exercises have been completed as required.

The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on Thursday, 9 January 2025 from 14 - 16h.
PrecognitionDescription: Introductory university level math courses (such as Math I and II), as well as a good experience in programming (i.e. using Python) and knowledge of basic data structures and algorithms.
ObjectiveDescription: By the end of the course, the students will be able to identify a suitable method to solve basics problems of scientific computing, understand the main implications of the method and implement it directly or apply it using existing libraries. The students will learn how to solve such problems and to implement required algorithms and solutions in Python. The course will provide to the students the basis to understand more complex numerical tools that they may encounter in future courses or in their professional career.
MaterialDescription: Lecture slides as well as exercises will be made available and distributed via OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription: Every students is required to install and work with Python and use additional required packages on her or his personal computer for this course as instructed (support instructions will be communicated via OLAT).
CommonDescription:
The course presents the basic numerical and linear algebra techniques to solve mathematical problems that arise in computer science. The topics cover a wide range such as e.g.: basic concepts of scientific programming, solution of systems of linear equations and of nonlinear equations; interpolation and least-square approximation of data and functions; eigenvalues and eigenvectors computation; integration and differentiation and numerical optimization.
The course consists of lectures, exercises and homework assignments.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
60% Final exam
40% Lab (composed of different assignments, graded during the course).

To pass the course, both the final exam grade and the lab grade must be a passing grade (i.e., 4 or higher). In case either grade is lower than the passing grade, the final grade for the course is the highest grade below the passing grade (e.g., with grades 3.5 and 4.0, 3.5 will be the final grade; with grades 3.5 and 3.75, 3.75 will be the final grade).

The exam for the module takes place on 18.12.2024 between 11:30 and 14:30 as a "Bring Your Own Device (BYOD)" online exam at "Messe Zürich" in Oerlikon.

To take the exam, you must bring your own laptop (Windows or macOS). The exam cannot be taken on tablets. To take the exam it may be required to install the Safe Exam Browser (SEB). Furthermore, online examination supervision (proctoring) is possible and is agreed upon booking the module.

In order to be admitted to the exam, you must complete a functional test as well as a test run on site at "Messe Zürich" using your individual technical equipment. Exact information on the required SEB version and other details will be provided to you during the semester.

The functional test of the Faculty of Business, Economics and Informatics will take place from 7 October to 25 October 2024 and must be completed remotely. Completion of the functional test is mandatory. The test run of the Faculty of Business, Economics and Informatics will be held on site at "Messe Zürich" on 28 October 2024 between 18:00 and 20:00 with your own laptop. Attendance in the test run is mandatory.

Students who have not attended the functional test and the test run will not be admitted to the final exam and fail the course. If you cannot attend the test run due to illness or accident, you must email to support@oec.uzh.ch with a doctor's note.

There will be a joint test run for all assessment modules as well as common compulsory program OEC and common compulsory program INF modules, i.e., for these exams, you have to take part in one functional test and one test run.
PrerequisitesDescription: Informatik I (or equivalent)
ObjectiveDescription:
As a result of this course, students will acquire:

A solid understanding of the principles and techniques of modern software design, including:
A.1 Concepts and issues of software quality and maintainability
A.2 Code as data
A.3 Object-oriented programming
A.4 Fundamental design patterns (recognized best practices of software architectures)
A.5 Fundamentals of software testing
A.6 Fundamentals of modern software engineering tools

B. Experience in collaborative tasks applying these principles and techniques
MaterialDescription:
• Wilson, Greg. Software Design by Example A Tool-Based Introduction with Python.
    Chapman & Hall, 2024. (freely available online at: https://third-bit.com/sdxpy/ )
  • Lecture slides
  • Provided supplementary material
FurtherInfoDescription: The course consists of weekly lectures and laboratory sessions.
CommonDescription:
Knowing how to program does not make a student a software designer. The next step
involves learning and practicing the fundamental principles and techniques for designing
long-lived software systems. This course helps students learn software design by building
examples of small versions of tools that programmers use every day. The course includes a
practical component, highlighting the engineering skills needed to design robust software
systems. Primarily, the course is taught using Python, with the final lectures introducing
Java.

TestsDescription:
• Hausaufgaben, Übungsleistungen vor Ort ( 33,33333%)
  • Abschlussklausur (66,66666%)

Die genauen Regeln zu den Hausaufgaben und Übungsleistungen vor Ort werden zu Semesterbeginn bekanntgegeben. Die schriftliche Prüfung zum Modul findet am
17.1.25, 10-12 Uhr vor Ort statt.
PrecognitionDescription:
Die Teilnehmer müssen Kenntnisse folgender Vorlesungen haben:

  1. "Informatik und Wirtschaft"
  2. "Informatik I"

Die Teilnehmer sollten Kenntnisse haben von: "Wirtschaftsinformatik 1"
ObjectiveDescription:
1. Sie kennen ERP-Systeme aus Nutzersicht und können einen Management Cockpit entwerfen
  2. Sie können Prozesse analysieren, modellieren und neugestalten.
  3. Sie können Prozessemodelle in ERP-Systemen und Process Engines implementieren
MaterialDescription:
1. Folien, Übungsblätter
  2. Skript mit Literatur
  3. Modellierungstools
  4. Umgebungen zur Implementierung von Prozessen in ERP-Systemen und Process Engines
  5. ERP-Simulationsspiel ERP-Sim
LanguageDescription: Deutsch; Hintergrundliteratur und Software kann auf Englisch sein
FurtherInfoDescription:
• Dieses Modul findet vor Ort und online (Podcast) statt. Wir werden die Vorlesungen in MS Teams oder Zoom übertragen und aufzeichnen.
  • Gewisse Übungsleistungen können nur bei Anwesenheit vor Ort und nicht online erbracht werden.
  • In der Vorlesung wird das ERP-SIM-Spiel zu Lernzwecken gespielt. Jeder Studierende muss einen Kostenanteil von ca. 40 Franken für seinen persönlichen Zugang übernehmen.
CommonDescription:
• Die Vorlesung behandelt Prozessmanagement und ERP Systeme. Sie hat folgenden Aufbau: Einführung in die Lehrveranstaltung
  • Prozesse
  • Business Process Model and Notation (BPMN)
  • Strategisches Prozessmanagement
  • Ist/Soll-Modellierung
  • Implementierung
  • Process Mining
  • Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP)
  • Organisatorische Implementierung
  • Die begleitenden Übungen behandeln das Modellieren von BPMN, die Ist/Sollmodellierung, die Implementierung mit einer Process Engine sowie die Nutzung von ERPSim. Projektaufgabe.
AudienceDescription: Hauptfach-Studierende der Wirtschaftsinformatik Hauptfach-Studierende anderer Informatikstudiengänge (Wahlbereich) OEC-Nebenfach-Studierende der Wirtschaftsinformatik OEC-Nebenfach-Studierende Informatik (Wahlbereich)

ObjectAttributes:
Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
Target Group: Open to School Students
TestsDescription:
Sufficient and successful completion of exercises during the semester. The examination of the module will take place onsite. Final written exam on
9.1.2025, 8 - 10h
SmText: Computer Networks and Distributed Systems (L+E) (Kommunikationsnetze und Verteilte Systeme)
PrecognitionDescription: The lecture "Communication Networks and Distributed Systems CNDS" runs as a basic course on basically no specific technical requirements, however, basic mathematical and programming language skills do certainly help.
ObjectiveDescription: Students will receive the required insights into basic foundations on Communication Networks and Distributed Systems. More specifically, the lecture will teach communication architectures, network building blocks, shared links, packet switching, end-to-end protocols, selected Internet applications, naming principles, distributed file systems synchronization, coordination, and basic security elements as well as mechanisms. Overall, students will be able to understand which communication systems exist, how Internet-based systems operate world-wise, which communications can be reliable, how the basic inter-operations of Distributed Systems work, and which ones may be secured.
MaterialDescription: Books as well as lecture slides can be found on the lecture's Web site, which is part of the CSG's teaching material's collection at www.csg.uzh.ch/csg/en/teaching.html.
CommonDescription:
The Information and Communications Technology (ICT) age has arrived within our daily life, not only during work and business hours, but at a good deal of entertainment and social interactions, too. Thus, the society has to cope with such
developments of digitization. Many of those human-centric statements only refer to or try to analyze the impact of these changes and the society. However, in very many cases the fundamentals to derive reliable, correct, and transparent conclusions requires a detailed know-how of Communication Networks and Distributed Systems (CNDS). Therefore, once stand-alone systems are discussed, their interconnection across physical boundaries of an office or building site forms the major development of the ICT society. While fundamental communication architectures did introduce communications by technical means, achieved over the past 100 years, the development of telephone communications to today's Internet will be covered. Protocols, reliable, unreliable, and secure services, algorithms for finding the corresponding receiver, routing, and basic mechanisms for Internet operations will form this lecture's part one.
Furthermore, once stand-alone systems have been interconnected, they constitute Distributed Systems, which form a collection of independent computers that appear to their users as a single coherent system, embedding hardware, within which all machines are fully autonomous, and software, for which users think they deal with a single system. Thus, basic theory and techniques of Distributed Systems are covered in this lecture's part two. Driven by an introduction, naming principles and distributed file systems are outlined. To ensure an application-driven interoperability, approaches for synchronization and coordination are discussed. Examples of Distributed Systems in use are overviewed. Finally, part three will overview the role of security in Computer Networks and Distributed Systems concludes this class.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: A talk and presentation of 45 min by utilizing slides on-site will be followed by a 45 min moderated discussion with theses and questions posed to the seminar audience. These tasks have to be complemented by a written, complete report (publishable quality), including bibliographic references, by utilizing a mandatory LaTeX report template. More details will be available on the seminar's Web page, which can be found as a sub-directory of www.csg.uzh.ch/csg/en/teaching.html.
PrecognitionDescription: The knowledge of communications (Internet, telecommunications) is important, and a basic economic background would be very good, but not essential.
ObjectiveDescription: This seminar addresses the integration of technical and economic aspects into homogeneous overall systems and its application in today's economy. This determines the key goal. In terms of a seminar and didactic school, the seminar report, presentation, and discussion determines the second goal. Thus, all these three areas will be guided by a local supervisor, which will result in a basic and small research work. The final marking of this seminar will embrace a pre-step on scientific work and research documentations. Content (technology and economics) and its homogeneous integration are of importance.
MaterialDescription: Literature will be offered as a kick-start within the kick-off meeting, further literature study is a must! Depending on the number of interested students, the seminar will be run as one person/one report and presentation manner or with a two persons/one report and presentation manner.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Each student will receive one topic. The language is English.
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool :studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription: The content of this seminar will address current topics and questions on Internet Economics - covering technical and economic aspects, always in an inherent manner. The dedicated topics will be announced during the kick-off meeting for all people interested. They will most likely include communications, blockchains, incentives, security, and decentralized systems aspects.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Students are supposed to give presentations about the topics included in their research paper. Bachelor students should prepare talks of 20-30 minutes, and a Q/A session of up to 15 minutes will be subsequent of each talk.
Research material is handed out to the students three weeks before their presentation date to assure equal preparation time for each student. The grading is based on six parts:
Content of the talk (20%), the presentation material (15%), presentation performance (25%), timeliness (10%) and the ability to answer questions (10%). Acting as a host will also influence the final grade (20%).
SmText: Seminar: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning (BSc)
PrecognitionDescription: Some papers are heavy on math, so a good knowledge of analysis, algebra and statistics will help to understand these topics. Skills in the creation of presentation media (Powerpoint, LaTeX Beamer, or alike) is advisable.
ObjectiveDescription: At the end of the course, the students are supposed to have understood their selected topic in detail and have gotten a good overview on the topic of the course. Additionally, students have gained experience on how to prepare and give an informed presentation about a scientific topic with limited preparation time. Students will also act as the host for the talk of another student, to learn how to prepare questions for presentations and how to act as a presentation host.
MaterialDescription: Topics will be handed out without additional literature, but with hints on how to find information. A short literature review is required.
LanguageDescription: Presentations will be generally held in English for Bachelor and Master students. Bachelor students might opt to present in German.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool :studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Participation of students is required for 9 out of the 12 days of presentation, usual exemptions apply.
CommonDescription: This Seminar introduces basic and advanced topics of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning. The course in HS2024 will focus on Deep Learning, providing insights into the basic technologies, showing different use cases of deep learning systems, highlighting the latest trends in deep learning applications, and presenting vulnerabilities and explanations of deep networks functions.
AudienceDescription: Students in term 5 or higher of the BSc program.
