ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Midterm exam (40%)- Passing the midterm exam is required to pass this module (1. November 2024, 12:15-13:45).

Essay writing assignments (30%)

Essay evaluation assignment (10%)

Discussion exam (20%)-The discussion exam is done in groups.

Each group will sign up for two appointments (one observation + one exam) between 11 November - 16 December. The sign up form will be announced in the first lecture.
ObjectiveDescription:
1. Students understand concepts and processes in cognitive psychology and can articulate how these theories apply to work situations.
  2. Students know conceptual frameworks for understanding and assessing research contributions.
  3. Students can identify the primary contributions of research papers
  4. Students can assess the credibility of sources of scholarly publications
  5. Students can analyze scholarly arguments and assess their quality
  6. Students can synthesize knowledge from multiple readings
  7. Students can formulate and communicate constructive critiques in scholarly contexts
  8. Students can articulate the strengths and weaknesses of selected research methods
MaterialDescription: Lecture slides and scientific texts will be provided during the semester.
FurtherInfoDescription: Before 2024, this module is organized in a self-study format. From 2024 onward, this module is a lecture course.
CommonDescription:
This course is an introductory module for People-Oriented Computing.

Students will gain learn knowledge and skills in individual and collaborative work, to work with scholarly literature, and to conduct scholarly discourses. They will learn concepts and processes from cognitive psychology and how to apply them to improve their thinking and work by themselves and with others. Students will learn several conceptual frameworks that could help them understand and assess research contributions. They will learn about components and forms of arguments and critiques. This course will use the scholarly literature from various fields related to People-Oriented Computing.
AudienceDescription: MSc students with a major in POC.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
25% problem sets, 75% exam. Both grading parts also need to be passed individually. Written examination onsite: 15.01.2025 10:15-12:00

Active participation in the evaluation event on the 11.12.24 and
18.12.24 as well as additional intermediary evaluation events during class time is required: The precise schedule for these events will be published at the beginning of the term.
PrerequisitesDescription:
This course assumes that you have taken an introductory AI course such as Introduction to Artificial Intelligence (offered in the spring term) or the previously offered Practical AI.
This is roughly equivalent to covering Chapters 1 - 18 in the Book Artificial Intelligence A Modern Approach 4th Ed.
PrecognitionDescription: You are expected to write large pieces of code in the assignments whilst relying on various programming library/frameworks.
ObjectiveDescription:
The students can

  • apply the theory and practice of advanced AI methods to realistic scenarios
  • develop novel AI methods & applications based on existing cutting-edge research
  • reason about the impact of AI applications on society and devise methods that exploit the technology's advantages whilst mitigating the risks
MaterialDescription: To be announced. Please check course web-site as well as the course's OLAT page.
CommonDescription:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques have become ubiquitous: we all repeatedly interact with artefacts that are driven by some AI technology.
The goal of this course is to go beyond the foundational approaches (which are covered in other classes) and explore advanced topics in artificial intelligence such as large-scale knowledge processing, encoding mechanisms for unstructured and structured data, the combination of various AI approaches to provide intelligent systems, as well as notions of human-AI collaboration and coordination spanning from collective intelligence to ensuring notions of fairness, accountability, transparency and diversity.
AudienceDescription: For students of the Artificial Intelligence MSc Program.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
There will be a mandatory written exam and mandatory coursework during the semester. To pass the module, the students must pass the written exam and successfully complete the coursework. The final grade will be determined based on the written exam and coursework.

The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on Monday, 13.1.2025, 15:45 - 18:15. The exam itself will take 2 hours and 15 minutes.
PrerequisitesDescription: Introductory courses on continuous mathematics, linear algebra, probability theory, such as: WWF courses Mathematics I, Mathematics II, and Statistics.
PrecognitionDescription: Familiarity with Python is necessary for the practical project.
ObjectiveDescription: This course introduces supervised and unsupervised learning. Students will learn the algorithms that underpin popular machine learning techniques. They will also develop an understanding of the theoretical relationships between these algorithms. The practicals will concern the implementation of machine learning algorithms and applications of machine learning.
MaterialDescription:
Lecture slides, lecture notes, and code will be provided during the semester.

Main book references:

  • C. M. Bishop. Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning. Springer
    2006.
  • I. Goodfellow, Y. Bengio, A. Courville. Deep Learning, MIT Press
    2016.
  • K. P. Murphy. Machine Learning: A Probabilistic Perspective. MIT Press 2012.

These books are also available in electronic format.
CommonDescription: Introduction to data science and different paradigms of machine learning; Linear prediction, Regression; Maximum Likelihood; Regularization, Generalization, Cross Validation; Optimization; Logistic Regression; Generative Models for Classification, Gaussian Discriminative Analysis, Naïve Bayes; Support Vector Machines; Kernel Methods; Neural Networks, Backpropagation; Clustering; Dimensionality Reduction, PCA.
AudienceDescription: MSc in Data Science; MSc in Artificial Intelligence; MSc in Software Systems; MSc in Information Systems

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: The examination of this module will take place onsite. A written exam will be held on 8.01.2025, 08:00 hours. In case of a smaller attendance, this written exam may be replaced by an oral exam for each student separately, for which dates and timing will be communicated at a later stage, latest at the last class in term.
PrerequisitesDescription: The lecture "Computer Networks and Distributed Systems (CNDS)" is recommended highly, but formally not mandatory, in case of a personal dedication to get hold of those basics on the students' own will.
PrecognitionDescription: see «Voraussetzungen»
ObjectiveDescription: Students will receive a deep insight into protocols for multi-media communications, Quality-of-Service (QoS) models, and supporting network technologies. More specifically, the lecture will teach up-to-date knowledge in networks, covering available technology and research. This will enable students to develop on their own at a later stage efficient, performing, and globally applicable multi-media communications. Those protocols and mechanisms taught may leave the grounds of typical text books, which provides hooks to students to see in which way research in that field is undertaken. The finalizing discussion of technologies and QoS-based services offered takes into account where applicable economic incentives, which may limit or encourage the use of a dedicated communication service.
MaterialDescription: Relevant material as well as lecture slides can be found on the lecture's Web site, which is part of the CSG's teaching material's collection at www.csg.uzh.ch/csg/en/teaching.html.
CommonDescription:
Based on the basic course on communication networks, this PMMK lecture will deepen concepts and principles of efficient networking, advanced communication protocols, data formats and procedures, and their respective Quality-of-Service (QoS) management. It does address the basics in high-speed networks and optical networks, including Passive Optical Networks (PON) being complemented by ADSL, the IP Technology, and MPLS.
It is important to note that the PMMK lecture does address an integrated viewpoint of a full communication system, which does outline dependencies of networks, protocols, QoS and network or protocol architectures, especially by addressing QoS basics and its modeling, QoS methods, and QoS monitoring.
Additionally, protocols for an operations management, multimedia transport protocols (RTP, SCTP), messaging and overlays (VPN, CDN), optimized transport for multimedia and real-time streaming, and Software-defined Networks (SDN) are introduced and discussed.
AudienceDescription: Recommended for students in the MSc program.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on Wednesday, 8.01.2025, 14.00 - 15.45h. In case of a low number of students there will be an oral exam (date and place by arrangement with the lecturer).
PrecognitionDescription: Prior knowledge of programming and software engineering at Bachelor level as well as Java knowledge
ObjectiveDescription:
The participants know the core concepts of object-oriented software development. They can apply common design patterns to typical problems.
Furthermore, they are able to evaluate a simple software design, suggest improvements and also implement them.
MaterialDescription: Documents and literature will be announced in the lecture.
CommonDescription: The lecture provides a comprehensive overview of object-oriented software development. After a short introduction to the basics of object-orientation, the focus is on class libraries, design patterns, and frameworks. Primarily Java and Java-based frameworks such as Spring are used for illustration.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The evaluation is based on the grading of the team presentation as well as the result of the exam, the team presentation counts 1/3, the oral exam 2/3. There will be face-to-face oral exams on January
6 & 7, 2025.
PrerequisitesDescription: Basis in Software Engineering and Modeling
PrecognitionDescription: Basis in Software Engineering and Modeling
ObjectiveDescription: Students learn how architects work and which basic work products are used to specify architectures.
MaterialDescription: Slides of the lectures and additional reading material are made available via OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription: This module will be an onsite course. The course includes work for a team presentation, for which attendance in the classroom is mandatory.
CommonDescription: The course addresses Enterprise IT Architectures in a digital world by providing an introduction to the work of an architect in the IT industry. Architectural Methods are used to structure, describe, and specify solutions, and to define scope and context as well as logical and runtime architectures based on functional and non-functional requirements. Work products, documents, diagrams and models are discussed and used in order to specify and communicate the architecture of a solution. The students will work in a team on a proposal of a real case and will present their case studies in one of the lectures. In addition, current important technology concepts like cloud computing, web security, SOA (Service Oriented Architecture) and BPM (Business Process Management) will be introduced. Finally, Enterprise Architecture concepts and Governance of architectures within a complex organizational structure of a company will be discussed.
AudienceDescription: Recommended for students in the MSc studies.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
This course will be a project and paper-based course. The research project component is the primary component of the course; the outcome of all projects and/or project steps will be write-ups (similar to research papers or parts thereof). To pass this course, you must pass the research project component (obtain at least 50%) and must obtain a 50% overall mark that is based on the following:

  • 65%: Project, including write-ups (including proposal and intermediate reports), presentation, continuous progress, and meetings;
  • 35%: Readings, including response papers, class participation & leading discussion (in-person class attendance is mandatory), and peer reviews of project write-ups.
PrecognitionDescription: An undergraduate software engineering or human-computer interaction course and experience developing software as part of a team, as well as familiarity with issues in software engineering and with reading research papers would be helpful.
MaterialDescription: List of references will be on the course website.
FurtherInfoDescription: In this course, you will be reading research papers, leading interactive paper discussion(s), critiquing papers, participating in peer reviews, and undertaking steps involved in a research project. The research project component will be flexible but likely involve activities such as identifying research questions, designing (and potentially developing) an approach or study to address these research questions, analyzing data, and writing up the steps. Depending on the class size, certain parts of the research project component may be completed in groups of up to three. The intent of the project is to get students to think about a research problem, identify a research question, investigate it, and write it up in a scientific manner.
CommonDescription:
Producing great software as fast as the market demands requires great, productive developers. Yet, what does it mean for an individual developer to be productive, and how can we best help developers to be productive? To answer these questions, researchers in software engineering have been, and are still predominantly looking at the output that software developers create, such as the applications, the source code, or the test cases. This output-oriented focus misses one of the most essential parts in the process of software development: the individual developer who creates the software.

Recent advances in technology afford the opportunity to collect a wide variety of detailed information on a software developer and her work, ranging from the number of resolved work items all the way to the cognitive load the developer experiences while working. The availability and accessibility of data on each developer is enabling us to explore questions about developer productivity in powerful new ways.

In this course, we investigate how we can ensure the human ingenuity and smarts are being amplified by the processes and tools used to create systems, rather than the humans spending precious cognitive effort dealing with mundane or unnecessary problems.

The course will be adjusted according to your feedback, interests, and experience. This is an overview of the kinds of topics we could cover:

* quantitative & qualitative evaluation of software engineering research
* (biometric) sensing in software development
* developer retrospection, productivity, and well-being
* work fragmentation and interruptions
* code navigation & exploration
* program comprehension
* software development tools and environments.
AudienceDescription: Graduate students with an interest in software engineering research.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
50 % Final Grade - Assignments
50 % Final Grade - Final Project (Involving research, report submission and oral presentation)
PrecognitionDescription:
Fundamental courses in statistics (e.g. Empirical Methods MOEC0021).

Basic to medium programming skills (the course is taught in Python, so an introductory material to the level of Hot to Think Like a Computer Scientist: Learning with Python 3 [Chapters 1 - 15] is sufficient) Bibliography:
openbookproject.net/thinkcs/python/english3e/
ObjectiveDescription:
At the end of the course students:

  • are able to construct network representations of complex datasets
  • characterise and understand topological properties of networks
  • know the typical characteristics of networks in social, economic and technology systems
  • can understand mechanisms that lead to the emergence of large scale network properties
MaterialDescription: Lecture slides, online resources.
FurtherInfoDescription: This course replaces "Network Science for Business, Economics, Informatics and Social Sciences" (MOEC0572), which will be discontinued from HS21. Students which have already successfully passed "Network Science for Business, Economics, Informatics and Social Sciences" (MOEC0572), are not allowed to book this course.
CommonDescription:
Network Science is an interdisciplinary field of research that has become synonym with the study of multiple complex systems that pervade social and economic systems. Network refer to representations of systems whose constituents are linked together because of social ties, information flow, economic relations, etc. Network modelling is a methodology with ample applications in modern data-intensive fields which has multiple applications in management, marketing, informatics, among multiple others.

The course covers topics a wide range of topics: it starts with an introduction to the basic concepts about networks; it then deals with the most important properties that real-world networks exhibit, and how they can be modelled; then, it introduces network analytic techniques to uncover the most important properties of empirical networks. Finally, an introduction to the diffusion of technologies, opinions and rumours (and viruses!) are taught.

During the course, special emphasis is employed in introducing network analysis and visualisation tools.The course is highly interactive. All the lectures consist of a theoretical part, then, the students must develop (in small groups and always supported by the instructors) the some practical exercises themselves. This permits them to gain direct experience and familiarity with the concepts taught and the techniques involved. In this participatory environment, multiple exercises and the creation of visualisations play an important role.
AudienceDescription:
Students from Data Science and AI tracks will use constantly these results.
Students from Economics, Management, Management and related areas (like those from Social Sciences) will also have the opportunity to learn new tools of great value in their work life.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
• Successful group presentation of one exercise solution in the lab during the semester.
  • The examination for the module takes place on site. Oral or written exam by arrangement with the lecturer and depending on the number of participants. Written exam on 15.01.2025, 16:15-18:00.
SmText: Database Systems Lab MSc (Praktikum Datenbanksysteme MSc)
PrerequisitesDescription: Course "Database Systems" is mandatory.
PrecognitionDescription: Databases, in particular basic SQL skills (bachelor level)
ObjectiveDescription: Consolidation of knowledge and practical experiences in database technology
FurtherInfoDescription: There is very little classical lecturing and lecturer presentation. It is expected that students attend regularly, prepare individual sessions, and actively participate in the lab in order to solve exercises.
CommonDescription: In the database lab students apply their database skills in order to implement the database component of a complex yet doable application. They develop conceptual and logical data models, define consistency constraints, formulate SQL queries, and implement user-defined functions and triggers.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: In order to pass the lab course, all of the three following criteria have to be met individually: Attendance of all lab sessions; fulfillment of all exercise tasks; 10 min oral presentation on a self-chosen topic from the areas covered by the lab course.
PrerequisitesDescription: Interest in communication systems; attendance of "Computer Networks and Distributed Systems (CNDS)" is highly recommended.
PrecognitionDescription: Basic knowledge of IP networks, which can be based on "Computer Networks and Distributed Systems (CNDS)".
ObjectiveDescription: This practical course exists to strengthen and deepen the knowledge within the range of the communication and distributed systems by a set of selected practical tasks.
MaterialDescription: Material will be handed out during the first Lab session.
FurtherInfoDescription: As the number of participants is limited to 16, students are required to send an email to Jan von der Assen (vonderassen@ifi.uzh.ch) for registration. A first come, first serve approach is implemented. A waiting list will be maintained.
CommonDescription:
During this lab course, students study the setup and configuration of wired and wireless IP networks. Additionally, the operation of selected applications are analyzed in order to identify application requirements.
Both Windows and Linux are used as underlying operating systems. In this lab course, students have to solve practical exercises on different topics. The set of solutions is discussed and prepared in groups of students. Exercises include topics about network protocols, setup and configuration of a LAN network, firewalls, iptables, DNS, honeypot analysis, Web application security, wargames, Blockchain basics, Smart Contract development, and data forensics.
AudienceDescription: Recommended for students in the MSc studies.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Sufficient and successful completion of exercises and the Challenge Task (CT) during the semester within which the latter includes a short, but precisely written report and a respective presentation of successfully running code. The examination of the module will take place onsite. Final written exam on 15.1.25 from 10 am - 12 pm.
PrerequisitesDescription: The class on "Computer Networks and Distributed Systems (CNDS)" is highly recommended to be taken before. The attendance of "Computer Engineering and System Software (CESS)" is considered to be useful as well. The "Communication Systems Lab" can be either taken after or before CNSP.
PrecognitionDescription: This class requires bachelor-level knowledge in networking basic concepts, such as basics of networking architectures and protocols, the ISO/OSI and Internet protocol stack, and TCP/IP protocols.
ObjectiveDescription:
Students will deepen their knowledge on basic concepts and applied cryptography of network security principles, in particular to (a) understand basic principles of network security (such as confidentiality, integrity, availability), major threats, cryptography mechanisms (symmetric and asymmetric), essentials of cloud security, existing security guidelines and risk assessment frameworks, as well as to understand the intersection between Machine Learning (ML) and Cybersecurity; (b) identify basic and advanced (i.e., basics of penetration testing) network security problems and propose associated solutions, being necessary the evaluation and classification of risk, as well as the association of basic mitigation measures, and (c) apply basic security concepts (such as security policies, access control mechanisms, firewalls and intrusion detection systems) in different network architectures and protocols, as well as detailing advanced security mechanisms for communications.

At the end of the course, students will be able to demonstrate the following skills: (a) know and apply security protocols based on thread models defined, (b) elaborate access control policies for networks and IT systems, (c) prepare failure recovery and incident response plans, and (d) install and configure security tools for computer networks and their devices.
MaterialDescription: Books as well as lecture slides can be found on the lecture's Web site, which is part of the CSG's teaching material's collection at www.csg.uzh.ch/csg/en/teaching.html.
CommonDescription:
This class on "Computer Network Security Principles (CNSP)" involves the study of mechanisms related to security in computer network environments as well as studies of protection mechanisms, policies and security culture, and necessary mitigation options of attacks. Furthermore, it includes selected aspects of practical relevance, such as viruses, fraud, cryptography, and unauthorized access.

Students will be able to enhance their competencies with respect to their understanding of the design, development, and prototyping of security policies, being essential to manage security in computer networks. For this, a variety of mechanisms are discussed, such as basic security concepts, cryptographic principles on different layers, network security guidelines and information risk management, intrusion detection and prevention combined with network forensics based in Artificial Intelligence, security policies and metrics, and selected cybersecurity aspects and systems. In consequence, the design and management of security mechanisms for information systems as well as the determination and deployment of mitigation approaches in case of certain attacks will be possible.
AppointmentsDescription:
Thursdays 10.15 - 12.00: lecture
Wednesdays 10.15 - 12.00: exercises

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: A talk and presentation of 45 min by utilizing slides on-site will be followed by a 45 min moderated discussion with theses and questions posed to the seminar audience. These tasks have to be complemented by a written, complete report (publishable quality), including bibliographic references, by utilizing a mandatory LaTeX report template. More details will be available on the seminar's Web page, which can be found as a sub-directory of www.csg.uzh.ch/csg/en/teaching.html.
PrecognitionDescription: The knowledge of communications (Internet, telecommunications) is important and a basic economic background would be very good, but not essential.
ObjectiveDescription: This seminar addresses the integration of technical and economic aspects into homogeneous overall systems and its application in today's economy. This determines the key goal. In terms of a seminar and didactic school, the seminar report, presentation, and discussion determines the second goal. Thus, all these three areas will be guided by a local supervisor, which will result in a basic and small research work. The final marking of this seminar will embrace a pre-step on scientific work and research documentations. Content (technology and economics) and its homogeneous integration are of importance.
MaterialDescription: Literature will be offered as a kick-start within the kick-off meeting, further literature study is a must! Depending on the number of interested students, the seminar will be run as one person/one report and presentation manner or with a two persons/one report and presentation manner.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Each student each will receive one topic. The language is English.

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool :studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription: The content of this seminar will address current topics and questions on Internet Economics - covering technical and economic aspects, always in an inherent manner. The dedicated topics will be announced during the kick-off meeting for all people interested. They will most likely include communications, blockchains, incentives, security, and decentralized systems aspects.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Students are supposed to give presentations about the topics included in their research paper. Master students should prepare talks of 30 minutes, and a Q/A session of up to 15 minutes will be subsequent of each talk.
Research material is handed out to the students three weeks before their presentation date to assure equal preparation time for each student. The grading is based on six parts:
Content of the talk (20%), the presentation material (15%), presentation performance (25%), timeliness (10%) and the ability to answer questions (10%). Acting as a host will also influence the final grade (20%).
SmText: Seminar: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning (MSc)
PrecognitionDescription: Some papers are heavy on math, so a good knowledge of analysis, algebra and statistics will help to understand these topics. Skills in the creation of presentation media (Powerpoint, LaTeX Beamer, or alike) is advisable.
ObjectiveDescription: At the end of the course, the students are supposed to have understood their selected topic in detail and have gotten a good overview on the topic of the course. Additionally, students have gained experience on how to prepare and give an informed presentation about a scientific topic with limited preparation time. Students will also act as the host for the talk of another student, to learn how to prepare questions for presentations and how to act as a presentation host.
MaterialDescription: Topics will be handed out without additional literature, but with hints on how to find information. A short literature review is required.
LanguageDescription: Presentations of Master students will be generally held in English.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool :studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Participation of students is required for 9 out of the 11 days of presentation, usual exemptions apply.
CommonDescription: This Seminar introduces basic and advanced topics of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning. The course in HS2024 will focus on Deep Learning, providing insights into the basic technologies, showing different use cases of deep learning systems, highlighting the latest trends in deep learning applications, and presenting vulnerabilities and explanations of deep networks functions.
Events_1_EStext: Seminar: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning (MSc)

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
This course will be a project and paper-based course. The research proposal is the primary artifact of the course; the outcome of all projects will be a research proposal. To pass this course, you must pass the research proposal (obtain at least 50%) and must obtain a 50% overall mark that is based on the following:

  • 75%: Proposal, including continuous progress, meetings, write-ups (including final proposal and intermediate report), and presentation;
  • 25%: Readings, including active reading and collective annotations and discussions (Perusall), response papers, class participation, leading discussion (in-person class attendance is mandatory), and peer reviews of project reports.
PrecognitionDescription: Content of Software Engineering and Programming.
ObjectiveDescription:
In the end, students should

  • Have gained a deeper and broader understanding and knowledge of Software Engineering research by reading, analyzing, reflecting, and discussing current and classic literature;
  • Be able to identify and discuss research problems and questions as well as identify relevant related work;
  • Be able to peer review and provide constructive feedback on a research proposal and research papers;
  • Be able to write a research proposal in the form of a scientific report and present and discuss ideas on an advanced topic in software engineering research.
MaterialDescription:
Journal and conference papers. The list will be put on the web page of the course and announced in the first meeting, but are subject to change.

Course website: hasel.dev/teachings/hs24-sedp/
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription: This seminar will focus on selected topics in Software Engineering with a specific focus on the evolution of software as well as the humans involved in the development and their productivity and wellbeing. The course materials will consist of current and seminal research papers in the field.
AudienceDescription: Recommended for students in the MSc program

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The course includes mandatory assignments and a written final exam (Tuesday 07.01.2025, 08:00-10:00).

The exam for the module takes place as a bring-your-own-device exam, with proctoring on 07.01.2025, 8:00-10:00. To take the exam, you must use your own laptop (Windows or macOS). The exam cannot be taken on tablets. To take the exam, you must install the Safe Exam Browser (SEB) in advance and take a functional test as well as a mock exam using your individual technical equipment. Exact information on the required SEB version and other details will be provided to you during the semester.

The functional test will take place from 7-25 October, 2024 . Completion of the functional test is mandatory. Students who have not completed the functional test will not be admitted to the final exam and fail the course.
If you cannot complete the functional test due to illness or accident, you must email to support@oec.uzh.ch with a doctor's note.
PrecognitionDescription: Bachelor's degree
ObjectiveDescription:
After this course you will be able to:

  1. Understand and apply theoretical models in personnel economics
  2. Understand and apply empirical analyses
  3. Apply theoretical models to business problems
  4. Use empirical findings in order to assess the relevance of theoretical models for business practice
MaterialDescription:
OLAT Campus Course

www.business.uzh.ch/professorships/emap/teaching.html
FurtherInfoDescription:
The course includes mandatory assignments.

This module takes place on-site and online (podcast)
CommonDescription: www.business.uzh.ch/professorships/emap/teaching.html
AudienceDescription: Advanced students interested in empirical research and personnel economics from a business perspective.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination for the module takes place as a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) online exam on site on Tuesday, 17.12.2024 between 12:30 and
13:30h.
ObjectiveDescription:
-Evaluate the relative usefulness of accounting information for valuation purposes and incentive contracting
-Identify potential conflicts of interests between different uses of accounting information
-Use management accounting information for performance evaluation (budgeting, transfer pricing, incentive schemes)
-Understand the economic role of financial accounting to reduce incentive problems between a firm and their stakeholders
-Understand the basic determinants of voluntary disclosure
MaterialDescription: Course materials and lecture notes will be available on OLAT. A reading list will be provided in the lecture notes.
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place on-site and online (podcast).
CommonDescription: This course covers both financial and managerial accounting theory, with an emphasis on the role of accounting as an information source and its usefulness for facilitating and influencing decision making. Focusing on the different needs of different user groups (such as investors, firms or managers), the course discusses fundamental concepts from financial and managerial accounting and applies them to a series of economic problems. Topics include firm valuation, incentive contracting, budgeting, transfer pricing and earnings management. Related to these topics, some current practices and problems will be discussed.

PrerequisitesDescription: Completed bachelor's degree
ObjectiveDescription: Solving case studies using microeconomics
MaterialDescription:
Angner, E. (2020). A course in behavioral economics. Bloomsbury Publishing.
ppt-Folien
FurtherInfoDescription:
Business administration students (BWL) must register for this mandatory master module.
Economics (VWL) and M&E students must register for the mandatory module "Advanced Microeconomics 1" (MO0012).

This module takes place on-site.
CommonDescription: The course provides basic knowledge of micro-economics including decision theory, game theory, and market equilibrium through case studies.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Two Online Quizzes (2 x 15%), Final exam (70%) The quizzes will be carried out online on Tuesday, 15.10.2024, 16:15 -17:45 (90 min) and Tuesday, 19.11.2024, 16:15 - 17:45 (90 min).
The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on:
Tuesday, 14.01.2025, 16:15 - 17:45 (90min). To take the exam, you must bring your own laptop.

Online quizzes may be reattempted as needed in the event of the officially excused student absences. The schedule for these reattempts will be determined later.
SmText: Applied Empirical Methods for Business Administration
PrecognitionDescription: A course in probability and statistics as well as basic knowledge of linear algebra.
MaterialDescription:
Statistics for Business: Decision Making and Analysis
3rd edition (January 5, 2017)
Robert A. Stine (Author), Dean Foster (Author) Publisher: Pearson
Language: English
Hardcover: 830 pages
ISBN-10: 0134497163
ISBN-13: 978-0134497167
FurtherInfoDescription:
This module takes place on site and online (podcast).

The lecture with practical exercises takes only place in the fall semester.

In the spring semester there is offered a re-examination, for students who failed the exam.
CommonDescription: This course aims to provide master students in business administration with both the knowledge and a critical understanding of standard statistical methods applied in modern management. The course will emphasize the application of regression analysis for managerial decision-making. Students are expected to develop a thorough understanding of applied statistics which will enable them to analyze business data and interpret and report their findings. A series of entertaining yet realistic case studies are a central element of the course.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Exam and group projects may also be assigned during the semester. The examination for the module takes place as a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) online exam on site on Thursday, 23.01.2025
2-4pm.
ObjectiveDescription:
Topics covered

  1. Capital structure: Perfect markets and irrelevance
  2. Risk, leverage, taxes, and the cost of capital
  3. Leverage and financial ratios
  4. Payout policy: Dividends and share repurchases
  5. Capital structure: Taxes and bankruptcy costs
  6. Capital structure: Information asymmetries, agency costs, cash holdings
  7. Valuation: DCF, adjusted present value and WACC
  8. Valuation using options
  9. The use and pricing of convertible bonds
  10. Corporate risk management
MaterialDescription: Notes are to be downloaded from OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription: The lectures and exercise sessions will take place on-site.
CommonDescription:
This course develops and refines tools for evaluating investments (capital budgeting), capital structure, and corporate securities. With respect to capital structure, we start with the famous Miller and Modigliani irrelevance proposition and then move on to study the effects of taxes, bankruptcy costs, information asymmetries between firms and the capital markets, and agency costs. In this context, we will also study how leverage affects some central financial ratios that are often used in practice to assess firms and their stock. Other topics include corporate cash holdings, the use and pricing of convertible bonds, and risk management. The latter two topics involve option pricing. With respect to capital budgeting, the course pays special attention to tax effects in valuation, including in the estimation of the cost of capital. We will also study payout policy (dividends and share repurchases). The course seeks to deepen students' understanding of the link between corporate finance theory and practice. Cases may be assigned to reach this objective.
For further information please contact benjamin.schneider@df.uzh.ch.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Passing a group case study assignment (pass/fail only) ) and written examination. The case study assignment takes place during the semester (20% of final grade if passed successfully). The written examination of the module will take place onsite (80% of final grade). Written examination on: 7. January
2025, 14.00-15.30.
PrerequisitesDescription: Basic knowledge of Finance and Accounting.
ObjectiveDescription: Students will acquire expert knowledge to analyze and solve practical issues in corporate finance and develop problem-solving skills to conceptually and critically appraise challenge faced in corporate financial decision making in the future.
MaterialDescription:
The course will cover large parts of the book by Damodaran Applied Corporate Finance. The author also has made a PDF version of the 3rd edition of the book available:
pages.stern.nyu.edu/~adamodar/New_Home_Page/ACF3E/manuscript.htm

Slides are made available that cover the material discussed in class.
Parts of the slides closely follow the book and you should be able to understand the basic concepts based on the slides. The slides include a series of exercises.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This module takes place onsite.

Presence is not compulsory. However, please bear in mind that in-class participation and attendance will help you understand and master the course content. If you have questions for me, you should ask them in class rather than by email; if I have an announcement to make, I shall make it in class rather than post it on the course website.

You should contact the teaching assistant Thea Kolasa (thea.kolasa@df.uzh.ch) for any question regarding the course..
CommonDescription: In this course, students will be introduced to essential issues and concepts for financing firms. The course will be conceptual while at the same time being also practical and relevant. The module covers applied topics in finance. The module is built around lecture notes, which deliver the content and case studies that apply the content. The purpose of this course is the introduction of techniques to analyze major financial decisions made by firms. The course focuses on corporate finance concepts that can be applied directly to real-life financial decision making. Main topics covered in the course include hurdle rates and the cost of capital (i.e., the investment decision), the mix of debt and equity and the choice of the right kind of debt (i.e., the financing decisions), and basic valuation concepts (i.e., discounted-cash flow and multiples valuation. The course also discusses concepts related to sustainable finance or ESG issues as relevant for a corporate finance context. The course enables participants to make and assess complex corporate financial decisions.
AudienceDescription:
Management and Economics students.
Master of Science UZH ETH in Quantitative Finance students.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Written exam on Thursday, 9. January 2025 (14:00-16:00).

The examination of this module is carried out onsite. Attendance to the lecture is highly recommended. Both the abilities to think qualitatively and quantitatively are
required.
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place onsite and will be available as podcast.
CommonDescription:
Sustainability refers to the long-term welfare of a system. Our social, economic, and physical environments are strongly connected and the welfare of one subsystem depends on the welfare of the other subsystems. This course focuses on key aspects of sustainability, analyzing the financial and environmental dimensions.


The first part of the course deals with the field of sustainable finance, its main tools, approaches, and how they apply to real-world investors. Participants develop a deep understanding of how sustainable finance works, what the misconceptions are, where key barriers lie, and how to circumvent them.

Topics and papers explored focus on topics such as how which sustainable investing approaches can or cannot relate to real-world impact, if and how much investors care for impact and are willing to pay it, as well as challenges for the measurement of social, environmental, and governance sustainability of firms.

 

The second part of the course deals with two issues, the systemic risks generated by the financial system as well as environmental sustainability, which are described below.

 

  • Financial imbalances and the 2008 financial crisis have led to various criticisms against banks, financial supervisory authorities and central banks, but also against the academic world in Finance and Economics. One of the objectives of this advanced course is to draw lessons of these imbalances and, therefore, to undertake a critical analysis of current paradigms and models in finance. In particular, we will shed light on the size and complexity of financial markets and will explore the need for regulations of these markets in order to promote sustainable economic development. Possible measures to cure dysfunctions of the financial sector will be discussed.
  • During the last decade, climate change and biodiversity loss have emerged as the most serious environmental problems to be faced by mankind in the near future. The inherent dangers cannot be neglected; rather, the situation deserves urgent action to curb the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from which this problem arises and the rapid loss of biodiversity. Despite the urgency of the situation, at the international level, policy makers have been unable to implement agreements leading to significant emission reductions. The current situation raises a fundamental question that this part of the course aims to address. What is the nature of the relation between economic growth and the environment?

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
20% problem sets, 80% exam. The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on 13.01.2025, 10:00-12:00 am (2 hours).

No re-exam.
PrerequisitesDescription: A course in probability and statistics as well as basic knowledge of linear algebra.
MaterialDescription: See syllabus on OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This module takes place on-site and online (podcast).

Please contact EmpiricalMethodsTA@econ.uzh.ch if you have any questions.
CommonDescription: The course has two primary objectives. First, it explores the standard tools of modern empirical economic research, beginning with the linear regression model and then moving to more advanced methods such as generalized least squares, two-stage least squares, and maximum likelihood estimation. Second, it aims at sharpening your understanding of the prospects for, and limitations of, valid causal inferences from observational data. Tutorial exercises and case studies from the literature offer hands-on experiences in utilizing these concepts and methods.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on 9.1.2025, 8.00-9.45 am.

No re-exam.
PrecognitionDescription:
Basic knowledge of macroeconomics and mathematics (equivalent to Mathematik I/II and Makroökonomik I in Zurich).
It is NOT necessary to have attended "International Macroeconomics".
MaterialDescription:
Barro, Robert and Sala-i-Martin, Xavier (2003): Economic Growth, MIT Press.
Romer, David: Advanced Macroeconomics, 5th ed.
FurtherInfoDescription: This module will not be recorded/no podcast.
CommonDescription: Neoclassical Growth with Infinite Horizons, Overlapping Generations Models, AK Models, Models with expanding varieties (horizontal innovations), quality ladders (vertical innovations). Public Infrastructure and Growth. Human Capital and Growth.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on:
15 January 2025, 10.15-12.00 am.
PrecognitionDescription: passed exams Microeconomics I and II
MaterialDescription:
Gibbons, R. (1992): A Primer in Game Theory.
Additional reading material will be provided.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Master's students in Economics and Management & Economics have to book this course.
Business Administration students have to book "Advanced Microeconomics for Business Administration" (MOEC0269).

This module takes place on-site; a podcast will be made available on a limited basis.
CommonDescription: This course covers standard topics in non-cooperative game theory, such as normal and extensive form games, repeated games, and games with incomplete information. The course also covers extensions of non cooperative game theory to important economic contexts, including contracting. The course also presents an introduction to behavioral approaches to game theory. No previous knowledge of game theory is required.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Written discussion (c. 3 pages per paper, c. 10 pages in total) of, and oral examination (c. 10 minutes per paper, 30 min in total) on three research papers presented.
Date, time and location: end January 2025; further details to be communicated.
Students in early January 2025 suggest six papers to Felix von Meyerinck (felix.vonmeyerinck@bf.uzh.ch) who then chooses and communicates to the students those three papers they will be examined on.
PrecognitionDescription: Advanced knowlege of finance and economics.
ObjectiveDescription: To be exposed to and become familiar with cutting-edge research in finance
MaterialDescription:
Presentation of research papers by invited speakers and the related paper.
Titles/topics/speakers can be found at
www.df.uzh.ch/en/research/seminars/finance-seminar.html
FurtherInfoDescription: No restrictions on the number of participants. No separate registration is required. Those students wanting to take the examination must register via the Modulbuchungstool.
CommonDescription: Research seminar in which external speakers present their work. The seminar takes places weekly during the semester. Each seminar runs 75 minutes. Topics cover a wide range of topics, including asset pricing, corporate finance, banking, ESG, and macro-finance.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module is carried out onsite.

Witten Exam on: Monday, 6.01.2025, 08:00-09:45
SmText: The Economy of Risk in Insurance (L)
PrerequisitesDescription: Bachelor Degree
PrecognitionDescription: Basic Corporate Finance and Statistics
ObjectiveDescription: Through examples and case studies from the practice, we explain how sophisticated mathematical methods can be integrated in the efficient management of an insurance portfolio of risk. At the end of the course, students should be able to understand how a modern financial institution manages her risks.
MaterialDescription: You will receive a bibliography and a course schedule the first day of the course
FurtherInfoDescription:
On-site lecture without recording
Most of the course will be lectures in front of students, but we will provide some exercises to deepen the understanding and discuss case studies coming from practice. Extensive slides will be distributed to the students and a research project will be used to conclude the course.
CommonDescription:
The purpose of the course is to familiarize the student with the modern concepts of insurance in view of their application to pricing, capital management and solvency regulation. Most of those concepts are in line with the financial theory and apply to both P&C and life insurance.
The course is thought in five modules:

  1. In a first part, we present the concept of risk and risk measure and the pricing of risk in insurance.
  2. Aggregation of risk and dependencies
  3. Concept of capital and management of capital
  4. Adding time diversification to risk diversification
  5. Enterprise risk management towards a holistic approach to risk management

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place onsite.
Written exam on Monday, 18 November 2024, 14:00 - 15:30 (90 min)
PrerequisitesDescription: Bachelor Degree
PrecognitionDescription: Knowledge of calculus and basic statistics. Complementary introductory material on rudiments of stochastic calculus will be provided.
ObjectiveDescription: The module aims to introduce the new reality for banking and financial institutions in the aftermath of the 2008 crisis. Highly debated topics such as counterparty credit risk modeling, pricing of counterparty risk (CVA/DVA), cost of funding and collateral management will be examined in depth.
MaterialDescription:
Recommended literature
a) Discounting, Libor, CVA and Funding: Interest Rate and Credit Pricing, Kenyon, Chris and Stamm, Roland, 2012, Palgrave
b) Counterparty Credit Risk, Collateral and Funding: With Pricing Cases for All Asset Classes, Brigo, Damiano and Morini, Massimo and Pallavicini, Andrea, 2013, Wiley Finance
c) Interest rate models-theory and practice: with smile, inflation and credit, Brigo, Damiano and Mercurio, Fabio, 2006, Springer
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place on-site (no recording)
CommonDescription:
One of the challenges that the financial industry is facing after the crisis is to reach consensus on how to correctly assess counterparty credit risk. In particular, the two following practices emerged as consequence of the 2008 breakdown: (a) the splitting of the LIBOR curve in multiple curves (so to account for the different levels of credit risk embedded) and (b) the explicit inclusion of credit risk in the price of the trades. Additionally, (c) the new Basel III legislation brought much tighter rules on capital, defining RWA as the key parameter to assess the feasibility of any business strategy. Here below, more details on a)-c):
a) Multi-curves pricing: the market participants realized after the financial crisis that the banks contributing to LIBOR can also default.
This fact brings a plethora of basis spreads which need to be considered when pricing financial instruments. E.g. a forward rate agreement (FRA) which is fully collateralized (i.e. risk free) cannot be priced as an uncollateralized one. In addition, banks charge differently tenors on the yield curve (e.g. 3m vs 6m) taking into account the higher probability of default over the longer period of re-payment. Given that every market participant has a main funding currency, cross currency swaps are required to fund transactions in other currencies. The credit risk present in this process is reflected in a further cross currency basis that is included in pricing the trades.
b) CVA / DVA: financial institutions should charge for the counterparty risk they are taking, entering trades with defaultable counterparties.
The, so called, Credit Value Adjustment (CVA) is this additional component of the product's price. When CVA is taken into account even linear instruments, for instance vanilla swaps, acquire option-like characteristics. In bilateral agreements the counterparty risk is charged by both counterparties to ensure symmetry in the price-payoff [Bilateral CVA, i.e. CVA and Default Value Adjustment (DVA)].
c) Basel III: the new regulation which focus on the counterparty risk space (through the introduction of a capital charge for CVA) needs to be examined in focus by financial institutions to ensure optimal capital allocation/management, where a risk-return analysis will be actively part of the daily work and exposure.
These aspects will be discussed in a multi-asset class framework, working on real trading examples and complex portfolios. Best practices on modelling Counterparty Credit Risk, pricing under CVA and capital management will be added to the module to stimulate students who want to follow a Risk Management/Trading Career in Investment Banking.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Several in-class presentations and a written report.The final grade will be adjusted for class participation.Attendance is compulsory.
PrerequisitesDescription: Students must have a very strong background in corporate finance and accounting.
PrecognitionDescription: This course is open to Master level students in their second year only.
ObjectiveDescription: To learn how to analyze and value a company, to write a professional analyst report, and to give a professional analyst presentation.
MaterialDescription: Presentations by academics and practitioners.
LanguageDescription: English. All presentations will be conducted and all reports written in English.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This module takes place on-site. This course is a competition, and the number of participants is limited. Only students who have already taken advanced courses in corporate finance and accounting.

Selection procedure: Please register on OLAT by the end of August.

The exact dates and links can be found on the DF website. Please visit the DF website for further information:
www.df.uzh.ch/en/studies/lectures/seminars.html

5351
CommonDescription:
The course is intended to familiarize you with the work of financial analysts and to teach you how to conduct a hands-on, in-depth analysis of a specific company in its market environment. As do professional financial analysts, you will give an oral presentation of your results (max. 10 minutes) and hand in a written report (max. 10 pages).

The best team of the seminar will represent UZH at the CFA Investment Challenge. The CFA Investment Challenge is part of a Swiss-wide competition to be held in February 2025. The Swiss winning team will qualify for the European eliminatory competition to be held in Spring
2025. The European winning team will in turn qualify for the final competition to be held in Spring 2025. For more information about the Challenge please see:
www.cfainstitute.org/en/societies/challenge

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Participation in regular meetings and performance presentations.
Submission of monthly reports. Slides of the presentations and monthly reports must be submitted electronically. The presentation themselves are held on site.
PrerequisitesDescription: Successful completion of Portfolio Management Theory 1 and 2
PrecognitionDescription: Portfolio Management Theory 1 and 2
ObjectiveDescription: Under the supervision of professors and practitioners, students learn to actively manage a portfolio, in a group setting, according to a predetermined investment strategy.
MaterialDescription: None
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of participants is limited. Only open to students who successfully completed Portfolio Management Theory 1 and 2.

This module takes place on site.
CommonDescription: Following a year of insight into the theoretical foundations of portfolio management and asset allocation, students are given the unique opportunity to implement what has been learned. They actively manage a portfolio, following a behavioral, quantitative or macroeconomic approach. Students provide regular performance updates in the form of monthly reporting sheets and regularly present on their portfolio holdings and performance to their peers, professors, and industry experts.
AudienceDescription: Masters students with an interest in portfolio management.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The exam takes place on site on the computer on January 14, 2025 (10:15-
12:45). Students must bring their own computer for the exam.
PrerequisitesDescription: Prior or simultaneous enrollment in the course "Asset Management: Advanced Investments."
PrecognitionDescription: Very good knowledge of finance, the functioning of financial instruments, and portfolio management as well as familiarity with quantitative investment strategies.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This module takes place on site.
The mandatory test run for this examination takes place on December 17,
2024 in the lecture hall.
CommonDescription: This course provides an introduction to programming in Matlab with a focus on portfolio management applications, in particular the backtesting of quantitative investment strategies. The course covers programming basics, creating scripts and functions, flow control, importing and exporting data, synchronizing data, statistical analysis of data, and the use of graphical tools to present results. The class is designed to provide students with tools for other classes, in particular the Portfolio Management Theory and Portfolio Management Implementation seminars. It is also useful for students planning to write a master thesis in the area of portfolio management.
AudienceDescription: Master's students with an interest in portfolio management.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place on site. Written exam on Monday,
13.01.2025, 10:15-12:00 hrs.

The Midterm examination of the module will take place on site on November 6,
2024, 10:15-12:00am.

The final grade for the course will be computed by taking the average of the midterm and final exam grades, with equal weight given to both assessments.
(Each exam will contribute 50% to the final grade.)
PrerequisitesDescription: Basic calculus knowledge is required.
MaterialDescription: 1. Slides and lecture notes
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place on-site.
CommonDescription: The course explains the basics of decision theory and general equilibrium theory which belong to the two main foundations for financial theory. Decision theory is needed for modeling investors' behavior in financial markets. General equilibrium theory is needed for asset pricing and valuation.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place on site. Written exam, Monday
06.01.2025, 14:00-16:00 (90 Min.)
PrerequisitesDescription: BA degree, ideally with a focus on Banking and Finance.
PrecognitionDescription: Very good knowledge of finance, solid background in mathematics and statistics (calculus, linear algebra, probability theory, regression analysis), and ideally knowledge in portfolio management.
ObjectiveDescription: The aim of this lecture is to provide students with the theoretical and empirical foundations of the key facets of modern asset management and to introduce them to advanced tools for quantitative asset management.
MaterialDescription: Slides with bibliographical references.
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place on site.
CommonDescription: The lecture covers financial market theory, the theoretical underpinnings of behavioral, quantitative, and macroeconomic approaches to portfolio management, strategic and tactical asset allocation, and methods used in the development of investment strategies. The course also covers a wide range of investment strategies spanning predictability and the cross-section of expected returns in equity, bond, currency, and options markets.
AudienceDescription: Masters students with an interest in portfolio management.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Final Presentations on Saturday, 14. December 2024 (08:00 - 12:00h) and/or Monday, 16 December 2024 (16:00 - 20:00h) The performance assessment is carried out by means of a final presentation and written reports on mini case studies.
Reports on case studies: 40% (two cases), final presentation: 40%, involvement/contribution to class discussion: 20%.
The course intends to allow for a fair amount of time for discussion.
Please only take the course if you intend to actively participate in a discussion.
PrecognitionDescription: A sound understanding of Corporate Finance is required. Attendance in the classroom is mandatory.
ObjectiveDescription:
• Governance Foundations
  • Governance Models
  • Legal Framework and Stewardship
  • CSR & ESG
  • Shareholders
  • Stakeholders & Proxy Advisors
  • Board of Directors
  • Compensation
  • Reporting & Audit
  • Disciplining Mechanisms

It is further planned to have a talk by a company as well as an investor representative on the topic of governance.
MaterialDescription:
The Seminar will include some E-learning elements which you are asked to do / follow prior to class sessions.
Class sessions are mandatory to attend.

The course will not follow a specific textbook. We will look at academic papers and other resources on corporate governance that are available online. A reading list will be distributed at the beginning of the course.

Further reading (voluntary):

  • Corporate Governance Matters by David Larcker & Brian Tayan, ISBN:
    978-0-13-351850-4
  • Handbook of the Economics of Corporate Governance, Editors: Benjamin

E. Hermalin & Michael S. Weisbach, ISSN: 2405-4380
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of students is limited. Please register by Email and include a copy of your latest Leistungsausweis (christoph.wenk@bf.uzh.ch).
The course intends to allow for a fair amount of time for discussion.
Please only take the course if you intend to actively participate in a discussion.

Learning method: case studies
CommonDescription: This course will provide students with a synthesis of Corporate Governance theory, key findings of the empirical academic literature, and actual examples from the market. The aim is to use the theoretical models and findings of the empirical literature to evaluate and qualify governance frameworks of individual companies as well as legal and regulatory proposals that are widely discussed in the media. The course will cover the main actors of Corporate Governance, from shareholders to the board of directors to auditors and regulators. Note that the course is not intended as a pure classical lecture, but also involves a fair amount of discussion about current governance developments and actual cases.
AudienceDescription: MA Students in Banking and Finance and WWF in general

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Active participation in the seminars; group presentations and exercises.
Slides of the presentations and exercises must be submitted electronically.
PrerequisitesDescription:
BA degree, ideally with a focus on Banking and Finance. Prior or simultaneous
enrollment in the courses "Asset Management: Advanced Investments" and "Matlab for Portfolio Management."
PrecognitionDescription: Very good knowledge of finance, solid background in mathematics and statistics (calculus, linear algebra, probability theory, regression analysis), and ideally knowledge in portfolio management.
ObjectiveDescription: The aim of the Portfolio Management Program (PMP) is to provide students with a fundamental theoretical and practical education in all key facets of modern asset management. The first two semesters, Portfolio Management Theory 1 and 2, enable students to develop a basis of theoretical knowledge. A special emphasis is placed on quantitative, behavioral and macroeconomic approaches with an eye towards practical applications. Based upon this, the students are afforded the rare opportunity to apply said knowledge in a practical setting during the Portfolio Management Implementation phase.
MaterialDescription: Diverse materials.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of participants is limited. The application details can be found on the IBF homepage:
www.cpm.uzh.ch/en/application-process.html. Once admission has been confirmed it is necessary to book the course through the relevant tool.

This module takes place on site.
CommonDescription: This seminar is the second component of the Portfolio Management Program (PMP), a comprehensive program spanning four semesters that combines recent developments in academic and applied research and "real-money" asset management. The seminar makes extensive use of the content covered in the "Asset Management: Advanced Investments" and "Matlab for Portfolio Management" courses, which are prerequisites for admission to this course. The topics covered include financial market theory, the theoretical underpinnings of behavioral, quantitative, and macroeconomic approaches to portfolio management, strategic and tactical asset allocation, methods used in the development of investment strategies, and investment strategies spanning predictability and the cross-section of expected returns in equity, bond, currency, and options markets.
AudienceDescription: Masters students with an interest in portfolio management.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: In-class presentations and written report.
PrecognitionDescription: Limited to the best performers among the students who took the CFA Investment Challenge.
ObjectiveDescription:
Develop a convincing and appealing equity story based on a thoroughly-grounded, consistent and precise valuation model.
Prepare a professional equity story presentation.
CommonDescription:
The purpose of the seminar is to prepare the team representing the University of Zurich for the Swiss semi-final and final of the CFA Investment Challenge.
That team in the vast majority of cases will be comprised of those students who won the Zurich final of the CFA Investment Challenge, but changes in team composition may occur in exceptional circumstances.
AudienceDescription: Limited to the best performers among the students who took the CFA Investment Challenge.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place onsite.
Written examination on Friday, 10 January 2025, 08:00-9:00 (60 minutes) Closed book. One cheat sheet.
PrerequisitesDescription: Bachelor's Degree
PrecognitionDescription: Knowledge of quantitative risk management techniques is desirable.
ObjectiveDescription: Participants will gain an understanding of key concepts of bank-wide stress testing including an overview of the structure of a bank and key risk types. Based on practical examples and publicly available data, participants will be provided hands-on deep dives in stress testing models as well as an overview of regulatory requirements and management usage. Stress testing will be illustrated for a sample bank.
MaterialDescription: Recommended literature will be provided throughout the course.
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place on-site.
CommonDescription:
In the aftermath of the financial crisis, regulators looked to ensure banks and financial institutions could survive a severe economic shock and no longer pose systemic risk. As a consequence, bank-wide stress tests became a key tool for risk management.
Bank-wide stress tests measure the resilience against a severe scenario such as a recession. A major advantage of stress tests, compared to more complex risk measures, is that its results are relatively easy to understand which facilitates the communication and usage. However, building a sound stress testing framework and stress testing models is complex.

TestsDescription: Verfassen eines Diskussionspapiers allein oder zu zweit (Umfang 15 Seiten pro Gruppe, Ablieferung bis Sonntag, 17.11.2024) und 20-minütige Präsentation der Arbeit im Blockteil mit anschliessender Diskussion
SmText: Brennpunkt Wirtschaftspolitik – Ökonomie im Kampf der Argumente (S) Focus on Economic Policy - Economics in the Struggle of
PrerequisitesDescription:
Teilnehmerzahl ist auf 30 Personen begrenzt.

Bei Übernachfrage werden prioritär die bis zum 3.9.2024 bei Christoph Eisenring (christoph.eisenring@avenir-suisse.ch) oder Jürg Müller (juerg.mueller@avenir-suisse.ch) eingegangenen Anmeldungen berücksichtigt.
Zudem wird ein kurzes Schreiben verlangt, in dem die Motivation zur Teilnahme am Seminar, der Stand der eigenen Ausbildung sowie ein speziell interessierendes Thema aus der Wirtschaftspolitik kurz dargelegt werden.
ObjectiveDescription: Vergleichende institutionelle Analyse
MaterialDescription:
Literatur zur Vorbereitung des Seminars:

* Jürg Müller, Basil Ammann, Laurenz Grabher Eine Medienpolitik für das digitale Zeitalter, Avenir Suisse, Zürich 2022.

  • What is Public Choice? Videos von Alex Tabarrok: marginalrevolution.com/?s=public+choice
    (marginalrevolution.com/?s=public)
  • Groenewegen, John, Antoon Spithoven and Annette van den Berg.
    "Institutional Economics - An Introduction. Palgrave McMillan, January
    2010.
    Online www.researchgate.net/publication258318787_Institutio nal_Economics_An_In
  • Freytag, Andreas and Gunther Schnabl. "Monetary Policy Crisis Management as a Threat to Economic Order", CESifo Working Paper No.
    6363, February 2017. www.econstor.eu/handle/10419/155605?locale=de (www.econstor.eu/handle/10419/155605?locale=de)
  • Weidmann, Jens. "Ordnungspolitik im digitalen Zeitalter". Referat, Deutsche Bundesbank
    2020. www.bundesbank.de/de/presse/reden/ordnungspolitik-im- digitalen-zeitalte
  • Friedman, Milton. 1962. Capitalism and Freedom. University of Chicago Press.
  • Hayek, Friedrich A. von. "Der Wettbewerb als Entdeckungsverfahren". in: von Hayek, Freiburger Studien, 1969, Tübingen, S. 349-365.

* Sowell, Thomas. 2014. Basic Economics. A common sense guide to the economy. Basic Books, New York.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Dieses Seminar wird von zwei externen Dozenten durchgeführt: Dr. Christoph Eisenring ist Senior Fellow (ab 15.6.2024), Dr. Jürg Müller Direktor beim Think Tank Avenir Suisse. Bei Fragen zum Seminar bitte die Dozierenden (Ch. Eisenring, christoph.eisenring@avenir-suisse.ch oder J. Müller, juerg.mueller@avenir-suisse.ch) kontaktieren.


Das Seminar findet vor Ort statt und wird nicht aufgezeichnet.
CommonDescription: Die Veranstaltung "Brennpunkt Wirtschaftspolitik - Ökonomie im Kampf der Argumente" ist auf Themen der wirtschaftspolitischen Debatten ausgerichtet. Sie wird teilweise als Blockveranstaltung durchgeführt. Ziel ist es, das Kräftemessen der Interessengruppen in der Politik ökonomisch zu analysieren und zu diskutieren. Zentrale Themen sind Privateigentum, Wettbewerb, Gerechtigkeit und Freiheit.
AppointmentsDescription:
Einführende Vorlesungen am Donnerstag:
19.9., 26.9., 3.10.
jeweils von 12.15 bis 13.45 Uhr

Blockseminar Do/Fr 21./22.11.2024 von 8 bis 17 Uhr

TestsDescription: Vortrag und Seminararbeit (schriftliche Bearbeitung eines Themas vor Seminarbeginn).
SmText: Geschäftsmodelle in liberalisierten Märkten (S)(Business Models for Liberalized Markets)
PrecognitionDescription: BWL II (Strategisches Management)
MaterialDescription: Werden in der Veranstaltung bekannt gegeben.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Das Seminar findet als Blockseminar am Freitag, 24. Januar 2025 von
12:00-18:00 Uhr statt. Die Infoveranstaltung findet am Dienstag,
01.10.2024 um 18.15 Uhr statt (Teilnahme als zwingende Voraussetzung).
Anmeldung / Bewerbung (Leistungsausweis, CV und Motivationsschreiben in einem einzigen PDF Dokument) bis spätestens 1. September 2024 via Modulbuchungstool (studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad).



Bewerbungen nach dem 1. September sind per Mail (an pascal-flurin.meier@business.uzh.ch) möglich.
CommonDescription:
Neue Technologien und Produkte schaffen ein neues Angebot oder beeinflussen mit neuen Akteuren die Marktstruktur, neue Bedürfnisse der Konsumenten verändern die Nachfrage. Daneben werden Märkte wie z.B. Energie, Telekommunikation, Medien oder auch der Bankensektor entscheidend von der Regulierung geprägt.
Häufig findet diese Regulierung gerade wegen einer formellen Öffnung des Marktes für den Wettbewerb mit (privater) Konkurrenz statt. Regulierungen schaffen Markteintrittsmöglichkeiten, etwa weil sie den Zugang zu einer Netzinfrastruktur ermöglichen (Stichwort Unbundling, Zugang zur letzten Meile etc.), oder sie stellen die Aufrechterhaltung eines besonderen, von der Öffentlichkeit erwünschten Leistungsniveaus (Service public) sicher. Nicht selten sind in solchen (teil-) liberalisierten Märkten die vormaligen (staatlichen) Monopolisten weiterhin in einer relativ starken Position - nicht nur wegen ihrer Grösse, sondern auch aufgrund günstiger regulatorischer Rahmenbedingungen, die sie durch ihre Staats- und Verwaltungsnähe zu sichern verstehen. Umgekehrt können anhaltende staatliche Eigentümerschaft und/oder politische Einflussnahme auch besondere Nachteile schaffen. Zudem agieren neue, in den Markt eintretende Unternehmen oft flexibler und können sich eher auf besonders attraktive Segmente fokussieren. Unternehmen in liberalisierten und gleichzeitig hoch regulierten Märkten stehen daher vor besonderen strategischen Herausforderungen. Wie gehen beispielsweise vormalige Monopolisten damit um, dass durch eine formelle Marktöffnung neue Konkurrenz entstehen könnte? Welche Markteintrittsstrategien wählen neue Unternehmen? Und wie beeinflussen neue Technologien wie die Digitalisierung Markteintrittsbarrieren?
AudienceDescription: Studierende, die den Bereich des strategischen Managements vertiefen und/oder eine wissenschaftliche Arbeit an unserem Lehrstuhl schreiben wollen.
