TestsDescription: Eigenständiger Seminarbeitrag in Gruppen (Lösung der Praxisfälle und Präsentation).
SmText: Unternehmensbewertung in der Praxis (S) (Valuation in practice)
PrecognitionDescription: Fundierte Kenntnisse in Corporate Finance werden erwartet. Diese werden in den BA-Veranstaltungen "Corporate Finance" und "Corporate Finance 2" sowie "Unternehmensbewertung und M&A" vermittelt.
ObjectiveDescription: Anwendung der theoretischen Kenntnisse im Bereich der Unternehmensbewertung anhand der Bearbeitung von Praxisfällen.
MaterialDescription:
Spezifische Seminarunterlagen werden bei der Vorbesprechung abgegeben Hintergrundliteratur zur Unternehmensbewertung sind: Volkart, R.: Unternehmensbewertung und Akquisitionen, 3. Auflage, Zürich 2010 und Volkart,
R./Wagner A.F.: Corporate Finance, Grundlagen von Finanzierung und Investition,
7. Auflage, Zürich 2018 und Koller, T./Goedhart, M./Wessels D.: Valuation - Measuring and Managing the Value of Companies, 7th edition, New York 2020.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Die Teilnehmerzahl ist beschränkt. Anmeldungen sind unter Einreichung eines Lebenslaufes, eines aktuellen Leistungsausweises und eines kurzen Motivationsschreibens (Begleitbrief) möglich. Anmeldungen senden Sie bitte per Email bis Montag, 20. Mai 2024 an Simone.Thurnherr@ifbc.ch.
Die definitiven Teilnehmer werden per Email informiert. Nach Erhalt der Zulassungsbestätigung ist zusätzlich eine Anmeldung im Modulbuchungstool notwendig (Fristen und Studiengang beachten!).
Am Mittwoch, 27. Mai 2024 werden die Teilnehmer anlässlich einer Veranstaltung über den genauen Ablauf des Seminars orientiert und die Praxisfälle für die Gruppenarbeiten vergeben. Weitere Informationen finden sie auf www.bf.uzh.ch.

Vorbesprechung: Montag, 27. Mai 2024, 08:15 - 10.00 Uhr
CommonDescription:
Zum Thema Bewertung von Unternehmen und Vermögenswerten bietet das Blockseminar Unternehmensbewertung in der Praxis Studierenden die Chance, erworbenes Wissen aus dem Studium zu vertiefen und in spezifischen Fallstudien praxisnah anzuwenden. Dabei werden die Studierenden von Fachexperten mit jahrelanger Praxiserfahrung durch das Seminar begleitet.

Die TeilnehmerInnen bearbeiten im Vorfeld ausgewählte Praxisfälle und präsentieren ihre Lösungen im Rahmen des Seminars. Während des Seminars werden verschiedene Fragestellungen anhand von realitätsnahen Fallstudien gelöst und diskutiert. Dabei nehmen die Studierenden u.a. die Rolle von Beratern im Rahmen einer Unternehmenstransaktion ein.

Die Bedeutung und Umsetzung von Unternehmensbewertungen und M&A in der Praxis wird zusätzlich durch einen Gastreferenten eines kotierten Unternehmens erläutert. Zudem geben Berater Einblicke in die Bewertungs- & Transaktionspraxis anhand ihrer Erfahrung.
AppointmentsDescription:
Donnerstag 24.Oktober und Freitag 25. Oktober 2024, jeweils 08:00 Uhr bis 17:30 Uhr
Ort: extern / Raum Zürich

TestsDescription:
• Seminararbeit: Bearbeitung einer Fallstudie in Gruppen
  • Präsentation
  • Regelmässige Teilnahme und aktive Mitarbeit
SmText: Praxisfälle aus der Wirtschaftsprüfung (S) (Seminar: Selected Cases in Auditing)
PrecognitionDescription: Einführung in die Wirtschaftsprüfung
ObjectiveDescription: Die Studierenden erwerben Grundlagenkenntnisse der Wirtschaftsprüfung.
MaterialDescription: Fallstudien aus der Wirtschaftsprüfung
FurtherInfoDescription:
Die Teilnehmerzahl ist auf 24 Personen beschränkt. Zweitanmeldung direkt am Lehrstuhl erforderlich.
Hinweise zum Anmeldeverfahren siehe OLAT: https://t.uzh.ch/1Cy Nach Zuteilung eines Seminarplatzes müssen Sie diesen innerhalb einer gegebenen Frist bestätigen. Durch die Bestätigung wird die Anmeldung verbindlich und Sie verpflichten sich zur Teilnahme am Seminar.
CommonDescription: In diesem Seminar, welches in Zusammenarbeit mit KPMG Audit Financial Services Zürich durchgeführt wird, werden von den teilnehmenden Studierenden Fallstudien bearbeitet und präsentiert. Dabei werden Fragen der externen Revision, diverse Problemstellungen im Bereich Prüfungsverfahren und -techniken sowie des rechtlichen Umfelds diskutiert.
AppointmentsDescription:
Freitag, 20.09.2024, 09:00 - 18 Uhr Einführung in das Seminar Freitag, 29.11.2024, 09:00 - 18 Uhr Abschlusstag: Präsentation und Diskussion der Fallstudien

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Combination of oral assessment (class participation, presentation, discussion) and written assessment (essay)
ObjectiveDescription:
At the end of the course, you should be
able to:

  1. Understand the practice approach to studying strategy.
  2. Understand how practices shape important aspects of strategy.
  3. Understand the role of strategists in the strategy process.
MaterialDescription: Journal articles (will be distributed to participants)
FurtherInfoDescription:
Places in the seminar are limited. Please apply via VVZ to participate in the seminar. Your application should include (1) a motivation letter, (2) your CV and (3) transcripts of your grades, including your current GPA (all in
one document).
Deadline for applications to be received: September 1st, 2024. Seminar participants will be selected and applicants informed about the selection decisions at the beginning of September.

Application for this course is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad/
CommonDescription:
While strategy is often understood as something organizations have, the strategy-as-practice perspective emphasizes strategy as something people in organizations do. In other words, strategy is seen as a social practice that is constituted by the daily activities of strategy actors. Taking this perspective, in this seminar we will discuss a range of important topics in strategy research, including the activities of different strategy actors (top and middle managers), the dynamics of strategic decision making, the process of strategic change, and the practices and tools used in strategizing. This seminar is primarily research-oriented and aims to provide students with the foundations to understand the practice-based approach to studying strategy.
Based on papers published in top international journals, we will discuss concrete research exemplars as to how strategists - top or middle managers - produce, reproduce and change strategy.
This seminar is highly participative. In each session, students are required to actively take part in discussions. During the semester, students are in charge of presenting papers of one session and to animate discussions in another one.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: The examination of the module is carried out as a combination of a group assignment and an exam (18. December 2024, 12:15-13:45).
PrerequisitesDescription: Bachelor Degree
PrecognitionDescription: "Banking" (bachelor programme level)
ObjectiveDescription:
(1) Define and explore the concept and practices of impact investing. (2) Apply empirical methods to assess the performance of impact investing, with applications to financial inclusion.
(3) Analyze the investment universe, practices and performance of financial institutions that serve low-income customers in developing economies.
MaterialDescription: Reading list and materials will be made available in the syllabus and lecture notes.
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place onsite and will be recorded as podcast.
CommonDescription:
Impact investing, defined by the Global Impact Investing Network (GIIN) as "investments made into companies, organizations, and funds with the intention to generate social and environmental impact alongside a financial return" (GIIN, 2018), has become an increasingly visible and fast growing part of the broader field of sustainable investing. This course draws from economics, management, and finance frameworks to explain the existence and explore the functioning of impact investing.

The course examines the characteristics and claims related to impact investing through a deep dive into the field of financial inclusion, also called microfinance. The financial inclusion industry in emerging and developing economies offers a variety of financial services to low- income and vulnerable customers who, in the past had been deemed "unbankable" because of their lack of assets, income, or security.
Specialized banks and non-bank institutions are offering services, commercial banks are "downscaling", mobile network operators offer financial services. Funding through aid agencies has long been complemented or substituted by impact and commercial investments.
Financial sector regulators are covering microfinance. Specialized investment funds and asset managers (a large share of whom are based in Switzerland), rating agencies, training institutes, and credit reference bureaus complement the industry, which, till today, receives a large share of development-oriented impact investments, much of it in private placements.

The course focuses on financial inclusion because this field is considered a pioneer and flagship in impact investing and an engine of growth to achieve a range of sustainable development goals. Financial inclusion is located at the intersection of public policies, regulations and public sector funding on the one hand, and private sector investments on the other hand, thus allowing to explore the links between impact investing and blended finance. Yet, the course also touches other industries which are considered recipients of impact investments.

TestsDescription:
Die Prüfung zum Modul findet vor Ort statt. Schriftliche Prüfung am Mittwoch,
02. Oktober 2024, 14:00 - 16:00
PrerequisitesDescription: Erfolgreicher Abschluss der Bachelor-Stufe.
PrecognitionDescription: Grundlagenkenntnisse Portfolio Theory und Anlageinstrumente.
ObjectiveDescription: Verstehen der Funktionsweise, der Besonderheiten, Einsatzmöglichkeiten im Rahmen der Asset Allocation und Risiken von Alternative Investments.
MaterialDescription: Unterrichtsmaterialien können über OLAT bezogen werden.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Blockvorlesung: 10., 11. und 13. September 2024, jeweils 09:00-18:00.
Prüfungstermin: Mittwoch , 02. Oktober 2024, 14:00-16:00. Bei Fragen wenden Sie sich bitte an Tim Müller (Tim.Mueller@ppcmetrics.ch). Es gibt keinen Podcast.
CommonDescription:
In der Vorlesung werden die Grundlagen von Alternative Investments und deren Einsatz im Rahmen der strategischen Asset Allocation von institutionellen Investoren erörtert:

  • Grundlagen: Bedeutung der strategischen Asset Allocation und Möglichkeiten zur Herleitung der strategischen Asset Allocation
  • Alternative Investments aus Sicht der Asset und Liability-Management
  • Grundlagen, Funktionsweise, Besonderheiten und Risiken ausgewählter alternativer Anlagen wie bspw.:

Commodities, Hedge Funds, Private Equity, Immobilien, Infrastructure, Insurance Linked Securities, Sustainable Investments

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
One final exam.
The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on: January 16, 2025, 10.00 - 12.00
PrerequisitesDescription: One semester of calculus, one semester of basic statistics or "Empirical Methods".
PrecognitionDescription: Undergraduate course(s) in calculus, and an introductory, "first semester" course in basic statistical inference
ObjectiveDescription: To have a working knowledge with the standard topics of basic probability theory, as required for a further study of related topics, such as statistical inference.
MaterialDescription:
Fundamental Probability: A Computational Approach, by Marc Paolella.
Wiley, 2006.
While the book is not absolutely necessary because lecture notes will be given out, it is highly recommended for complimentary reading, associated material not covered in lecture, many more examples, and large sets of exercises (with solutions available).
Further strongly suggested reading is Probability: A Lively Introduction, by Henk Tijms
CommonDescription: This 6 credit optional course covers fundamental concepts in probability theory, with some attention paid to concepts used in quantitative finance and risk management. After a quick review of basic set theory, basic calculus, and some basic combinatorics, we cover probability and conditioning, Bayes' Theorem, discrete and continuous random variables, conditional distributions, expectations, moments, sums, and transformations of (univariate and multivariate) random variables. We also cover the notion of fat-tailed distributions, and the basics of the financial risk measures Value-at-Risk and Expected Shortfall. Time permitting, we will also cover moment generating functions, and their use for sums of independent random variables, and the derivation of the main results of the multivariate Gaussian distribution. The course, though oriented towards Finance,is highly recommended for Master students in any quantitative field. Often, computer programs (Matlab) are shown and discussed in class for numerically computing solutions, but such material will not be tested.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written exam on
13.01.2025, 4:15-6:00 pm.
PrerequisitesDescription: Bachelor courses on Statistics and Introductory Econometrics
MaterialDescription: John A. Rice: Mathematical Statistics and Data Analysis (with CD Data Sets). Brooks/Cole, International student edition, 2006.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The module will not be recorded/no podcast.

The exercise class will start in week two only. On September 18, there will be a lecture instead to make up for another lecture later in the semester that will have to be canceled (on November 18).
CommonDescription: This course is specifically designed for students interested in entering a Ph.D. program in economics or finance after finishing their Master degree (be it at UZH or elsewhere). This is because Ph.D. courses in these two fields require certain knowledge in statistics and probability theory that is not taught at the Bachelor level. On the other hand, students who plan to find a job in industry after finishing their Master degree might not find this course to be overly useful to them.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on Friday, 17.01.2025, 10.15-11 am.
PrecognitionDescription: No prior knowledge is required.
MaterialDescription: Handouts
FurtherInfoDescription:
This lecture is held by an external lecturer, Dr. Enzo Rossi, who is currently working as an Economic Advisor at the Swiss National Bank (SNB). Email address: enzo.rossi@snb.ch.

The lecture will not be recorded.
CommonDescription:
This course addresses a current hot topic in economic and fiscal policymaking that has important implications for asset and risk management. It analyses both practical and theoretical aspects related to public debt management. After a general description of the prevailing global situation, the financing instruments and selling methods used by public debt managers will be discussed.
This will be followed by a derivation of the fundamental equation which constraints fiscal policymakers' and debt managers' actions. Against this backdrop, the two main approaches in public debt management pursued in the literature on the one hand, and in practice on the other, will be examined. The macroeconomic perspective focuses on welfare aspects of debt management decisions. Its main objective is to provide fiscal insurance to the government, the key element being 'risk minimisation'. By contrast, the 'micro portfolio optimisation perspective' focuses on debt servicing costs. Both approaches will be critically analysed. Students who successfully complete the course will gain a strong background on public debt management from a theoretical, empirical and practical perspective, as well as a better understanding of present challenges for public debt managers and bond investors in a world overloaded with debt.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Mandatory exercises (Pass or Fail);
Exam on 16.01.2025, 10:00-12:00.

Final Grade and Exam
Provided that the students have completed and passed the mandatory assignments, the final grade of the course is based on the results of the final examination. Students who have attended all guest speaker lectures will receive extra 5 points (out of 100) in the final exam, provided that they pass the final exam. The exam will be based on the lectures and the textbooks. To pass the course, at least 50% of the total points are required.
ObjectiveDescription:
After the course, students should

  • Understand the challenges created by operating in multiple international markets
  • Know key managerial challenges faced by managers of MNE and the solutions available to address these
  • Understand the differences between domestic and international strategy
MaterialDescription: Please see the syllabus on the Chair's website.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Attendance at all meetings is strongly encouraged.
Students who have attended all guest speaker lectures will receive extra
5 points (out of 100) in the final exam, provided that they pass the final exam.
CommonDescription:
Global Strategic Management addresses the challenges confronting managers and firms competing internationally. The course focuses on multinational enterprises ("MNEs"), which own or control significant resources and operations in several, often disparate countries, cultures, and markets. An MNE's performance depends on internal and external income streams denominated in multiple currencies. MNEs have operations situated in localities with different and often face conflicting public policy priorities, product preferences, and standards of ethical conduct. The context creates strategic challenges that are distinctly different from operating in a single country.
The overall theme of the course is understanding the MNE: how it is structured, how it competes, and how we explain persistent differences in performance between the MNC and its various rivals. The overall aim of the course is to understand how strategies carried out by the MNE in an international context is different from firm strategy in a purely domestic setting.
The course will consist of lectures and case studies.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on Monday 13.1.2025, 10:15-11:45 am (90 minutes).
PrecognitionDescription: You are assumed to be familiar with undergraduate-level microeconomics and statistics/econometrics.
ObjectiveDescription: At the end of the course, students will be familiar with core topics of labor economics.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Please note: You should not take this course, if you are also taking the "Empirical Methods" compulsory course this semester, because lecture AND exam of both courses are at the same time (no exceptions possible).

The lecture will not be recorded/no podcast. Lecture takes place at SOF- G-21 only on December 16 the lecture will take place in room KOL-F-109.
CommonDescription: This course introduces students to theoretical concepts and empirical research in labor economics. It covers topics such as labor supply and demand, the impacts of technology and trade on the labor market, and discrimination and gender differentials in the labor market.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Students will be graded based on homework, class participation, short project paper and presentation.
The exam will take place on Tuesday, 7 January 2025, 14.00 - 15.45 h.
PrerequisitesDescription: Master students
PrecognitionDescription: Linear Algebra and Mathematical Analysis for Economics, some familiarity with statistical software tools such as Matlab, Python, R or other is welcome.
ObjectiveDescription: In this course, students will learn to master the main theoretical notions of financial network models, with a focus on financial contagion and financial risk. Importantly, during the practical exercises with provided data and software- tools, the students will also acquire an operational know-how to analyze empirical financial networks from the perspective of systemic risk and how to carry out simple stress-tests, also related to climate change, on real financial networks.
MaterialDescription: Handout will be distributed after each lecture.
CommonDescription: Sustainable finance is today a strategic area of investment for both private and public institutions. Our society faces unprecedented sustainability challenges both in terms of environment, such as climate change and biodiversity loss, as well as social issues such as mounting inequality and the new risk of pandemics. Financial technologies play a crucial role for the functioning of the modern economy and for the management of both for macro-economic challenges (financial stability, growth, inequality) and for sustainability (climate risk, low-carbon transition, green growth, resilience to pandemics). Depending on financial technologies are used, they can either support the good management of these challenges, or, instead they can exacerbate their mismanagement. The discipline of financial networks is key to make this difference: many important unintended effects and externalities can only be captured by a financial network analysis. Three main effects propagate through networks of financial contracts: the exposure of portfolios to risk (e.g. systemic, climate), the impact of portfolios on social and climate objectives, and the creation and redistribution of wealth. Accordingly, the course will start from the basic notions of graph theory and progress towards developing network models of financial actors with a focus on the context of financial stability and climate- related risks.

TestsDescription:
• Individueller Bericht zu eigener Forschungsidee. Inhalt, Form, Umfang und Abgabedatum werden in der Vorlesung kommuniziert.
  • Durchgehende Anwesenheit wird vorausgesetzt.
  • Benotung: 60% individueller Bericht, 40% Mitarbeit (dazu gehört u.a. eine Gruppenpräsentation).
PrerequisitesDescription:
• Zulassung zum Master Programm.
  • Kenntnisse der Programmiersprache R werden vorausgesetzt.
ObjectiveDescription: Ziel ist es, die wichtigsten psychologischen Theorien, Konstrukte und Methoden des Konsumentenverhaltens kennenzulernen. Nach der Lehrveranstaltung sollen die Studierenden in der Lage sein evidenz-basierte Forschungsfragen und Hypothesen zu formulieren. Zudem sollen die Studierenden die Methoden der Konsumentenverhaltensforschung so einsetzen können, dass eine systematische Verzerrung von Ergebnissen vermieden wird. Die Studierenden sollen Wissen über das Studien-/Experimentdesign für eigene Forschungsideen einsetzen können. Die Studierenden sollen grundlegende statistische Konzepte wie die Moderations- und Mediationsanalyse verstehen und anwenden können.
MaterialDescription: Folien und Literatur werden während des Kurses bekanntgegeben.
FurtherInfoDescription:
• Die Anmeldung für diese Lehrveranstaltung erfolgt über das UZH Modulbuchungstool.
  • Räume und Uhrzeiten werden einige Tage vor Kursbeginn auf der Lehrstuhl Website publiziert (siehe Lehrstuhl für Marketing, Prof. Natter - Education, Courses tiny.uzh.ch/XK).
  • Weitere Informationen werden auf OLAT zur Verfügung gestellt.
  • Kontaktperson für Fragen zur Lehrveranstaltung: Dr. Sabrina Stöckli (sabrina.stoeckli@business.uzh.ch).
CommonDescription:
Die Studierenden erhalten durch das Modul "Consumer Insights" eine Einführung in das wissenschaftliche Arbeiten als Vorbereitung für empirische Masterarbeiten im Bereich Konsumverhalten und Marketing.

Im Rahmen eines Flipped Classroom Kurses erhalten die Studierenden anhand von diversen angewandten Beispielen aus der aktuellen Forschung eine Einführung in den Forschungsprozess. Als Basis dafür erhalten die Studierenden einen Überblick über zentrale Theorien, Forschungsfelder, Methoden, Open Science Standards und Trends. Die Studierenden werden nach diesem Kurs in der Lage sein

(1) konkrete Forschungsfragen und Hypothesen aus bestehender Literatur abzuleiten,
(2) experimentelle Forschungsdesigns zu entwickeln, (3) Fragebogen zu erstellen und
(4) erhobene Daten zu analysieren und diese im Hinblick auf Forschungsfragen/Hypothesen zu interpretieren und diskutieren.

Die Inhalte dieses Kurses werden interaktiv vermittelt und im Rahmen von verschiedenen Übungen angewendet. Schliesslich werden die Studierenden ihre Kenntnisse zum Forschungsprozess anhand einer eigenen Forschungsidee im Rahmen einer Einzelarbeit sowie einer Gruppenpräsentation vertiefen.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The following components comprise the final grade:

  1. Daily coding exercises: every day of the class (20%): on-site assessments (computer-based, BYOD format; bring a charger)
  2. Kaggle competition (10%): on-site assessment (computer-based, BYOD format; bring a charger)
  3. Final exam on 06.09.2024 (50%): on-site, written examination, multiple choice format
  4. Online exercises on DataCamp (to be completed after the course) (20%)

Absence Policy for Daily Coding Exercises:

In the event that a student is unable to participate in a daily coding exercise due to a valid medical reason, the student must promptly submit a doctor's certificate to the instructor (within one week of the missed assessment).

With a valid doctor's certificate, students are thus permitted to miss a maximum of two daily coding exercises. Assessments missed under these circumstances will not be factored into the final grade calculation.
Consequently, only those assessments taken will contribute to the final grade.
If any further daily coding exercises are missed, these will be graded as "1".

Failure to provide the necessary documentation within the stipulated one-week period will result in the missed assessment(s) being graded with a "1" and counting towards the final course grade.

This policy does not apply to the Kaggle Competition and Final Exam. In cases where the final day (i.e., Day 5) of the course must be unavoidably missed, the official regulations and procedures outlined by the Dean's Office apply.
SmText: Machine Learning - A non-technical introduction with applications to Marketing (L)
PrecognitionDescription: Recommended: Marketing Analytics, R - a non-technical introduction with applications to Marketing
ObjectiveDescription:
• Get familiar with the concept of machine learning.
  • Understand the basic theory behind various machine learning techniques.
  • Apply different machine learning techniques and interpret the results.
MaterialDescription: Hastie, T., Tibshirani R., Friedman, J. (2013): The Elements of Statistical Learning - Data Mining, Inference, and Prediction, 2nd edition, Springer.
FurtherInfoDescription: Please visit our website at tinyurl.com/Edu-Master-Classes for current information and details about the course.
CommonDescription:
Machine Learning has become one of the core pillars of information technology. Since the amount of available data is steadily increasing, smart data analysis will become more and more important in the future.
This course introduces Machine Learning in a non-technical, hands-on way with integrated exercises.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on Monday 13.1.2025, 60 minutes, 4.15-5.15 pm.

To be admitted to the written final exam the weekly indicator review task has to be passed (see end of course description for details).
PrecognitionDescription: You should know basic microeconomics (profit and utility maximisation) and econometrics (OLS regression). It also helps if you have already encountered the Ramsey model, monopolistic competition, and structural vector autoregressions (SVAR).
FurtherInfoDescription:
This lecture is held by an external lecturer: Dr. Yannic Stucki, who is an economist in the Forecast and Analysis Switzerland unit at the SNB. Contact: yannic.stucki@snb.ch.

The lecture will be recorded/podcast.
CommonDescription:
This lecture aims at providing first answers to questions around the following topics:

Empirics: what are the empirical properties of the business cycle? How do applied economists monitor the business cycle in real time? Where do Switzerland and the world's most important economies currently stand in their cycles? What are the main shocks causing the business cycle and how can we identify these shocks?

Modern business cycle theory: what are the most important elements of the modern workhorse model? What can the model be used for? What are its shortcomings? In which directions does current research go? Normative questions: Why do people care about the business cycle? How costly are economic fluctuations and inflation? Should governments attempt to stabilize the cycle?

We will start each lecture with a short student presentation (5-10 minutes) on an important economic indicator that has been published during the past week.
The goal is to get to know the most prominent economic indicators and to develop a feeling for the current state of the business cycle in Switzerland and the most important other economies. For each indicator there is a limited number of slots available that are allocated on a first come, first served basis. Each student must enrol for one indicator, submit her/his chartbook in time, be present at the day they chose, and hold the presentation in case that they are selected. To be admitted to the written final exam the weekly indicator review task has to be passed.
AudienceDescription: This class is aimed at Master students.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: In order to get credit for the course, students have to participate in the seminar meetings (10% of the final grade), present their findings on the chosen topic to the class (30% of the final grade) and write and submit a seminar paper (60% of the final grade).
ObjectiveDescription:
The objective of this course is to familiarize students with the challenges and opportunities of responsible leadership. Students will thereby

  • Learn to understand the current debates on the responsibility and ethicality of leadership in the global business environment
  • Reflect about responsible leadership in general and their own leadership values in particular
  • Understand and learn ways to engage with the challenges of leadership
  • Train their analytical, reflective, holistic, and creative thinking
FurtherInfoDescription:
The seminar is limited to a maximum of 18 students. To apply, please send your CV, an overview of attended courses and a short motivation for your participation (max 1 page) until September 4, by email to Stefan Schembera (stefan.schembera@ru.nl).

The seminar will take place onsite on the following dates:

Block 1:
- Wednesday, 18 September 2024, 10:15-18:00

Block 2:

  • Wednesday, 30 October 2024, 09:00-18:00
  • Thursday, 31 October 2024, 08:00-12:00

Block 3:

  • Wednesday, 27 November 2024, 09:00-18:00
  • Thursday, 28 November 2024, 08:00-12:00 

Further information will be placed on our homepage: www.business.uzh.ch/professorships/as/teaching/overview.html
CommonDescription: A globalized business world poses numerous challenges for business leaders, decision makers, managers, and employees. In particular, leading in a responsible and sustainable manner has become one of the major challenges managers need to deal with. Triggered by recent developments including high-scale business scandals and an ever increasing societal pressure for companies to operate responsibly and sustainably, those working in organizations frequently feel the need for guidance when it comes to simple questions like "What does responsibility mean?", "Why be responsible?" or "How can I be responsible?", etc. At the same time, being able to deal with these challenges, pressures, and questions offers a wide range of opportunities for business leaders to develop sound strategies, create long-term value and sustainability, and to have a positive impact which makes a difference. The objective of this course is to familiarize students with the challenges and opportunities of responsible leadership.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Students must write an essay and present their work in an onsite block event towards the end of the semester. The homework assignment must be completed in groups of two students and is structured as follows:

  • Students will be asked to select a research topic/question from a list that will be made available to students in the first lecture. The topics/questions are based on the content covered in the lectures. The assignment of the topic/question should be agreed with the lecturers in the first weeks of the semester.
  • The essay should consist of around 3,000 words, a bibliography and few well-chosen graphs and tables. In the block event, students will be asked to give a 20-minutes presentation based on their essay. All deadlines will be announced in the lecture.

Grading:
The essay will account for 60% of the grade, the essay presentation for
30% and the remaining 10% will be for class participation. The grading of the homework assignment will be identical for the two students, while the grading of the presentation of the homework assignment and the participation in the seminar will be individual.
PrecognitionDescription: This seminar is for Master students.
ObjectiveDescription: The seminar seeks to deepen students' understanding of the link between monetary policy implementation and the impact on financial markets.
MaterialDescription:
Bindseil, U. (2014). Monetary Policy Operations and the Financial System. Oxford University Press.
Nyborg K. G. (2017). Collateral Frameworks: The Open Secret of Central Banks.Cambridge University Press.
Additional reading material will be announced in the lecture.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This module takes place on-site.
Master students, maximum 20 participants. Students must apply for the course by email (incl. brief motivation letter, latest academic record & CV) and will be selected by the lecturers. Pls submit your application until Aug. 31, 2024 to secretariat.nyborg@df.uzh.ch.
CommonDescription:
Overview. The objective of the seminar "Monetary Policy and Financial Markets" is to give students theoretical and practical insights into monetary policy implementation and the impact on financial markets. The seminar is split into (i) a lectures part and (ii) a homework assignment and presentation part. The lectures focuses on the following topics:

  • First, we review the mandates of central banks and discuss standard tools to implement monetary policy. This includes a description of different approaches to steer short-term interest rates, central banks' access policies, and
    a discussion of open market operations as well as standing facilities.
    Moreover, the role and the importance of collateral frameworks are discussed.
  • Second, we discuss the role of interbank and wholesale money markets.
    This includes a description of different money markets, the relevant participants, and different money market trading arrangements, pre- and post-crisis. In this part of the seminar, we also discuss the importance of robust money market benchmark interest rates.
  • Third, we will focus on the measures taken by different central banks in response to the financial crisis and as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
    In particular, we discuss the objective, operational set-up, success and potential side effects of unconventional monetary policy operations including quantitative easing, fixed rate full-allotment policies and negative interest rates.
  • Fourth, we discuss the implications of central bank digital currencies (CBDC) and stablecoins for monetary policy implementation and financial markets.
AudienceDescription: Master students with an interest in monetary policy and financial markets.
AppointmentsDescription: Weekly lectures at the beginning of the semester followed by a block event towards the end of the semester.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place on-site.
Seminar paper in groups, (20 pages, 80%), with final presentation (20%) (Wednesday, 11.12.2024, 09:00-12:00 Uhr).
SmText: FinTech & InsurTech – Digitization of the Financial Services Industry (L+E) (Digitalisierung der Finanzindustrie)
PrerequisitesDescription: Passed Bachelor-Level, Branch of Study: Bachelor of Arts UZH in Business and Economics or Informatics
ObjectiveDescription: Introduction to the theory and practice of Fin-Tech and InsurTech as well as acquiring skills to develop your own Fin-Tech and InsurTech concepts.
MaterialDescription: Textbook and other literature
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place on site.
CommonDescription:
The lecture "FinTech - Digitalization of the Financial Industry" is intended to give an introduction to the topic and consist of two parts: (1) Theory:
This part contains a mixture of scientific content and practical contributions.

(2) Lab:
This part includes the development of a concept for a FinTech solution of your choice (e.g. mock-up / prototype).
The theoretical part takes place as a 1.5 day block seminar, the lab part is part of a half-day block course. The students have the opportunity to present their developed
concepts to a jury of specialists consisting of start-up entrepreneurs, venture capitalists and digitization experts from financial service providers and to receive feedback.
AudienceDescription: Students in the Master of Arts in Economics and the Master of Science in Business and Economics or Informatics

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Project during lecture 50% (documentation of the solution: 20%, presentation of the solution: 20%, analytics solution: 60%) and a final exam 50% (open book).
The examination of the module is carried out onsite.

Written Exam on Wednesday, 18 December 2024, 12:00-14:00, 90 minutes.
SmText: Applied Financial Analytics for Strategic Decisions and Value Creation (L)
PrerequisitesDescription: Bachelor
PrecognitionDescription: No specific prerequisites are required. Basics for statistics, finance, business administration, applied mathematics, data science or information technologies will be beneficial.
ObjectiveDescription: The goal of this course is to provide the understanding of the connection between data science concepts or analytics technologies and the level of corporate intelligence and digital enablement required to insight driven strategic steering large-scale international corporate groups. This course will also encourage students to develop the necessary technical skills and have the first-hand experience in building up an application in the context of a team assignment.
MaterialDescription: Lecture notes will be available.
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place on-site, with online recording.
CommonDescription:
Finance Analytics is about unlocking the power of data science and analytics to create granular, connected and dynamic intelligence for executive teams to steer financial performance, deliver successful corporate deals and create value​.
The applications of data science and advanced analytics technology empower C-suite, executive and management to:

  • have collective transparency on (financial) numbers​,
  • understand root-causes and key drivers of major financial performance shifts,​
  • simulate impact of alternative decisions and future scenarios​,
  • closely track progress and value realization of strategic initiatives.

The lecture introduces to the main building blocks of Finance Analytics, including leading technologies and key concepts of financial performance modelling. Several real-life corporate use cases are also presented.
Finally, a project assignment (in teams of 4-5 people) allows students to put theory into practice under the supervision of a senior "project buddy" from the industry.
AudienceDescription: Master students in Business and Economics, Informatics and Master Students in Quantitative Finance

TestsDescription:
Die Bewertung erfolgt im Rahmen einer Gruppenpräsentation je Arbeitsgruppe.
Bewertet werden hierbei:

  • Ausarbeitung der Präsentation
  • Mündliche Präsentation

Gewürdigt werden die Beiträge der einzelnen Gruppenteilnehmer*innen sowie die Ausarbeitung der Gesamtpräsentation.
ObjectiveDescription:
Nach Abschluss der Veranstaltung sind die Studierenden in der Lage,

  • die OECD-Transfer-Pricing-Richtlinien zu verstehen und deren Relevanz für die lokale Gesetzgebung zu erkennen;
  • die Relevanz der Funktionsanalyse im Transfer Pricing einzuschätzen;
  • die Beurteilung eines Sachverhalts sowie das Durchführen von Interviews für die Funktionsanalyse zu verstehen;
  • die Wichtigkeit einer Verrechnungspreisdokumentation zu erkennen;
  • sich über die neusten Entwicklungen im Transfer-Pricing-Bereich zu orientieren.
MaterialDescription: Die Kursunterlagen (inkl. Fallstudie) sind auf Englisch verfasst. Die Präsentationen und Arbeitsgruppen-Meetings werden auf Deutsch (ggf. im Ausnahmefall auch auf Englisch) gehalten.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Die Teilnehmerzahl ist auf 16 Personen beschränkt. Zweitanmeldung direkt am Lehrstuhl erforderlich.
Hinweise zum Anmeldeverfahren siehe OLAT: https://t.uzh.ch/1Cz Nach Zuteilung eines Seminarplatzes müssen Sie diesen innerhalb einer gegebenen Frist bestätigen. Durch die Bestätigung wird die Anmeldung verbindlich und Sie verpflichten sich zur Teilnahme am Seminar.
CommonDescription:
Die Transfer Pricing «Masterclass» basiert auf einer praxisnah definierten Fallstudie. Die Kursteilnehmenden versetzen sich in die Rolle des/der Leiters/Leiterin Abteilung Steuern, die sie neu übernommen haben.
Die Fallstudie illustriert den OECD-Ansatz zur Behandlung von Transferpreisen und ist demzufolge in den meisten Ländern mit entsprechenden Verrechnungspreisvorschriften direkt umsetzbar. Jede Arbeitsgruppe wird von einem erfahrenen Transfer-Pricing-Spezialisten von PwC betreut und geleitet.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
1.    Presentation (50%) 
2.    Written thesis (40%)
3.    Performance in revenue management game (10%) on Monday morning, 09.09.2024, and Saturday afternoon, 02.11.2024

If you are officially excused on the day of your presentation, you will present on another day of the seminar. If this is infeasible, a video of the presentation must be submitted within two weeks. If you are excused for both rounds of the game, please contact Henrik Imhof (henrik.imhof@uzh.ch) to arrange an alternative time for the game. In this case, the game will be remote.
SmText: An Introduction to Revenue Management and Pricing (S)
PrecognitionDescription: Content of Mathematik I and II, basics of linear programming.
ObjectiveDescription: Students will be able to demonstrate an understanding of the basic concept of revenue management and pricing. They will also enhance their general knowledge about the topics of demand modeling, forecasting and mathematical optimization.
MaterialDescription: Course materials will be published on Moodle / OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription: The seminar is limited to a maximum of 18 students. To apply, please send a short letter of motivation and a current Leistungsausweis to Christiane.Barz@uzh.ch by July 31st. Later applications might be considered if there are empty slots available.
CommonDescription: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to revenue management and pricing including demand models, forecasting, and algorithms. The first set of classes will be lectures providing a general introduction and an overview of the topics that can be worked on. Potential topics include but are not limited to customer choice models, extensions of optimization models, approximate dynamic programming and Q-learning. In our final meeting, we will consider revenue management with competition and play an interactive revenue management game.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The seminar is composed of mandatory weekly meetings, in which we will discuss different theories and the evidence supporting them. Part of the meetings will be devoted to student presentations of their homework assignments, which are designed to help the students learn how to construct testable hypotheses from theories and/or real world inputs and provide them with the tools to find the appropriate data in order to empirically test their hypotheses. In addition to homework presentations throughout the semester, students will be presenting their final work in the last weeks of the semester (see the "Termine" section for details) and are expected to submit a seminar paper summarizing that work.

The module grade will be determined based on the student's seminar paper and its presentation (50% of the grade), homework (40% of the grade), and class participation (10% of the grade). To pass the class a student needs to have a passing grade in each of these components.
PrerequisitesDescription: Successful completion of a bachelor's degree.
PrecognitionDescription: Microeconomics and econometrics
ObjectiveDescription:
Students will acquire knowledge about the economic models of investments in skills and the empirical evidence regarding the relationship between different skills and labor market outcomes.

Through their work on the homework assignments and seminar paper, students will learn how to construct hypotheses based on theories learned in class or on a combination of such theories and inputs from the "real world" (such as newspaper articles or their own experiences as workers and students). They will understand what data is relevant to test such hypotheses (both ideally and in practice) and know where to look for such data, how to use such data to determine whether it supports the hypotheses and what conclusion (and limitation) can be drawn based on the relationships found in the data.
MaterialDescription: Papers will be distributed electronically.
LanguageDescription: The course is taught in English. All the assignments, presentations, as well as the seminar paper must be written in English.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Please note, the number of students that can participate in this seminar is limited. To determine who is allowed to participate, each interested student will be asked to prepare a short assignment. Students who are interested in taking the seminar should e-mail Professor Segal (carmit.segal@business.uzh.ch) before September 16,
2024.
CommonDescription: This seminar examines (theoretically and empirically) the processes of skill (or human capital) formation throughout an individual's life. The theory of human capital applies generalized cost-benefit analysis to the investment in skills. In light of this theory, we will discuss in detail who would be willing to invest in socially productive skills, and under what conditions. Our discussion will not be limited to investments in cognitive skills (via investment in education, for example) but also will include investments in non-cognitive (or "soft") skills. We will examine the evidence about the relative importance of these skills to labor market outcomes and the optimal timing of investments.
AppointmentsDescription: The tentative dates and times for seminar paper presentations are: December 12, 2024 (between 10:00 and 16:00) and December 13, 2024 (between 10:00 and 16:00). Please note that some of these dates/times do not coincide with the seminar's usual hours and/or days, they have been assigned to accommodate up to 20 students. In case they are unnecessary, some of these dates/hours will be canceled. Participation in classmates' presentations is mandatory. However, conflicting classes' schedules will be taken into consideration. The exact times and dates of each individual presentation will be determined during the course of the seminar.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: There is no final exam during the usual final-exams-week. Instead, there are two written exams that take place during lecture time, and two take-home assignments involving computer programming and report writing. For the take-home exams, students may work in teams of two, or possibly (decided in class) three people.
SmText: Statistical Foundations for Finance (Mathematical and Computational Statistics with a View Towards Finance and Risk Management)
PrerequisitesDescription:
Probability theory at the level of "Fundamental Probability: A Computational Approach", by Paolella, John Wiley & Sons, 2006.
While it cannot be imposed, students outside of the quant Finance master program should have taken the course from the same professor entitled Fundamental Probability.
PrecognitionDescription: very solid knowledge of calculus, linear/matrix algebra, and fundamental probability and distribution theory is required.
ObjectiveDescription: On successful completion of this module, students should be able to: Be fluent with the major aspects of the aforementioned (large) list of topics, and have confidence and competence in (i) being able to implement the methods computationally, and (ii) be able to read, understand, and implement theory and methods from the academic literature in quantitative finance, financial econometrics, and quantitative risk management.
MaterialDescription: Required textbooks are "Fundamental Statistical Inference: A Computational Approach", and "Intermediate Probability Theory", Marc Paolella, John Wiley and Sons.
CommonDescription:
We begin with some relevant material from probability and distribution theory, notably moment generating (MGF) and characteristic functions (CF), the standard inversion theorems, convolutions and other functions of two random variables.
We will optionally cover the use of saddlepoint approximations for inverting the MGF, and the use of the FFT for inverting the CF. We will cover financial risk measures, notably Value-at-Risk and Expected Shortfall. The rest of the course is dedicated to statistical inference in the so-called IID setting, with emphasis on distribution theory, use of inversion theorems, simulation, optimization, and other computational methods. Topics include the bootstrap for confidence intervals, goodness-of-fit measures from the empirical CDF, distributional hypothesis testing, parameter hypothesis testing and the (mis-)use of p-values, theory of maximum likelihood estimation, various alternative estimators, shrinkage estimation, discrete mixture distributions, the EM-algorithm, and tail estimation. We will also cover stochastic convergence concepts and the major limit theorems.
AudienceDescription: The course has been designed and optimized for the students in the Masters of Quantitative Finance program, but is open and encouraged to well-prepared masters students in the regular Banking and Finance program, as well as Data Science and Economics.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: To pass the module, students must pass the final written exam. The examination of the module will take place onsite on Wednesday, 15.01.2025, 16:00- 18:00.
PrerequisitesDescription:
The content of the following lectures are mandatory prerequisites: 1.
Informatics I, 2. Informatics II, 3. Foundations of Computing I
PrecognitionDescription: Knowledge of algorithms is required. Knowledge of basic probability theory is helpful. Students need to be proficient in math to solve the theoretical homework exercises.
ObjectiveDescription: The goal is to learn about the most important algorithmic design principles and techniques for their analysis related to randomness in computation.
MaterialDescription: Lecture notes will be supplied. Further reading will be indicated.
FurtherInfoDescription: This course replaces "Randomized and Online Algorithms" (BMINF014), which will be discontinued from HS22. Students which have already successfully passed "Randomized and Online Algorithms" (BMINF014), are not allowed to book this course.
CommonDescription:
This lecture covers several aspects of randomness in computation. Firstly, we establish basic probablistic tools, such as linearity of expectation and bounds on probabilities. Building on these we cover the design and analysis of randomized algorithms. Such an algorithm is allowed to use "coin flips" in its decision making. Some randomized algorithms yield significantly better runtimes and/or solution qualities as their deterministic counterparts. We also treat stochastic processes, e.g. Markov chains in the lecture, and give classical applications like 3-SAT. More advanced topics like random graphs, the probabilistic method, and randomized rounding are also covered.

Mathematically sound analysis is an important and integral part of this lecture. That is, we will not only state the properties of an algorithm, e.g.
its correctness or running time, but also prove them mathematically.

In particular, we plan to treat the following topics:

  1. Introduction
  2. Linearity of Expectation: Concept, Balls-Into-Bins, Coupon Collector, Quicksort
  3. Bounds on Probabilities: Markov, Chebyshev, Chernoff, Balls-Into-Bins, Coupon Collector, Quicksort
  4. Markov Chains: Concept, Hitting Times and Probabilities, Random Walks, Invariant Distributions, 3-SAT
  5. Randomized Rounding: Concept, SET COVER, MAX SAT, Derandomization
  6. Probabilistic Method: First- and Second Moment Method, MAX SAT, Random Graphs
AudienceDescription: Recommended for all MSc students with an interest in topics at the intersection of computer science and mathematics.

TestsDescription: Anwesenheit und Mitarbeit im zweitägigen Workshop; Vorbereitung, Durchführung und Nachbereitung von Übungssitzungen und -dokumenten; Korrektur von praktischen Aufgaben
SmText: Coaching für wissenschaftliches Arbeiten (S) (Coaching for scientific working)
PrerequisitesDescription: Zulassung zum Masterstudium
ObjectiveDescription:
• Erlernen berufsrelevanter Kompetenzen wie Führung im Team, Personalentwicklung im Team und weiterer Sozialkompetenzen
  • Anwenden und Vermitteln der Grundlagen wissenschaftlichen Arbeitens
  • Studierende lernen insbesondere...

...zu wissenschaftlich korrektem Arbeiten anzuleiten

...Übungen zu bewerten sowie allgemeine Schwierigkeiten und Probleme zu identifizieren

...Gruppensitzungen und Übungen vorzubereiten

...Gruppensitzungen gruppenspezifisch zu gestalten

- Organisation und Management multipler Gruppen
FurtherInfoDescription:
Die Teilnehmerzahl ist beschränkt. Bewerbungen für einen Seminarplatz sind bis zum 30.04.2024 per mail an Deborah Kistler (deborah.kistler@econ.uzh.ch) zu senden.

Inhalt der Bewerbung:

  • Lebenslauf inklusive Personalien (Name, Vorname, Adresse, E-Mail (uzh),
    Matrikelnummer, Olat-Benutzername, Anzahl Semester und Studienrichtung)
  • Studienvoraussetzungen (aktueller Leistungsausweis)
  • Begleitschreiben (Motivation für die Teilnahme, maximal eine halbe Seite)

Das Auswahlverfahren findet im Mai 2024 statt.

Für Fragen wenden Sie sich bitte an Deborah Kistler (deborah.kistler@econ.uzh.ch)
CommonDescription: In einem zweitägigen Workshop (in der Woche vor Semesterstart) erwerben Sie die Fähigkeiten, die Grundlagen des wissenschaftlichen Arbeitens zu vermitteln und lernen, worauf es beim Coaching und der Organisation von Gruppen ankommt. Sie übernehmen anschliessend zwei Tutorate pro Woche der Bachelorvorlesung "Einführung in das wissenschaftliche Arbeiten" (welche neu konzeptioniert wird). Dabei führen sie die Bachelorstudierenden in die verschiedenen Themen des wissenschaftlichen Ar-beitens, wie zum Beispiel quantitative und qualitative Forschungsmethoden, Nutzung und Umgang mit KI sowie wissenschaftsethische und -philosophische Fragestellungen ein. Zudem können Sie damit die im Rahmen des Workshops erarbeiteten Kenntnisse direkt praktisch anwenden. Neben der Leitung der Übungsgruppen beinhaltet der Erwerb der 6 ECTS-Punkte die Betreuung von E-Learning-Aktivitäten, die Korrektur praktischer Übungsaufgaben, die Beantwortung von Fragen der Studierenden sowie die Unterstützung der Dozierenden bei organisatorischen Aspekten des Managements mehrerer Gruppen.
AudienceDescription:
Sie haben:

  • ein Flair für die Anleitung von Gruppen von Studierenden im Rahmen von Übungen
  • Interesse am wissenschaftlichen Arbeiten
  • Interesse an und gute Grundkenntnisse von quantitativen Forschungsmethoden
  • Interesse an wissenschaftsphilosophischen und -ethischen Fragenstellungen
  • eine selbstverantwortliche, zuverlässige und motivierende Persönlichkeit und können sich vorstellen, Ihr Wissen und Ihre eigenen Erfahrungen aus dem Studium an die neuen Studierenden weiterzugeben
  • Freude daran, Teil eines jungen und dynamischen Teams zu sein und Bereitschaft zur Selbstreflexion
AppointmentsDescription:
Zweitägiger Workshop zur wissenschaftlichen und praktischen Vorbereitung auf die Führung von Übungsgruppen (für alle): Dienstag
10.09.2024 (09:00-16:00) Mittwoch 11.09.2024 (09:00-16:00) 

Folgende Zeitfenster stehen für die Korrektur der praktischen Aufgaben (PA) zur Verfügung (für alle):

  • Korrektur PA 1 28.09.2024 - 30.09.2024 
  • Korrektur PA 2 12.10.2024 - 14.10.2024
  • Korrektur PA 3 26.10.2024 - 28.10.2024
  • Korrektur PA 4 16.11.2024 - 18.11.2024

Vier Termine zum Erfahrungsaustausch, d.h. Reflexion der Führungserfahrung und Herausforderungen wissenschaftlichen Arbeitens (für alle):

  • Montag 30.09.2024 (16:15-18:00)
  • Montag 07.10.2024 (16:15-18:00)
  • Montag 28.10.2024 (16:15-18:00)
  • Montag 18.11.2024 (16:15-18:00)

Abgabe Dokumentation: 30.11.2024

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
written exam (50%) and oral presentation (50%). However, an exam below passing grade (4.0) cannot be compensated with the mark on the presentation and leads to a fail mark for the entire course.

Written final examination 60 min (11.00-12.00 am) on 8.11.2024.

The examination of the module and the presentations will take place onsite.
PrerequisitesDescription: Participants must have successfully passed the lecture "International Macroeconomics" held by Prof. Hoffmann.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Upon agreement with the instructor, there is a possibility for students to develop their paper presentation into an independent study project (worth 3 credit points) by writing a separate paper developing some independent empirical results.

The seminar is limited to 15 participants.

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.econ.uzh.ch/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the regular module booking period for lectures.

The seminar takes place at ZUH-F-02 (Zürichbergstrasse 14).
CommonDescription:
This seminar course offers an introduction to modern international macro-finance for advanced Master students.

The course has two parts. The first part (1st quarter, weeks 1-7) is a lecture-based introduction to the field and is completed by a written exam (week 8). In the second part (weeks 10-14), students present current papers from the literature in class.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Regular per-person exercises and individual homework assignments (50%), programming project in the group including iterative presentation and report submission (50%). Students must pass both the individual grade and the overall grade for successful completion of the course.
PrerequisitesDescription: Willingness to participate actively in class is recommended. Willingness to work in groups to face data analysis challenges together.
PrecognitionDescription: Programming expertise is mandatory. Student groups should be comfortable with front end and backend development. Basic knowledge in data science, machine learning, and data analysis are useful but not mandatory.
ObjectiveDescription:
Students will learn characteristics of data and data (pre-) processing/analysis methods. Further, students will learn skills about how data can be represented visually, and which types of interaction techniques are meaningful to enable users to get in a dialog with their data. For both data visualization and the interaction with data, students will learn a and apply a design methodology.
Students will also learn how interactive visualization techniques can be combined with algorithmic data analysis and machine learning support, to create powerful visual analytics and interactive machine learning solutions. Along these lines, students will learn principal unsupervised, semi-supervised, and supervised machine learning techniques and gain a practical understanding of how these techniques can be
leveraged for interactive visual data analysis. Finally, students will gain an understanding of personalized data analysis, human-centered machine learning, explainable artificial intelligence, and human-centered artificial intelligence.
MaterialDescription:
see module website
www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/ivda/teaching.html
FurtherInfoDescription:
see module website
www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/ivda/teaching.html

If you have already taken the course "Introduction to Interactive-Visual Data Analysis (MINF4570)" in fall 2021 you are not allowed to book this course.
CommonDescription:
Gaining knowledge from data is key in the age of data-driven research and decision-making. The same applies for the use of machine learning methods to support the knowledge generation process. But how can different user groups of different skills, application backgrounds, and expertise be supported to interact with their data?

This course introduces concepts and techniques for the design and development of interactive-visual data analysis systems. The main focus is on the combination of interactive visual interfaces with automatic data analysis methods, to enable users to engage with their data and to enhanced data analysis. Associated research fields are Information Visualization, Visual Analytics, Interactive Machine Learning, Explainable Artificial Intelligence, and Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence.
AudienceDescription:
This module is designed for MA students (POC, DS, AI).
This module is also suitable for students with a programming background, and with an interest in interactive data analysis solutions.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
• Report: 60% of the Final grade
  • Final Presentation: 40 % of the Final Grade
PrecognitionDescription: General familiarity with computer networks and distributed systems basic principles, and high-level familiarity with Internet as of Web 2.0 would be a plus, but none are strictly required.
ObjectiveDescription: At the end of this seminar, students will gain knowledge in most popular blockchain platforms including, but not limited to, Bitcoin, Ethereum and Polkadot. Students will research on the technical and economic aspects of blockchains via multiple resources such as official documentation of the blockchain protocols.
MaterialDescription: Online documentation
FurtherInfoDescription:
Students will be offered a set of topics from which they can pick one in groups of 1 - 2 and will present the topic.
The presentation will need a preparation done by students and under the supervision of their supervisor.
This seminar requires a short report as well, which is a documentation of the studied (and presented) topic be produced by the students of each group.

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give pref-erence to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guar-antee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription: The goal of this Seminar is to give students first-hand overview of the most popular blockchain protocols, including - but not limited to - Bitcoin, Ethereum, Cardano, Algorand, Casper, Tezos, Cosmos, and Polkadot. This seminar sheds light on selected advances of Blockchain platforms in terms of their structure, performance, security, and use cases, while the challenges and deficits will be critically and objectively analyzed, too.
AudienceDescription: Bachelor students in Information Systems, Software Engineering, Data Science

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Assignments: 40% of final grade

Final Exam: 60% of final grade

Written final exam will take place onsite on 17 December 2024, 12 -
14h.
PrerequisitesDescription: Recommended: Distributed Systems
PrecognitionDescription: Programming skills in any of the popular general purpose programming languages (C++, Java, Python). Optional experience in Web technologies (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) for building Web applications.
ObjectiveDescription: At the end of the lecture students will gain practical knowledge in programming new decentralised applications on the most popular blockchain protocols, including, but not limited to, Bitcoin, Ethereum and Polkadot. They will learn how to setup their own blockchain forks for research and development. They will learn how to research technical information (white papers) and read official documentation of the blockchain protocols, as well as (if needed) their source code to solve technical challenges while developing their decentralized applications.
MaterialDescription: Online documentation / Course Material
CommonDescription:
This course aims to give students a fundamental overview of a set of Blockchains and Crypto Economic concepts and incentives.
Much is spoken about the trading markets around cryptocurrencies and other tokenized assets. However, little is discussed about different economic and social aspects that enable the functioning of blockchain- based systems. Thus, this course overviews the incentive schemes embedded at different levels that ultimately determine the long-term functioning of these systems and digs into real-world use-cases of this technology, critically analyzing the suitability of their implementation within each context.

This course is designed as a combination of theoretical and practical sessions to provide first-hand experience in employing decentralized applications on the most popular blockchain protocols, including - but not limited to - Bitcoin, Ethereum, Cardano, IOTA, and Polkadot.

During the hands-on practical sessions, students will be given theoretical and technical guidance and technical infrastructure such as forks of before-mentioned blockchains to work on a set of practical exercises as mini-projects on their own deploying or developing decentralized applications on platforms akin to the original ones.
Examples of these platforms include implementing Decentralised Finance (DeFi) protocols (like Uniswap, SushiSwap, or Aave), using Smart Contract functionalities on Ethereum or other blockchains, deployment of second-layer solutions, forking and development of own blockchains, and deployment of monitoring tools. Based on the theoretical and technical concepts covered in sufficient detail, students will be able to start working on their own projects. Prior programming knowledge and experience are required, not necessarily in blockchain technologies.
During their project work, students are expected to develop and deploy their selected applications in two different protocols, followed by critically assessing all relevant technical aspects of their developed application within a comparative fashion. Students will assess the usability of decentralized applications compared to centralized solutions and provide an in-depth comparison of the technical and efficiency differences of employed blockchains.
AudienceDescription: MSc Students in Information Systems, Software Engineering, Data Science

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The seminar presentations include two talks, followed by a discussion of your presentation and the topic. Attendance and active participation in seminar presentations and discussions of other students is mandatory.

You will need to hand in all your presentation materials, such as slides, notes, figures etc.

Close attention must be paid to the structure of the presentation, which should in general include a short introduction and motivation of the topic, a precise statement of the problem, a detailed analysis of the method, a summary of the results and a personal conclusion.

It is strongly recommended that you rehearse your presentation beforehand.

Grading will be based on the presentation (66%) as well as on the discussion (33%) of papers.
SmText: Seminar: Best Practices and Guidelines for Visualization (BSc)
MaterialDescription:
A good starting point for understanding best practices and guidelines are:

  • Diehl, A., Firat, E. E., Torsney-Weir, T., Abdul-Rahman, A., Bach, B., Laramee, R. S., ... & Chen, M. (2021). VisGuided: A Community-dri Approach for Education in Visualization. In Eurographics 2021 (EG 2021).
  • Diehl, A., Kraus, M., Abdul-Raman, A., El-Assady, M., Bach, B., Laramee, R.
    S., ... & Chen, M. (2020). Studying Visualization Guidelines Acco to Grounded Theory. arXiv preprint arXiv:2010.09040.
  • Diehl, A., Abdul-Rahman, A., El-Assady, M., Bach, B., Keim, D. A., & Chen, M.
    (2018, June). VisGuides: A Forum for Discussing Visualization Guidelines. In EuroVis (Short Papers) (pp. 61-65).
  • McNabb, L., & Laramee, R. S. (2017, June). Survey of surveys (S Mapping the landscape of survey papers in information visualization. In Computer Graphics Forum (Vol. 36, No. 3, pp. 589-617).

A set of survey papers will be selected from IEEE Visualiza- tion/InfoVis/VASR, IEEE Pacific Visualization, EUROGRAPHICS, EuroVis, EuroVA, ACM SIGGRAPH, ACM SIGGRAPH Visualiza-tion Symposium, along with the associated journals (ACM Transac-tions of Graphics, IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Comput-er Graphics, and Computer Graphics Forum).
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool :studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription:
• The main focus of this seminar is to review best practices and guidelines in the field of data visualization and apply them by sketching and discussing these best practices collaboratively.
  • We will review key preselected guidelines and best practices, provided by surveys and state-of-the-art reports, about their generality, applicability, and usefulness in particular scenarios. For this purpose, a list of papers will be provided.
    Each participant will choose two papers and prepare a summary presentation.
    Each participant will also participate as a discussant for other presentations and provide arguments or counter-arguments to support or contest the presented guidelines.
    Finally, the presenters and the discussants will work on a joint Q&A document that summarizes the main discussed points and the provided answers.
  • Successful completion of the seminar requires the following:
  • Select and study two papers from the provided list of papers. Each student will thus have to present two reading papers in detail in class.
    Students also have to select papers from others on which they have to act as discussion moderators and debate opponents.
  • After their presentation, each student will have to moderate the question & answer part of two such discussion papers. As a modera the presented paper must also be read and three key questions must be prepared to ask after the presentation. These questions can be, e.g.

challenge the method, scrutinize the technique, or identify the limitations in the results, and must be argued for (see deliverable).
Students will thus be scheduled in pairs of presenter and moderator throughout the semester.

Deliverables:

  • Two presentations (PowerPoint, Keynote, or PDF) for the reading and lists of questions and argumentation for the moderated discussion papers.
  • Summary Q&A documents.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The assessment consists of three parts:

  • Programming project (40%)
  • Tutorial presentation (30%)
  • Exercises (30%)
PrerequisitesDescription: Absolutely necessary are a solid understanding of assessment-level programming concepts (functions, calls, variables, classes, interpreter/compiler etc.) and an ability to program well in at least one programming language. Also, the willingness to seriously learn another programming language is required.
ObjectiveDescription: At the end of this course, students should be able to recognize and explain different programming paradigms and know their concepts and features, motivation, advantages and disadvantages. They will also have attained basic skills in multiple additional programming languages.
MaterialDescription: There will be an overview lecture with slides. Other than that, language-specific online resources will be the primary source of information
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription:
Programming languages can be classified into one or more paradigms. Going beyond the most popular and frequently encountered ones, such as object-orientation, students will learn about the reasoning and constituents of a variety of programming paradigms, including but not limited to: functional, logic, event-driven, reactive, concurrent, imperative vs. declarative, and side-effect-free programming as well as lambda calculus, message passing, pipelines and assembly. The course will begin with a few lectures giving a broad overview of programming paradigms. During the semester, each student will learn to solve problems in multiple programming languages. Students will need to create and solve programming exercises, give a presentation and implement a small software project.

Attending all sessions physically is mandatory.
AudienceDescription: Bachelor's students who wish to enrich their knowledge in programming para and learn an additional programming language.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
All assessments are carried out on-site. Please bring your laptop computer with charger. The following components comprise the final grade:

  1. Final written exam on the last day of the course (13.09.2024) (70%)
  2. Practice exercises during class (10%)
  3. Online exercises to be completed after the course (20%)
PrecognitionDescription: Basic knowledge in R is a prerequisite for the Marketing Analytics class. The required skills are on par with our class "R - A non-technical introduction with applications to Marketing". We strongly recommend participating in this class or to complete similar online courses (e.g., free R Intro classes available on www.datacamp.com).
MaterialDescription:
Field A, Miles J, Field Z (2012), Discovering Statistics Using R, 1st ed., London: Sage. Hair JF, Black WC, Babin BJ, Anderson RE (2014), Multivariate Data Analysis. A Global Perspective, 7th ed., Upper Saddle River: Pearson.
Additional literature will be given in class.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This course will be held on-site with digital elements. All assessments will take place on-site, with some requiring you to bring your own device (iPads and other tablets are not permissible). Students must bring a laptop with R (cran.r-project.org/) & R-Studio (rstudio.com/rstudio.com/) installed (latest version). Please remember to bring your charger.

Contact: market-research@business.uzh.ch
CommonDescription: This course is an introduction to marketing analytics. Today, companies heavily rely on data-driven marketing to better understand the needs of their customers. Through various data collection methods, they gather data on, e.g., purchase behavior, social relationships, or attitudes. By analyzing such data, firms gain market insights and can enhance marketing decisions such as segmentation and targeting of customers, positioning of products based on customer preferences, or developing the right marketing mix. This class offers a practical introduction into understanding, applying, interpreting, and documenting quantitative research methods to analyze marketing data.
