ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The assessment consists of three parts:

  • Programming project (40%)
  • Tutorial presentation (30%)
  • Exercises (30%)
PrerequisitesDescription: Absolutely necessary are a solid understanding of assessment-level programming concepts (functions, calls, variables, classes, interpreter/compiler etc.) and an ability to program well in at least one programming language. Also, the willingness to seriously learn another programming language is required.
ObjectiveDescription: At the end of this course, students should be able to recognize and explain different programming paradigms and know their concepts and features, motivation, advantages and disadvantages. They will also have attained basic skills in multiple additional programming languages.
MaterialDescription: There will be an overview lecture with slides. Other than that, language-specific online resources will be the primary source of information.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription:
Programming languages can be classified into one or more paradigms. Going beyond the most popular and frequently encountered ones, such as object-orientation, students will learn about the reasoning and constituents of a variety of programming paradigms, including but not limited to: functional, logic, event-driven, reactive, concurrent, imperative vs. declarative, and side-effect-free programming as well as lambda calculus, message passing, pipelines and assembly. The course will begin with a few lectures giving a broad overview of programming paradigms. During the semester, each student will learn to solve problems in multiple programming languages. Students will need to create and solve programming exercises, give a presentation and implement a small software project.

Attending all sessions physically is mandatory.
AudienceDescription: Master's students who wish to enrich their knowledge in programming paradi and learn an additional programming language.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Re-examination will take place on 24.10.2024, 10.15 - 12.00 h.
PrerequisitesDescription: Advanced Microeconomics recommended
PrecognitionDescription: Microeconomics
ObjectiveDescription:
We will develop simple theoretical models with information asymmetry and review the recent empirical literature on bank stability and regulation.
At the end of the course, you should be able to understand the functioning of these models and be able to analyze and interpret banking data.
MaterialDescription:
Book: Microeconomics of Banking (Jean-Charles Rochet). For availability of the required reading please refer to "Link(s)" Freixas, X. and J.C. Rochet. "Microeconomics of Banking", MIT Press, second edition
Degryse, H., M. Kim and S. Ongena. "Microeconometrics of Banking", Oxford University Press
Various scientific papers
FurtherInfoDescription: The re-examination is only open to students who did not pass the examination in the spring term 2024 (due to failing or illness on day of exam). Students who do not fulfill this requirement may not take the examination.
CommonDescription:
The objective of this class is to get a better understanding of the role of banks in the economy, and how new financial products and technologies have changed traditional banking.
The course addresses the following questions:

  • Why do banks exist?
  • How does the loan market work?
  • How has banking changed in response to globalization?
  • How do banks manage credit risk?

Topics covered: The role of financial intermediaries, the lender- borrower relationship, credit market rationing, competition in the banking sector, the transmission of monetary policy, credit risk management and global banking.
AudienceDescription: Master Students and MSC UZH/ETH in Quantitative Finance Students

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module is carried out on site. The grade will be based on the final exam, which will cover all the materials used in the courses.

Examination on Monday, 13.01.2025, 16:15-18:00
SmText: Intercultural Management: Cultural dimensions of international management (L)
PrerequisitesDescription: Good command of English
PrecognitionDescription: General management, organization theory
ObjectiveDescription:
This course is designed for students at master's level who wish to prepare themselves for working effectively in international environments. After completion of this course, the participants shall have in-depth understanding of

  • Culture at both national and organizational levels.
  • The dimensions to compare basic human norms, assumptions, and behaviours.
  • The frameworks to analyse culture-bound management practices.
  • The challenges and opportunities for working in intercultural environment.

The final goal of this course is to help students develop intercultural competences and gain confidence in dealing with culture-related issues.
MaterialDescription: Hand-outs. Reading materials and case studies will be assigned throughout the course
CommonDescription:
Part I: Cultural intelligence

  • The concept of multiple intelligences
  • The determinants of cultural intelligence

Part II: Comparing cultures

  • Definitions of cultures
  • Measuring cultures
  • The six dimensions of Hofstede Model
  • Other cultural models

Part III: Culture-bound managerial challenges

  • National culture and organizational culture
  • Employee motivation across cultures
  • Expatriation and culture shock
  • Communication & negotiation
  • Management of diversity
  • Management of creativity and innovation
AudienceDescription: Elective course for students at master level majoring in management, economics, and finance

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Paper/essay and presentation on a selected topic to be carried out in groups of three students, plus discussion of a project carried out by another group.
Attendance on all three days is required.
Grading components:
Seminar paper/essay (60%), presentation (30%), discussion (10%).
PrerequisitesDescription: Before taking the seminar, students should have passed the exam in Financial Engineering (MSc Quant. Finance UZH/ETH course).
PrecognitionDescription: It is assumed that students have a good knowledge of mathematics, statistics, and financial theory.
ObjectiveDescription: This seminar serves as continuation of MSc Quant. Finance UZH/ETH course Financial Engineering. The main goal is to gain insights into and to critically assess current research in quantitative finance. In particular, the seminar puts an emphasis on applied topics in financial engineering and work with financial data.
MaterialDescription: References to relevant research papers will be provided at the beginning of the seminar. Additional materials will be available online.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Deadline for application (sending CV and motivation letter): Monday 09.
September 2024 (EOD)
Deadline for selection of topics: Wednesday 25. September 2024 (EOD), Deadline for submission of essays / reports: Sunday 1st December 2024 (EOD) Distribution of topics for discussion: Monday 2 December 2024 (EOD)
CommonDescription: The seminar covers current research in applied quantitative finance. The topics span new contributions in option pricing/hedging and variance/jump risk premia modelling, with special focus on applications of machine learning techniques in quantitative finance.
AudienceDescription: Advanced master students who have completed MSc Quant. Finance UZH/ETH course Financial Engineering.
AppointmentsDescription:
Intro Lecture: Monday 16. September 2024 (16:15-18:00) Presentation Session 1: Monday 09. December 2024 (08:00-12:00) Presentation Session
2: Tuesday 10. December 2024 (08:00-12:00)

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
50% exam, 50% in-class and homework assignments

The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on
7.1.2025, 2.00-3:45 pm.
FurtherInfoDescription: The module will not be recorded. No podcasts.
CommonDescription:
When does a policy achieve its intended goals, and when does it not? How can we use data to answer this question? How do we "translate" what the data shows into language that a policy-maker or the public can easily understand? In this class, we will focus on the fundamentals of using quantitative evidence - based on regression analysis and moderns econometric tools - to improve policy making. The primary goal is to become sophisticated and critical consumers of evidence, and a secondary goal is to become capable producers of evidence.
Contrary to typical courses in econometrics, we will do so in a rather non-technical manner, focusing more on building intuition, basic software skills, and ability to translate the evidence into language that makes it accessible to policy makers. (That is, using very little math or equations.) Also, the pedagogy will be based on in student-centered interactive learning, rather than solely relying traditional lecture-based pedagogy. This means that you are expected to participate in class room discussions. We will first define and discuss when and how evaluations are useful, as well as provide a framework for thinking how to judge the quality of an econometric study. Then, we will then cover the key concepts of different program evaluation methods (e.g.
difference in difference, randomized experiments, regression discontinuity design). This discussion will cover both the underlying statistics behind each technique, as well as how to draw relevant policy conclusions based on the statistical evidence. Through in-class exercises, case studies and assignments, students will practice using evaluation methods and will study the quality of the evidence. Examples will be primarily but not exclusively be drawn from international development and relations topics, but the material will be useful for anyone who is generally interested in using quantitative analysis to improve policy making.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Paper presentation (60%), participation/discussion (40%)
PrerequisitesDescription: The seminar is only open to students who are taking the lecture MOEC0434 Econometrics for Policy Analysts this semester as well.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The seminar is limited to 20 participants.

Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory.

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies.
Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.econ.uzh.ch/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html


Application for this seminar is via the module booking tool studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the regular module booking period for lectures.

The seminar takes place at SOF-G-21.
CommonDescription:
This seminar accompanies the lecture "Econometrics for Policy Analysts".
Students who want to further explore the topics of the lecture are invited to apply for the seminar as well.

The seminar is only open to students who are taking the lecture MOEC0434 Econometrics for Policy Analysts this semester as well. More details will be given during the first lecture session.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The final grade is comprised as follows:

  • Presentation and coding (70%).
  • In-class participation (30%).

The following absence policy for intermediate supervision sessions (worth 2.5% of the final grade each, 10% all together) is in effect:

In the seminar, there will be four intermediate "supervision sessions" to provide the students with advice, answer their questions individually, and assess progress toward the final presentation. These sessions are not graded, but participation is mandatory to achieve the full active participation score (10%). In the event that a student is unable to participate in the intermediate supervision sessions due to a valid medical reason, the student must promptly submit a doctor's certificate to the instructor (within one week of the missed assessment).

With a valid doctor's certificate, students are thus permitted to miss a maximum of two (out of the four) supervision sessions without reducing the active participation grade. Assessments missed under these circumstances will not be factored into the final grade calculation. If a session is missed but the necessary documentation is not provided within the stipulated one-week period, or if any further supervision sessions are missed, these will reduce the active participation grading by an amount proportional to the number of missed sessions.

This policy does not apply to the final presentation days. In cases where the final two days of the course must be unavoidably missed, the official regulations and procedures outlined by the Dean's Office apply.
PrecognitionDescription: Required: R or Python programming; knowledge of basic probability theory. No prior knowledge of social network methods or social dynamics modeling is required.
ObjectiveDescription:
The main objective is to offer the students theoretical knowledge and practical coding tools to understand the collective behaviors of consumers.  

On the theoretical side, the students will learn how to describe the spreading of new products and behaviors in terms of individual choices; analyze in which conditions certain social network structures and interventions may facilitate or prevent the large-scale adoption of new products and behaviors; and develop critical thinking about the main factors to consider when designing policies for social change.

On the practical side, the students will strengthen their coding skills by learning how to code simple agent-based models in Python and replicating one result from a published paper. They will also improve their presentation skills through a dedicated lecture and the preparation for their final presentation.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This seminar is limited to 8 students.

To apply for the seminar, students are required to send a CV, academic transcript (grades) and brief motivation letter (max. 1 page). Applications for this seminar should be submitted via email to manuel.mariani@business.uzh.ch by September 25th, 2024.
CommonDescription:
Why do most products, individuals and businesses remain little known, but a minority of them achieves runaway popularity and financial success? Why are some products and services adopted widely (e.g., Instagram, Tiktok, WeChat), but others failed spectacularly (e.g., Google glasses, Google+)? Which are key social factors to consider when designing a marketing intervention aimed at triggering the large-scale adoption of a new product or behaviour? What is the role of algorithms in all of that? To study these and more fascinating questions, the students will learn how to model the adoption of new products and behaviours in terms of the individual-level choices made by many consumers.
Such choices are not independent, but shaped by the social networks that connect the consumers. As a result, the collective dynamics generated by many consumers' choices lead to counterintuitive properties often overlooked by standard econometric and machine-learning models, with critical implications for marketing and social-change policies.

To understand collective consumer behavior and its marketing implications, the students will learn agent-based modelling and social network analytics techniques. The seminar aims to provide the students with a researcher-like experience: Each student will study in depth one research paper, attempt to replicate one of its figures, and deliver a final presentation on it. The papers cover four themes: Success inequalities; Social contagion in new product diffusion; Influencer marketing; Algorithmic feedback.

The seminar includes initial lectures that will provide the students with the theoretical elements of agent-based modelling and network science needed to understand and replicate the paper; hands-on tutorials in Python on agent-based simulations; a lecture on how to prepare a research presentation; intermediate supervision sessions. The seminar is particularly suited to: Business students who wish to deepen their understanding of the social forces driving consumer behavior; students who aim to strengthen their Python skills with a simple research project; students who are unsure whether to enroll for a PhD program in the future, as they could learn by doing how the research process looks like.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Assessment is based on students' performance in all four elements of the seminar:

  1. Seminar paper: 50%
  2. Slides & presentation of the seminar paper: 30%
  3. Discussion of the allocated co-student's presentation: 10%
  4. Active participation in the post-presentation dis-cussions of all other students: 10%
SmText: On-the-job training: Individual gains, firms' profits & labor market policies (S)
PrerequisitesDescription: Well passed courses in Empirical Methods and Personnel Economics and genuine interest in economics of education or personnel economics fields.
ObjectiveDescription:
Students will be introduced to various empirical findings within the on-the-job training literature. They will gain a solid overview of the problems when assessing the training effects on the firm and an individual level. They will understand labor market policies that change the prevalence of the training.

They will, too, train their presentation skills and learn to develop their own research topic. While writing their seminar paper, they will learn how to concisely summarize research findings and how to describe their own empirical research proposal.
MaterialDescription:
This is a paper-based course. The list of topics along with a set of example research papers will be presented and distributed to seminar participants during the kickoff. The recent study by Denzler et al. 2022 (below) serves as an initial introduction into the topic for students interested in the seminar:

Denzler, S., Ruhose, J. & Wolter, S. (2022). "The Double Dividend- Labor Market Effects of Work-Related Continuous Education in Switzerland. IZA DP No. 15619
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of students that can participate in this seminar is limited to 15.

Registration is mandatory:

Please send a brief email expressing your motivation to participate in the seminar, including your CV and latest transcript of records to katarina.zigova@business.uzh.ch by 15th of September 2024 at latest.

The seminar has a block form with a kickoff session at the beginning of the semester, where students obtain an overview of the research literature in this field organized along different topics. Each participant of the seminar picks from available topics based on his/her interest and prepares a seminar paper based on this topic which (i) summarizes empirical findings to date and (ii) proposes his/her own research project which could extend the current knowledge on the topic.

Midway through the semester, we will have a round of brief presentations, where each student gives a short overview of their topic and an early project vision. The seminar concludes with a full-day workshop at the end of the semester. In this workshop, students will present their seminar papers and make a short discussion of another student's paper including a critical assessment of his/her research proposal.

The course schedule is as follows:

Kickoff session: (Monday) 23.09.2024, 16:15-17:45

Brief presentation round: (Friday) 08.11.2024, 16:15-18:45

Individual midterm meetings: one hour per student during the week (flexible timing) 11.-15.11.2024

Deadline for the seminar paper submission: 08.12.2024

Student Workshop: Saturday 14.12.2024, 9-18
CommonDescription:
In this paper-based seminar we study, present, and discuss empirical contributions related to on-the-job training.

The issue of firm or individual financed training while on the job is of vivid interest among researchers, firms, and policy analysts. Since the early empirical evidence from 1970s, it rises continuous interest until today studying links between training and firms’ profit or innovativeness, between training and workers’ earnings, turnover, productivity or commitment. Individual or firms’ determinants of training, or effective labor market policies to moderate the prevalence of training in the economy are of equal interest to researchers and policy makers.
AudienceDescription: Well-passed courses in Empirical Methods and Personnel Economics and genuine interest in economics of education or personnel economics fields.
AppointmentsDescription:
The course schedule is as follows:

Kickoff session: (Monday) 23.09.2024, 16:15-17:45

Brief presentation round: (Friday) 08.11.2024, 16:15-18:45

Individual midterm meetings: one hour per student during the week (flexible timing) 11.-15.11.2024

Deadline for the seminar paper submission: 08.12.2024

Student Workshop: Saturday 14.12.2024, 9-18

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Group Projects (60%): Tasks from exercise sessions, including website setup, SEO optimization, social media, paid advertising, and email marketing, contribute to 60% of your grade. Each task requires a corresponding written report.

Presentation of Group Project (30%): A significant part of your assessment (30%) is based on presenting your group project, demonstrating your understanding and practical application of course concepts.

Participation in Interactive Sessions (10%): Active engagement in interactive sessions, including the Value Proposition Workshop, exercise sessions, and group work presentations, accounts for 10% of your overall grade. This reflects your commitment to the collaborative learning experience.
PrerequisitesDescription: Admission to the Master program
ObjectiveDescription:
Students...
...are able to apply the value proposition framework in the context of digital marketing.
...understand how to plan and integrate digital marketing strategy to traditional marketing and business strategy.
...are able to define and implement different approaches to realize and manage the digital marketing strategy using a digital marketing mix (i.e., website development, search engine optimization, paid online advertising, email marketing, marketing on social media)
...understand how to evaluate and optimize digital channel performance.
MaterialDescription: Slides and reading material (will be announced in the lecture)
FurtherInfoDescription:
• This lecture will take place on-site.
  • Slides, documents, and further information will be provided in OLAT at the beginning of the course
  • The registration for this course takes place via the UZH Module booking tool.
  • This course forms part of the marketing minor program in the master program
CommonDescription:
Digital marketing has transformed how business and other organizations communicate with their audiences. Thus, the question is not whether to use Internet technology but how to deploy it. The objective of this lecture is to give you an overview of the fundamentals of digital marketing. The lecture will be structured as follows:

  1. Introduction to Digital Marketing
  2. Value Proposition Design
  3. Metrics and Analytics
  4. Website Development
  5. Search Engine Optimization
  6. Marketing on Social Media
  7. Advertising Online (display and paid search)
  8. Email Marketing

Throughout bi-weekly exercise sessions, students will apply theoretical knowledge to a collaborative group project. Each group is tasked with developing their own project ideas, such as a book exchange platform, a landing page to promote an app launch, or a platform to find sports buddies. The practical application involves setting up a basic website, optimizing it for search engines, promoting their projects on social media, implementing a paid online advertising campaign, and conducting an email marketing campaign. In the final lecture and exercise session, each group will present their project along with the insights gained from the experience.

Active participation is crucial for success in this course, especially during exercise sessions, the Value Proposition Design Workshop, and group project presentations. Your engagement in these activities will directly influence your assessment.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Four to six groups work to co-design a concrete digital marketing campaign, bring it to life, measure its impact and communicate the results in the course. The digital marketing campaign unfolds over three main sequential milestones: 1. analysis, 2. strategy, and 3. execution. At each milestone, students need to demonstrate their business acumen and creative talent.

Grades are assigned as follows:
• Assignment 1: report, in-class presentation and discussion (20%);

• Assignment 2: canvas, in-class presentation and discussion (20%);

• Assignment 3: .ppt, in-class presentation and discussion (40%);

• Average individual peer evaluation score (20%).
PrecognitionDescription:
A very strong interest in digital marketing topics. It is strongly recommended to participate
in the lecture “Fundamentals of Digital Marketing” (L+E) offered by Prof. Andrea Giuffredi-
Kaehr (VVZ-Nr. 03SM22MO0197) in parallel to this seminar. While the lectures focus on the
core Digital Marketing concepts, the seminar applies them to concrete campaigns.
ObjectiveDescription:
The seminar is fast-paced, practical, and interactive. The module comprises a total of six frontal meetings over 12 weeks. Every meeting is an occasion to discuss the progress of the group projects are receiving valuable feedback from the instructor, classmates and managers. Each meeting builds on the previous and leads to the creation of a professionally designed and executed digital marketing campaign. 

Through course discussions, workshops, and projects we:

•    Gain a deep understanding of all critical digital marketing plan phases (analysis, strategy, execution). 
•    Learn how to professionally deliver on a mandate while collaborating with a diversified/multi-cultural group and interacting with complex business environments.
•    Apply innovative marketing techniques to real-world problems by co-creating a digital marketing campaign.
•    Review best-in-class processes for content marketing ideation, development and distribution.
•    Present and give feedback on marketing projects; fundamental activities to improve critical thinking and communication skills.
MaterialDescription: To be announced online
FurtherInfoDescription:
Application for this course is via the module booking tool: https://studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad/

In order to enroll in the course, students must submit their CV, academic transcript (showing their grades), and a short motivation letter (limited to one page) before the deadline. Incomplete applications will not be considered.

For detailed information, please download the course syllabus on our website (https://cutt.ly/DMCP2024).

Room: AND 4.55/4.57
CommonDescription:
This seminar is designed for future managers and entrepreneurs interested in planning, developing and implementing integrated marketing campaigns across different media outlets. 

This course introduces digital marketing thinking and explores the integration of traditional and innovative marketing techniques and their applications to real-world problems. With the explosion of technology-based consumer touchpoints and consumer expectations hitting all-time highs, managers are required to understand the nuances of ever-evolving consumer behaviors in a face-paced and uncertain business environment. 

Future careers increasingly demand the ability to understand digital environments and implement creative solutions to reach measurable goals. That’s why this course follows an experiential learning approach that puts students in the position of managers while encouraging them to make trade-off decisions and test ideas in the marketplace. 

A hands-on and can-do attitude are the common characteristics of all the course participants. Why? Students don’t have a textbook to memorize, and they are not micromanaged by corporate managers or tutors. Instead, participants are expected to learn by doing, proactively seek expert support, and independently make strategic managerial decisions. As such, this module is a playground for testing and learning from practice, following the new logic of "failing fast" and "constant experimentation. 

This seminar promises to provide talented students with deep insights into the challenges and opportunities modern marketers face in organizations when implementing digital marketing campaigns. At the end of this course, students are likely to have significantly changed their perspective on strategic and operational marketing practices. 

A supervised self-learning workshop format gives students the skills necessary to think like cutting-edge marketers seeking to digitally build relationships with relevant audiences. This is one of a kind seminar because: 

•    The program is intentionally unstructured.
•    There will be no classical teaching material.
•    Each team defines the project scope and breadth.
•    Students need to reach out to instructors proactively for domain-specific support.

TestsDescription: Seminararbeit in Gruppen
SmText: Seminar zum Accounting: Controlling in Fallstudien
PrecognitionDescription: Vorlesung Managerial Accounting
ObjectiveDescription:
• Controllinginstrumente und Finanzkennzahlen als Entscheidungsgrundlagen bewerten und anwenden können.
  • Das Zusammenspiel von Controlling, Finanzen und Unternehmertum in praxisrelevanten Fallstudien verstehen lernen.
MaterialDescription:
• Peters, Gerd/Pfaff, Dieter: Controlling: Wichtigste Methoden und Techniken,
    4. Aufl., Zürich 2021, Versus Verlag
  • Fallstudien zum Accounting
FurtherInfoDescription:
Die Teilnehmerzahl ist auf 18 Personen beschränkt. Zweitanmeldung direkt am Lehrstuhl erforderlich.
Hinweise zum Anmeldeverfahren siehe OLAT: https://t.uzh.ch/1CB Nach Zuteilung eines Seminarplatzes müssen Sie diesen innerhalb einer gegebenen Frist bestätigen. Durch die Bestätigung wird die Anmeldung verbindlich und Sie verpflichten sich zur Teilnahme am Seminar.
CommonDescription:
Schwerpunkt ist es, die betriebswirtschaftlichen Denk- und Analyseprozesse in
praxisorientierten Fällen zu vertiefen:

  • In welchen Kategorien denken Finanzleute und Controller*innen?
  • Welche Werkzeuge wendet das Controlling an?
  • Wie werden die finanziellen Aspekte von Managemententscheidungen erfasst?
  • Wie wird finanzwirtschaftlich argumentiert? Das Seminar soll Ihnen die Welt

und die Sprache des Controllings nahe bringen und Ihnen zeigen, in welchen
Dimensionen das Controlling denkt.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
One final exam.
The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on: Thursday, December 19, 2024. 12.00 - 14.00
PrecognitionDescription: at least one semester of undergraduate calculus
ObjectiveDescription: The student is expected to obtain a solid understanding and working ability with the concepts and methods associated with beginning real analysis.
MaterialDescription: We use (the first several chapters of) the following two books: «Introduc to Real Analysis», by Manfred Stoll, 3rd edition, 2021; and Fitzpatrick, Advanced Calculus, 2nd edition, 2000.
CommonDescription: We will cover the standard topics in a one semester first course in real analysis appropriate for the intended audience, which in our case is students in our faculty, as opposed to the mathematics department (for which a higher level of presentation is used). The goal is to prepare the student for further study in courses that require this material, such as (post-introductory) probability theory, machine learning, microeconomics, mathematical finance, financial economics, and asset pricing. The list of topics is very standardized in nearly all textbooks at our intended level, and we will cover up to Riemann integration.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The examination of the module will take place onsite. Written examination on:
16 January 2025, 16.15 to 18:00. The net processing time for the exam is 75 minutes.
ObjectiveDescription:
The principal aims of the course are to:

  • Provide students with a thorough understanding of the theories of leadership and contemporary leadership research
  • Engage in critical thinking regarding leadership research and the future of leadership
  • Translate a body of scientific knowledge into a concrete, applicable leadership toolbox necessary for future leaders.
MaterialDescription: Readings will be announced on the course webpage when the course starts.
CommonDescription: Students will learn about leadership and develop their own potential as leaders. This course guides students through over a century of leadership research, highlighting various theoretical perspectives of leadership as well as trends within the leadership literature. Students will learn to think critically about the history of leadership research and its future.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The final assessment consists of an oral group presentation (to a specific topic) in person on the exam date:
Tuesday 21 January 2025, 12:00-18:00
Assessment Criteria:

  1. demonstrate understanding of the topic (40%)
  2. adds own reflections (20%)
  3. academic integrity (20%)
  4. quality of presentation (20%)
SmText: Investment Process in Practice - Fundamentals and Applications (L)
PrerequisitesDescription: Bachelor
PrecognitionDescription: Asset Management: Advanced Investments (mandatory, can be taken in the same semester); FinTech & InsurTech - Digitalization of the Financial Services Industry, Behavioral Finance and Private Banking as well as Sustainable Investing (recommended)
ObjectiveDescription:
After completing this course students:

  • Understand the (institutional) investment process along multi- and single asset classes
  • Know the different elements of the investment process and how they interact: investment objectives, Strategic Asset Allocation, Tactical Asset Allocation, Selection/Rebalancing and Risk Management/Reporting/Performance Monitoring, also for various types of investors
  • Describe academic concepts related to the various steps of the investment process
  • Understand the key challenges in investment processes and bring in own thoughts
MaterialDescription: will be provided
FurtherInfoDescription: This module takes place on-site with no recording.
CommonDescription: The course "Investment Process in Practice - Fundamentals and Applications" integrates various areas of finance to look at the institutional investment process. The teaching will cover fundamental principles, asset classes in a portfolio context, strategic and tactical asset allocation and implementation, but also investment process governance, aspects of risk management as well as life cycle management, performance measurement and reporting. The course will also discuss the role of digital assets and has a particular look at sustainability across investment processes. In addition, use cases of specific types of investors (e.g. foundations) will be presented. The teaching will encompass the application of academic concepts, enriched by practical examples and various guest speakers.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
20% to oral participation
30% Presentation during the seminar (in Groups)
50% Final Presentation in Groups after the end of the seminar (Monday afternoon 14:00-17:00 21st of October)
PrecognitionDescription:
We would welcome students having followed or planning to follow the seminar "Verantwortung in den Finanzmärkten - eine interdisziplinäre Perspektive" (M. Chesney, C. Tanner, B. Maranghino- Singer) in the spring semester.
Additionally, students should have a basic understanding of finance and investments or a strong interest.
ObjectiveDescription:
- The students will:

(1) Achieve a broad understanding of how environ-mental risks and more precisely climate change and biodiversity loss impact today's business mod financial institutions

(2) Understand a possible framework to integrate environmental aspects into FIs business model and apply this framework (work on case studies)

(3) Understand how financial institutions can play an active role towards a low carbon and more sus-tainable economy by decarbonizing their portfolio, integrating climate and biodiversity risks, nature positive impact and mission investment and finance

(4) Get a general understanding of the different ap-proaches, tools and methodologies Financial Institu-tions have at hand when aiming at decarbonizing their portfolio for different asset classes and manag-ing biodiversity risks and impacts.
MaterialDescription:
Class time will combine lectures, seminar-style dis-cussions, work on case-studies and presentations by guest speakers.
A list of recommended books and papers will be uploaded at www.bf.uzh.ch/cms/studium_248.html
FurtherInfoDescription: Maximum 24 participants on a first come/first served-basis, according to the registration on OLAT. The registration on OLAT will be open from 15 May (12.00) until 15 June 2024 (12.00). Kick-off meeting: Friday, 21 June 2024, 10.00 h, in room PLD E-04 at Plattenstrasse 32. After the kick-off, the selected students have to book the seminar via the "Modulbuchungstool" in order to be registered for the exam and obtain ECTS points".
CommonDescription:
Today, no actor of the financial sector, being a bank, an insurer or an institutional investor, can afford not having an overall strategy for how to position itself towards a low carbon economy and an economy that protect and restore nature. Climate change and biodiversity loss represents both significant risks on a historical scale.

At the COP 21 in Paris, the international community agreed on an agenda to cut greenhouse gas emissions to a level that will limit the rise in average global temperatures to 1.5°C. Investments in emission reductions require significant upscaling to enable the rapid and far-reaching shifts in energy, land, urban, infrastructure and industrial systems. The IPCC report[1] finds that in 1.5°C pathways "annual average investment needs in the energy system of around 2.4 trillion USD2010 between 2016 and 2035, representing about 2.5% of the world GDP". By 2050, "annual investment in low-carbon energy technologies and energy efficiency need to be upscaled by roughly a factor of five" compared to today in 1.5°C pathways. If we look at nature, partial ecosystem collapse is projected to cost
$2.7 trillion each year by 2030[2] and according the WEF, $44 trillion of economic value generation, more than half of the world's total GDP, is moderately or highly dependent on nature and its services, and therefore exposed to risks from nature loss[3]

On the other hand, Institutional investors, in OECD countries alone, held over
70 trillion Euros in assets in December 2011[4] and could translate climate and nature risks and opportunities within their investment activities and decisions by implementing investment strategies that are compatible with a 1.5-degree scenario of climate change and that contribute to halting biodiversity loss.
To be prepared for the future, financial institutions should therefore systematically understand the environmental challenges and opportunities that climate change and loss of biodiversity represents and incorporate this into their mainstream business strategy and investment decisions.
AudienceDescription: This seminar is open to BF students in their second or third year of bachelor who have an interest for the links between the financial sector and environmental issues, and more specially climate change.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The grade will be determined based on the presentation (in groups of two/one grade per group, 40%) and an essay (8 pages, deadline:
10.11.2024, 60%).
PrerequisitesDescription: Students must have completed an undergraduate course in "International Trade" (e.g., Introduction to International Trade by Ralph Ossa). Proof of completion must be uploaded with the application.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The seminar is held by Prof. Ralph Ossa who is currently the chief economist of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The seminar is limited to 16 participants (by application only). The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

Please follow the instructions on our website: www.econ.uzh.ch/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html

Application for this seminar is via the module booking tool studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad


When applying, please upload a) your current MA transcript of records, and b) confirmation of BA course in International trade.
Applications lacking (one of) these documents will be rejected.

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the regular module booking period for lectures.

Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory.
CommonDescription: In this seminar, we practice deriving policy-relevant insights from academic research under the guidance of the Chief Economist of the World Trade Organization (WTO). We imagine a setting in which we advise the Director General on how to make trade in general, and the WTO in particular, part of the solution to the most pressing challenges of our time. This involves tackling broad issues such as trade & sustainability, trade & inclusiveness, and trade & security, as well as making concrete reform proposals on controversial WTO agreements such as the Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Duties (SCM), the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS), and the Agreement on Trade- Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS).
AudienceDescription: This seminar is open for MA students in their 3rd semester who have successfully completed the compulsory courses.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The final grade of the seminar consists of participation, a group presentation and a group project. The description and the weight of the assessment items are described below:

  • PARTICIPATION (20%). Students will be assigned readings, which prepare participants for in-class discussions.
  • PRESENTATION (40%). In a small group, students present concepts and managerial issues related to various applications of quantitative methods in sports.
  • GROUP PROJECT (40%). From theory to practice. The final project is a formal research proposal, in which students review the related literature and critically discuss the previous models and methodologies applied to a particular sports problem. The project should also identify potential future opportunities for application of quantitative methods in the considered sport setting, and discuss potential implementation challenges and desired outcomes.

Attendance:
Note: Punctuality, participation in group activities, and contribution to a fruitful and enjoyable class atmosphere are factors that will be considered. The instructors may use these items at their discretion to adjust final grades in borderline cases. Academic integrity and plagiarism.


Participants are expected to have a truthful and ethical behaviour and be familiar with the rules and procedures against plagiarism. Students will be held accountable for violations of these rule and procedures during the seminar. Further information on plagiarism and its treatment at UZH can be found in the information sheet "Fact sheet on plagiarism". This sheet is available on the university's website at the following link (listed under "Plagiarism" at the very bottom of the page):

www.oec.uzh.ch/en/studies/theses.html
ObjectiveDescription:
The seminar aims to stimulate students' learning with a combination of teaching methods: readings from academic journals and newspapers, class presentations, discussions, and group projects. By the end of the seminar, participants should have gained in-depth knowledge on the topic and the related interdisciplinary challenges reflected in the following specific learning objectives:

  • understanding of basic methodological concepts used in various sport related applications,
  • being able to explain and critically discuss (with data and/or theoretical concepts) various examples of quantitative methods applied to sports problems,
  • being able to identify and critically discuss opportunities, the resulting challenges, and the desired outcomes for potential future applications of quantitative methods in sport related settings.
MaterialDescription: There is no required textbook for the seminar. The lectures and notes of the seminar contain a number of research articles and book chapters for debate and discussion. The reading material will be readily available for students on OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of participants is limited. In the event of excess demand, we reserve the right to select the participants based on the application via the following link:

www.uzh.ch/zi/cl/umfragen/index.php/985741

  • Application deadline: August 26, 2024
  • Notification of acceptance: August 30, 2024
CommonDescription:
The application of mathematical/quantitative methods to the study and analysis of a wide variety of sports problems has become increasingly popular in recent years. This trend can be attributed to the increased availability of "big" data and the advancements in theoretical and computational analytics techniques, e.g., machine learning, operations research. It has been demonstrated by multiple examples that mathematical/quantitative methods may provide powerful insights and/or competitive advantages as well as help the sport organizations to improve their performance by making more informed and sophisticated decisions.
The seminar will review the mainstream literature on applications of quantitative methods in various sports related contexts. We will discuss multiple thought-provoking application examples ranging from classical scheduling problems in different sport leagues to modern "fantasy" sports. The seminar participants will become familiar with challenges and opportunities arising when applying quantitative methods to modern sports.
AudienceDescription:
The seminar is open to:
(1) Bachelor students of the Business Administration program (BWL); (2) Bachelor students from other programs with a justified interest in quantitative methods in sport related applications
AppointmentsDescription:
The number of participants is limited. In the event of excess demand, we reserve the right to select the participants based on the application. Link to be provided.

  • Application deadline: August 26, 2024
  • Notification of acceptance: August 30, 2024
  • Introductory meeting: tbd

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Replication and documentation of a topic currently published in the academic literature (topics and papers provided by the lecturer) and application to Switzerland (presentation 30% of grade, 5-page report with codes 70% of grade)

Deadline for the report is: 23.01.2025
PrerequisitesDescription: Contents of the Master lecture "Time Series Analysis".
PrecognitionDescription:
This seminar is designed for master-level students with a solid understanding of econometric principles and statistical analysis.
Familiarity with regression analysis and basic time series concepts is highly recommended. First experiences in R programming are welcome, but not necessary. Students should have a working knowledge of data manipulation, statistical modelling, and regression analysis techniques.
ObjectiveDescription:
By the end of the seminar, students will have a solid grasp of the theory and practice of applied time series econometrics.

They will be able to effectively analyze and interpret time series data, build econometric models, and make accurate forecasts for economic variables.

Moreover, participants will gain proficiency in using R as a prevailing tool for time series analysis, enhancing their overall analytical capabilities and employability in various research or industry settings.
MaterialDescription: Paper reading list via OLAT
FurtherInfoDescription:
This seminar is held by an external lecturer, Dr. Philipp Wegmüller who is currently Deputy Head in the Short-Term Economic Analysis unit at the State Secretariat for Economic Affairs (SECO Staatssekretariat für Wirtschaft).

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.econ.uzh.ch/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the regular module booking period for lectures.
CommonDescription:
The comprehensive and practical seminar is designed to equip students with the necessary knowledge and skills to analyze and model time series data in the field of economics. This seminar offers an advanced exploration of time series econometrics techniques, with a strong emphasis on hands-on applications using the open-source statistical programming language R.

Throughout the seminar, students will apply known concepts and theories underpinning time series analysis, understanding the unique challenges and characteristics of time-dependent data in economic research. The course will cover a wide range of topics, including stationarity, autocorrelation, forecasting, mixed-frequency models and more. Students will learn how to implement these techniques using the powerful R programming language and various packages dedicated to time series analysis.

The seminar will provide a combination of theoretical inputs, practical exercises, and real-world case studies to reinforce the understanding of time series econometrics. Participants will have the opportunity to apply their knowledge to real economic datasets, gaining hands-on experience in data preprocessing, model selection, estimation, and evaluation. The instructors will guide students through the process of implementing different time series models, such as ARIMA, SETAR, and state-space models, using R's extensive library of time series functions.

TestsDescription: 15-minütige Voice-over-PowerPoint (1/3 Endnote) Lösung Process Mining Case Study als 5-seitiger Report (1/3 Endnote) Abschlusspräsentation Case Study (1/3 Endnote)
SmText: Seminar: Business Process Intelligence - Management, Discovery, and Mining (BSc)
PrerequisitesDescription: Eigenes lauffähiges Notebook mit Python 3.9 und PyCharm vorinstalliert.
ObjectiveDescription:
Nach Teilnahme des Kurses, können Sie ...

  • ... die Grundlagen von Geschäftsprozessmanagement und -intelligenz erklären.
  • ... die Rolle von Geschäftsprozessen in Organisationen erläutern, diese modellieren und die Konzepte der Modularisierung, Variantenbildung und horizontalen Integration anwenden.
  • ... die methodischen Grundlagen von Datenanalyse über den kompletten Lebenszyklus eines datengetriebenen Forschungsprojektes verstehen, planen und anwenden (vgl. CRISP-DM Methode).
  • ... unterschiedliche Verfahren zur Datensammlung einsetzen und Rohdaten für die weitere Analyse aufbereiten (bspw. mit Big Data and Data Science).
  • ... die Grundlagen der Verarbeitung Natürlicher Sprache für prozessorientierte Analysen erkennen und diese auf ausgewählte Problemstellungen anwenden (vgl. Natural Language Processing and Natural Language Understanding).
  • ... Ansätze zur Planung, Erstellung und zum Betrieb einer Process Mining Anwendung in einem digitalen Ökosystem analysieren, untersuchen und bewerten.
MaterialDescription:
Leimeister, J. M. (2021): Einführung in die Wirtschaftsinformatik.
van der Aalst, W. (2016): Process Mining: Data Science in Action. James, G, Witten, D., Hastie, T., Tibshirani, R. (2017): An Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in R, Springer.
Provost, F., Fawcett, T. (2013): Data Science for Business: What you need to know about data mining and data‑analytic thinking, OʹReilly. Bird, Steven & Klein, Ewan & Loper, Edward. (2009). Natural Language Processing with Python.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Die Zuteilung der Studierenden zu diesem Seminar erfolgt durch das Institut über das neue Modulbuchungstool. Sollten nicht genügend Plätze zur Verfügung stehen, werden Studierende, die Informatik im Major studieren und noch kein Seminar besucht haben und bereits weit im Studium sind, bevorzugt. Bitte beachten Sie, dass wir keinen Platz garantieren können.

Weitere Informationen über das Verfahren finden Sie auf unserer Website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Die Anmeldung zu diesem Seminar erfolgt über das neue Modulbuchungstool :studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription:
Organisationen, die Daten ihrer Prozessstrukturen nicht kennen und intelligent nutzen können, werden in der Zukunft immer mehr Probleme mit ihrer Wettbewerbsfähigkeit bekommen. Dabei spielt nicht nur die Datenspeicherung und Datenanalyse eine wichtige Rolle, sondern insbesondere die Verknüpfung von Datenanalysemethoden mit den jeweiligen Geschäftsprozessen, um diese intelligent zu überwachen und eventuelle Vorhersagen abzuleiten.
Process Mining schließt die Lücke zwischen der traditionellen modellbasierten Prozessanalyse (z. B. Simulation und andere Geschäftsprozessmanagementtechniken) und datenzentrierten Analysetechniken wie maschinellem Lernen und Data Mining. Bei Process Mining werden Ereignisdaten (d.h. beobachtetes Verhalten) und (manuell erstellte oder automatisch ermittelte) Prozessmodelle einander gegenübergestellt. Die Technologie ist erst seit kurzem breit verfügbar, kann aber auf jede Art von Betriebsprozessen (Organisationen und Systeme) angewendet werden (bspw. bei der Analyse von Behandlungsabläufen in Krankenhäusern oder zur Verbesserung der Kundendienstprozesse).
Dieser Kurs vermittelt den Teilnehmern Wissen, Konzepte und praktische Methoden an der Schnittstelle zwischen intelligentem Geschäftsprozessmanagement und neusten Methoden und Ansätzen des Process Mining. Dazu werden zu Beginn des Kurses Konzepte über die Modellierung von Geschäftsprozessen vermittelt / wiederholt und dabei Bezug auf digitale Strategien und nutzerzentrierte Dienstleistungsbeispiele genommen. Mithilfe der Modularisierung erlernen die Teilnehmer ein praktisches Konzept, um Geschäftsprozesse nicht nur von Grund auf neu zu denken, sondern auch intelligenter zu gestalten und in Organisationen effizient einzubetten.
Das Hauptaugenmerk des Seminars liegt darauf den Bogen von der klassischen Geschäftsprozess-Modellierung zu Data Science und Big Data zu schlagen. Dabei werden die wichtigsten Analysetechniken von Process Mining erklärt und den Teilnehmern an praktischen Beispielen verdeutlicht. Aufbauend auf den drei Process Mining Analysetechniken (Process Discovery, Process Conformity und Process Enhancement) werden den Teilnehmern zusätzliche Methoden des Natural Language Processing und Machine Learning vermittelt, um neben einfachen Process Logs auch textuelle Daten in die Process Analyse intelligent miteinzubeziehen. Die Teilnehmer werden mit den Grundlagen von Big Data, Data Science und Data Mining vertraut gemacht und in die Lage versetzen, diese Ansätze auf prozessrelevante Probleme anzuwenden.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: 20% problem sets, 80% paper.
SmText: Impact Investing, Sustainable Finance & Family Offices (S)
ObjectiveDescription:
1. Understand the different sustainable investing approaches
  2. Understand the mechanisms of how investors have impact and how not
  3. Understand how to build investment portfolios including an impact- angle, including Strategic Asset Allocation implications.
  4. Understand the role and challenges of different actors along the value chain in wealth management
  5. Understand the processes and challenges behind ESG data
MaterialDescription:
Paetzold, F., Busch, T. (2014). "Unleashing the Powerful Few: Sustainable Investing Behaviour of Wealthy Private Investors".
Organization & Environment, 27(4), 347-367. doi:
10.1177/1086026614555991.
Kölbel, J., Heeb, F. (2020). The Investor's Guide to Impact - Evidence- based advice for investors who want to change the world. Zurich: CSP.
Impact Investing. Paetzold Falko, Editor: Swiss Sustainable Finance. In: Handbook for Sustainable Investments, Zurich: CFA Society, p. 97-111, Published: 2017
FurtherInfoDescription: Students need to apply to participate in the seminar. Application (CV) is possible until Monday, 1.07.2024, to falko.paetzold@df.uzh.ch.
CommonDescription:
This seminar discusses the rise of two parallel, critical themes: On one hand, the climate crisis, biodiversity crisis, and other sustainability challenges led to the currently ongoing mainstreaming of impact investing and sustainable finance - with all its challenges, incl.
green-/impact-washing. On the other hand, half of global wealth has become intensely concentrated amongst less than 1% of the world population. This seminar dives into how sustainable- and impact investing really works, and how private wealth holders and family offices grapple with the theme. We will discuss the underlying science, speak with real-world family offices in-person, and learn how to build impactful investment portfolios.
Events_1_EStext: Impact Investing, Sustainable Finance & Family Offices (S)

SmText: Doctoral Seminar Dynamic and Distributed Information Systems
ObjectiveDescription:
• The PhD students know how to design and present a scientific publication
  • The students know how to manage their PhD project
MaterialDescription: Slides and, possibly, additional material will be distributed after the presentations
FurtherInfoDescription: Registration by E-Mail to: ddis-teaching@ifi.uzh.ch
CommonDescription: The course has two parts: In one workshop lasting 1-2 days, each doctoral student presents a progress report on his/her PhD thesis. The second part consists of a series of one-hour lunch talks on every Tuesday during the teaching period. These lunch talks present current paper projects, conference reports, presentation rehearsals, research designs and guest lectures. If needed, written material will have to be prepared.

• Fact sheet (25%)
  • References list (10%)

ObjectiveDescription:
At the end of the course, students:

  • have gained a deeper and broader understanding and knowledge of visual analytics, as an important principle that fosters human-AI collaboration
  • will be able to identify and discuss research problems as well as identify and structure relevant related work
  • will be able to write a fact sheet about a specific paper, present the topic to a student audience, and discuss ideas on the topic.
  • will have learned to accept and give feedback on students' seminar contributions
MaterialDescription: Research papers. The teacher will give advice on how these resources can be retrieved (literature research) and be structured. These papers will depend on the seminar topic. The teacher may adapt individual seminar topics due to student curiosity.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription:
Topic Focus: Visual Analytics (VA) is the science of analytical reasoning and data-driven decision-making, by leveraging the strengths of powerful machine learning methods and human abilities, through interactive visual interfaces. At its core, interactive visual interfaces empower people to actively explore and manipulate data, making it easier to spot underlying patterns, trends, and anomalies that might otherwise remain hidden. This is further supported by the tight integration of algorithmic models and visual representations, ensuring a deep and nuanced understanding of data. Also, the human-in-the-loop and feedback loop principles deeply rooted in VA enrich interactive machine learning processes with human insights, leading to more accurate and relevant outcomes.

Course Mechanics: In small groups, students will study a visual analytics paper of interest, and with respect to this paper, develop a review of related works.
Students will structure related works in a taxonomic way, prepare a compelling fact sheet about the paper topic, and present the topic in class. In parallel, students will receive mentoring from the supervisor, give constructive feedback on other students' work, and participate actively in the presentation roun
AppointmentsDescription:
The kickoff meeting and topic presentation slots are fixed.
Hands-on supervision, based on individual appointments.

TestsDescription: Presentation of the group project
ObjectiveDescription:
• To understand the importance of digital health interventions for the prevention, management, and treatment of non-communicable diseases and common mental disorders
  • To discuss the opportunities and challenges of digital health interventions (e.g., data collection with wearables, smartphone- and chatbot-delivered health interventions)
  • To gain hands-on experience in the conceptual design, implementation and evaluation of a wearable- and smartphone-based digital health intervention
MaterialDescription:
All relevant learning material will be made available via the online learning platform. Moreover, the content of this module is drawn from the experience of the lecturers and the following work:

Balbim GM, IG Marques, DX Marquez, et al. (2021) Using Fitbit as an mHealth Intervention Tool to Promote Physical Activity: Potential Challenges and Solutions, Journal of Medical Internet Research (JMIR) Mhealth Uhealth 9(3):e25289, 10.2196/25289

Collins LM (2018) Optimization of Behavioral, Biobehavioral, and Biomedical Interventions: The Multiphase Optimization Strategy (MOST), New York: Springer, 10.1007/978-3-319-72206-1

Jacobson N, T Kowatsch & LA Marsch (2022) Digital Therapeutics for Mental Health and Addiction: The State of the Science and Vision for the Future (1st ed.), Cambridge: Elsevier, Academic Press, 978-0-323-90045-4

Kowatsch T & Fleisch E (2021) Digital Health Interventions, in Gassmann, O.; Ferrandina, F. (eds): Connected Business, Springer: Cham, 10.1007/978-3-030-76897-3_4

Kowatsch T, L Otto, S Harperink, A Cotti & H Schlieter (2019) Design and Evaluation Framework for Digital Health Interventions, it- Information Technology 61(5-6), 253-263, 10.1515/itit-2019-0019

Kowatsch T, T Schachner, S Harperink et al. (2021) Conversational Agents as Mediating Social Actors in Chronic Disease Management Involving Health Care Professionals, Patients, and Family Members: Multisite Single-Arm Feasibility Study, Journal of Medical Internet Research (JMIR) 23(2):e25060, 10.2196/25060

Sim I. (2019) Mobile Devices and Health, New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) 381(10):956-968, 10.1056/NEJMra1806949
FurtherInfoDescription:
Rooms and timing details to be found here: https://tinyurl.com/5n6vybtn

The allocation of students to this course will be done through the department via the new module booking tool.
A short motivation statement (3 - 5 sentences should be added in the text field in the module booking tool)

Application for this module is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription:
Fitbits detect lasting changes after Covid-19 (New York Times, 2022), The promise of the metaverse in cardiovascular health (European Heart Journal, 2022), Can Virtual Reality Help Ease Chronic Pain? (The New York Times Magazine, 2022), First of its Kind Alexa Experience Provides Hands-Free Access at Home to General Medical Care (GlobeNewswire, 2022), Can digital technologies improve health? (The Lancet, 2021), Predictive analytics and tailored interventions improve clinical outcomes (npj Digital Medicine, 2021), Q1 2022 Digital Health Funding Reaches $6B Across 183 Deals (Rock Health, 2022).

Digital health applications use information, sensor and communication technology to understand, prevent, manage, or treat diseases. The design of these applications requires interdisciplinary expertise at the intersection of medicine, psychology, computer science, technology, management, economics, and law. Only a close collaboration between experts from these disciplines and a specific target population can lead to a shared understanding of the problem at hand and, as a result, highly effective digital health applications. For this reason, national and international students studying computer science, business informatics, psychology, management, economics, or law are invited to work collaboratively with medical students.

Digital health applications and companies have the goal of advancing health care services to fight the ongoing increase of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) and common mental disorders (CMDs) in developed countries. To this end, the question arises of how to develop evidence- based digital health interventions (DHI) that allow medical doctors and other caregivers to scale and tailor long-term treatments to individuals in need at sustainable costs. Through input lectures and practical applications, this module has, therefore, the objective to help students to better understand the need, design, implementation, and evaluation of DHIs.

The following topics are covered:

  1. DHIs for the prevention, management, and treatment of NCDs and CMDs
  2. Strategies for long-term compliance with DHI
  3. Conceptual design of a wearable- and smartphone-based DHI
  4. Technical implementation of a wearable- and smartphone-based DHI
  5. Evaluation of a wearable- and smartphone-based DHI

Methodology
The module consists of live input sessions with interactive group exercises and group discussions. Complementary learning material is provided in the form of tutorial video clips and exercises. Additional coaching sessions are offered to support the groups with the development of their DHI and with the preparation of their presentations. In addition to the MobileCoach platform (www.mobile-coach.eu), an open- source software platform for the development of digital biomarkers and health interventions, students will gain hands-on experience with wearable fitness trackers (Fitbits).
Programming skills are not required.

SmText: Topics in Neuroeconomics and Social Neuroscience (S)
PrerequisitesDescription: Successful completion of all compulsory modules in the Doctoral Program in Neuroeconomics.
ObjectiveDescription: In-depth study of the materials presented

This course will take place in BLU-003 (Blümlisalpstrasse 10, 8006 Zurich).
If you wish to attend this course, please send an e-mail with your name and student ID number (Matrikelnummer) to cornelia.schnyder@econ.uzh.ch.

Partof_1_ScText: Doctorate Neuroeconomics (PVO10)

TestsDescription: The final grade will be a weighted average of the grades for the paper presentation (40%), the discussion of a paper (10%), active participation in classroom discussions (10%), and the seminar essay (40%).
ObjectiveDescription: This seminar has two goals. The first is to familiarize students with concepts and methods used in public economics. The second is to practice the skills of extracting and communicating insights from original research papers in economics. To this end, students will present recent research papers and discuss their merits and limitations. In a short final paper, students expand on the discussion in class and identify potential avenues for future research.
MaterialDescription: List of research papers will be published on OLAT
FurtherInfoDescription:
The seminar is limited to 12 participants. This seminar is held by an ECON PhD student.

Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory.

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: https://www.econ.uzh.ch
/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool
https://studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the
regular module booking period for lectures.

Deadline for application: 01.09.2024 (24.00 pm).
CommonDescription:
Public economics studies the role of government in the economy. Many current policy debates revolve around the topics of redistribution, social insurance, and the provision of public goods. How can we measure inequality, and how has it evolved over past decades? What are the social benefits and costs of wealth taxation? How generous should unemployment insurance benefits be? And why should governments subsidize childcare?
In this seminar, we study how economists think through such questions. Drawing on recent research papers in the field of public economics, we explore the motivations, methods, and effects of government interventions in the economy.
The selected papers cover a range of topics and methodological approaches. The seminar is intended for Master-level students in economics.
AudienceDescription: The seminar is intended for Master-level students in economics.

Kick-off : Tuesday, 17.09.2024    18:00-18:30    Zoom
Introduction: Friday, 27.09.2024    09:00-12:00

Presentations 4-6: Friday, 11.10.2024    09:00-12:00    
Presentations 7-9: Friday, 18.10.2024    09:00-12:00    
Presentations 10-12: Friday, 25.10.2024    09:00-13:00    
Final paper deadline : Friday, 06.12.2024    23:59        by E-Mail

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Online exercises: 10%
Minimal product: 25%, of which:
-    Individual grade: 50%
-    Group outcome: 50% 


Advanced product: 25%, of which: 
-     Individual grade: 50%
-    Group outcome: 50% 


Group Project: 30%, final presentations on 12.12.2024  
Peer evaluation: 10%
PrerequisitesDescription: Students can choose to program in either R or Python.
PrecognitionDescription: Good programming knowledge in R or Python. Basic knowledge of machine learning.
ObjectiveDescription:
The seminar gives an overview of the fundamental steps needed to create a product prototype for a data science web application. Topics include getting familiar with the Google cloud computing platform, training machine learning algorithms, structuring a project, and running it on the cloud. Most services we discuss provide a high-level, user friendly (often graphical) interface.
Therefore, no previous knowledge of cloud infrastructure is required.
MaterialDescription: Slides, videos, and learning resources will be provided during the seminar.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of participants is limited to 12. To apply, please send your application via email to radu.tanase@business.uzh.ch with the subject "Application PDSP HS2024". The application should contain your CV, transcript of records, and a short letter of motivation. The application deadline is Wednesday, September 11, 2024, at 23:59 CEST. The application results will be communicated on Friday, September 13. Please note that students who have taken a previous variant of this course are not eligible to take the seminar again.

Conditional on good outcome, we intend to make the results accessible to the public via a publication and/or public access to the application and/or its code. Therefore, all accepted students will be required to sign a research agreement prior to the start of the seminar.
CommonDescription:
The main objective is to teach students how to transform their ideas and data science knowledge into a product prototype. During the seminar, the students will improve their programming skills in R or Python (at their choice), learn to apply machine learning techniques to a concrete problem, create a product prototype and run it on the cloud. All participants will receive free credits on the Google Cloud Platform (courtesy of a Google Educational Grant) that they can use to get familiar with the services and cover the cost of running their product prototype. 

This year we will explore the potential of large language models (LLMs) to advance knowledge in social and behavioural sciences. We will create the prototype of a research-focused application that allows researchers to construct a series of experiments, collect data by interacting with LLMs (e.g., via ChatGPT) and integrate the findings using machine learning algorithms.
AudienceDescription: MA students with good programming and machine learning knowledge, who are interested in research and in turning their ideas into a software product.
AppointmentsDescription:
19.09.2024, 16:15-20:00: Kick-Off meeting & Fundamentals of product prototyping.  
26.09.2024, 16:15-20:00: Running a product prototype on the cloud & Group project assignment.  
17.10.2024, 16:15-20:00: Status update.  
01.11.2024, 16:15-20:00 Minimum product: Individual meetings with the groups (the exact time will be set in agreement with the group members).
28.11.2024, 16:15-20:00: Advanced product: Individual meetings with the groups (the exact time will be set in agreement with the group members).
12.12.2024, 16:15-20h: Final presentations of the group project.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
PrerequisitesDescription: Bachelor Degree
CommonDescription:
We believe in applying mathematical knowledge with success in the world of finance and our purpose is to help students with a quantitative background to build an outstanding career.
Our dreams are achieved when we complement our knowledge with the trust of the people around us. During this class you will strengthen the soft skills needed to succeed as a quant in the world of finance. You will also get familiar with the technical tools needed to apply such skills in a working environment.
Organizations are growing larger and becoming more diverse. Inspirational storytelling is essential to assure the cooperation of people towards a common goal. For example, a successful quant needs to simultaneously convince a scientific audience of the model's soundness and a business audience of it practical benefits. In this class you will develop the storytelling skills needed to present complex information to diverse audiences in an inspiring way.
The management level is always looking for ways to take decisions faster and smarter. Arguments based on data are very persuasive and a well-chosen visualization transmits complex information in a fast and efficient way. You will learn how to build clear arguments based on data, how to design compelling visualizations and how to consolidate trust as a presenter.
The background of the module is rooted in real life examples from the banking industry regarding the implementation of regulatory models in the business decision process. In this working environment, you will use the most established tools for data visualization and understand their strengths and limitations.
In our opinion, the skills and practical know-how accumulated during this class will contribute to a successful career, independent of the organization you will choose to work for in the future.

SmText: Introduction to Measure Theory and Lebesgue Integration (L)
PrecognitionDescription: All the usual topics in a first course in Real Analysis, notably including basic point-set topology concepts, e.g., sequential and topological compactness, and metric spaces.
ObjectiveDescription: The student will obtain a solid introductory understanding of Lebesgue measure (not abstract measure) and the univariate Lebesgue integral. The goal is to prepare for a second course, in which abstract measure theory, as required for probability theory, is covered, along with L^p spaces.
MaterialDescription: The precise textbook(s) will be decided later. A good idea of the course contents can be obtained from inspecting the first four chapters of Christopher Heil's recent book Introduction to Real Analysis.
CommonDescription:
We will begin with a fast review of essential concepts from real analysis, such as compactness and complete metric spaces. Then we cover the standard order of topics, e.g., outer measure, countable subadditivity and the other usual properties of outer measure; then Lebesgue and Borel measure, measurable functions, and the univariate Lebesgue integral, and its major properties,
e.g., the monotone convergence theorem and the dominated convergence theorem.
AudienceDescription: The course is open and encouraged to well-prepared masters students in the regular Banking and Finance program, as well as Data Science and Economics.
Events_1_EStext: Introduction to Measure Theory and Lebesgue Integration (L)
