SmText: Managing Geopolitical Risks in International Business (S)
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of participants is limited. Please send your application including a short CV to Dorothee Winkler (dorothee.winkler@business.uzh.ch) latest by August
25th, 2024.
CommonDescription:
Today, businesses act in various highly volatile, polarized and often unstable contexts,
where they need to be aware of global issues and ethical considerations.
Business decision making thus regularly involves entrepreneurs and managers having
to be aware of, and find solutions for geopolitical risks, in order to maintain business
operations in a responsible manner. Similarly, analysts and consultants have to assess the geopolitical risks that business have when conducting in such contexts.
Understanding and thus managing geopolitical risks globally thus becomes an important task for managing business responsibly.

This course introduces master students to a variety of topics related to managing
geopolitical risks. The course aims at providing students with an overview of potential
opportunities, but also the geopolitical risks that emerge from conducting business in
polarized, unstable or weak political contexts. It further aims to sensitize students for the ethical considerations of conducting businesses in the context of dictatorships, failed states, or highly polarized contexts.
Events_1_EStext: Managing Geopolitical Risks in International Business (S)

SmText: Economics of Child and Youth Development (S)
PrecognitionDescription: You should have solid knowledge of undergraduate-level microeconomics and statistics/econometrics.
ObjectiveDescription: At the end of the course, students will be familiar with core topics of the economics of education literature.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The course has two parts. The first part (1st quarter, weeks 1-7) is a lecture-based introduction to the field. In the second part (weeks
8-14), students present current papers from the literature in class.

Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory. The seminar will not be recorded/no podcast.

The seminar is limited to 24 participants.

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

IMPORTANT: When applying, please upload your current transcript of records and an overview of your spring 24 grades.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.econ.uzh.ch/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html

Application for this seminar is via the module booking tool studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the regular module booking period for lectures.
CommonDescription: This seminar offers an overview of child and youth development literature, emphasizing the impact of peers, parents, and teachers. It will shed light on the causal factors influencing the development of young individuals' capabilities. With a strong policy orientation, this course examines how academic research provides guidance on enhancing the structure of educational systems. The focus is primarily on developed economies. Among the research topics discussed in this course are: The significance of parental influence on life success, the effects of early educational environments on future earnings, the long-term effects of early childhood interventions, the measurable impact of teachers on students' future career paths, how the personalities of peers influence academic achievement at the university level, and optimal strategies for allocating teachers and students to classes for improved outcomes for all.
AudienceDescription: This economics of education seminar is designed for advanced Master students.
Events_1_EStext: Economics of Child and Youth Development (S)

SmText: Financial and Managerial Accounting Bootcamp for Master's Students (L)
ObjectiveDescription:
After successfully completing the course, you should be equipped with the fundamental accounting knowledge needed for managing a company.
Additionally, you will be ready to take more advanced classes that require accounting knowledge as a prerequisite.
FurtherInfoDescription: The course is divided into two parts. In the first part, we focus on financial reporting, starting with how the financial system is set up in a company and how financial statements are prepared and analyzed. In the second part, we concentrate on managerial accounting topics, such as cost analysis and management, budgeting, and performance evaluation. The course will take place on site with podcasts available.
CommonDescription: Master's students enter the program with varying levels of background know in accounting. This course offers an opportunity for those lacking a sufficient accounting foundation, or those who feel their accounting skills have become rusty, to catch up through intensive training.
Events_1_EStext: Financial and Managerial Accounting Bootcamp for Master's Students (L)

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
1. Participation (60%)
  2. Written assignments (40%)
SmText: Contemporary Readings on Behavior in Organizations (S) HS24
ObjectiveDescription:
Participants learn how to

  1. Critically evaluate on-going research
  2. Provide constructive feedback to peers and scholars, and suggest solutions for identified problems
  3. Review academic work and help improve it
  4. Expand knowledge on behavioral research in organizations
MaterialDescription: Readings will be assigned in class.
FurtherInfoDescription: Participation in this seminar is limited. Please apply for this seminar via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad/ including one PDF with the following parts: (a) a one paragraph statement of your research interests (b) your CV, and (c) an indication of whether you wish to contribute a working paper of your own to our reading list (if so, please submit a draft of the paper if it is available).
CommonDescription:
Participants will read, review, and discuss working papers to improve their ability to critically and constructively engage in the scientific writing process. The working papers can range from a first rough draft to papers at an advanced stage in the revise+resubmit process. The working papers will come from the participants, auditors and guests of the seminar themselves, and so students are encouraged to contribute a working paper of their own to our reading list. The seminar relies exclusively on the written word for input - there are no presentations.
Thus, participants will read and review papers, and are expected to base their discussions solely on what they have read. The author of the paper is in the role of the listener and has the chance to benefit from the feedback. The purpose of this seminar is not to find all the problems in a working paper, but instead to develop ideas on how the problems could be fixed and the paper be improved as a whole to heighten its chances in the publication process.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Class participation and written report/paper
PrecognitionDescription: Microeconomics for Research Students
FurtherInfoDescription: Venue: BLU-008
CommonDescription:
Market Design is an elective PhD course and is also open to motivated Master&ap students.
We will discuss topics in market
design, matching, and boundedly-rational mechanism design. The course will give you a sense of this rich area, but it will not be a complete survey. We will focus on some background papers and selected parts of the current research frontier. My aim is to make the class research oriented: we will talk in class about research ideas. In particular, I intend to go through papers in a selective fashion trying to understand what is in a paper, where it comes from, and where it might lead. While there will be lecture elements, we will also spend time jointly looking at questions.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Research proposal and presentation
SmText: Current Topics in Management and Business Ethics (S) HS24
MaterialDescription: The syllabus with information on required course materials will be provided for download on the website of the chair of Prof. Andreas Scherer, section "Teaching" before the seminar starts.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This is a block seminar. It takes place on four full days in September 2024:
10.-13.09.2024. The lecturer is Prof. Dr. Christopher Wickert, VU Amsterdam.

The number of participants is limited. Please send your application including a short CV to David Sieber (david.sieber@business.uzh.ch) latest by July
15, 2024.

For further details please refer to the homepage of Prof. Scherer: www.business.uzh.ch/de/professorships/as/teaching/overview.html
CommonDescription:
This doctoral seminar examines research in the fields of management and business ethics. It emphasizes the ethical, professional, social, and legal responsibilities of managers and leaders, especially as they relate to an organization's stakeholders, the media, and the role of business in societ Special attention is given to ethical aspects of the relationship between an organization and its stakeholders. Topics of interest include corporate governance, corporate social responsibility, corporate corruption, strategic and ethical decision making, the role of heuristics and biases, regulation, activism, corporate political activity, crisis management, reputation management, stakeholder management, social entrepreneurship, rhetoric and discourse, and the roles of traditional and social media.
There are five primary objectives of this course:

  1. Introduce the students to the relevant literature in management and business ethics.
  2. Help students understand, evaluate, and interpret the conceptual and methodological aspects of research in management and business ethics.
  3. Develop skills necessary to publish in and review for top-tier journals in the fields of management and business ethics.
  4. Expose students to content analysis and related methodologies.
  5. Provide feedback to students' work in-progress.
AppointmentsDescription:
This is a block seminar. It takes place on four full days in September 2024:
10.-13.09.2024.

The number of participants is limited. Please send your application including a short CV to David Sieber(david.sieber@business.uzh.ch) latest by July
15, 2024.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Written assesment (essay or update of research paper).
SmText: Reading, Doing, and Writing Qualitative Work in Management and Organization Studies HS24
ObjectiveDescription: At the end of the seminar, you should be able to: 1. Collect, analyze and/or theorize qualitative material 2. Have an idea as to how to write qualitative studies to meet international standards 3. Think critically about theories, methods and phenomena 4. Talk about your research
MaterialDescription: Will be provided upon accpetance to the seminar.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Places in the seminar are limited. In order to be admitted to participate in this seminar, please send an application to Kalliopi Vagias (by email to om@business.uzh.ch) which should include (1) a motivation letter, (2) your CV and (3) transcripts of your grades.
Deadline for applications to be received: August 31st, 2024.

Lecturer: Prof. Jennifer Howard-Grenville (Cambridge)
CommonDescription:
At a general level, this seminar is intended for doctoral students who want to improve their skills at theorizing and writing qualitative studies. It provides a unique platform for doctoral students to engage with the methodological, epistemological and practical issues they face when conducting qualitative studies. The content of this seminar evolves with the expert who is invited. For further information please visit our website:
www.business.uzh.ch/en/research/professorships/om/teaching.html

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The assessment is based on the following:

• 30% Response paper

• 20% Peer feedback

• 10% Self-evaluation of the response paper

• 20% Discussion plan 

• 10% Discussion moderation

• 10% Discussion participation
ObjectiveDescription:
At the end of this course, students should be able to:

  1. explain the Sustainable Development Goals, their importance, and their com-plexity
  2. understand tensions and potential syn-ergies across multiple Sustainable De-velopment Goals
  3. strategically read, and analyze argu-ments in research papers
  4. retrieve, identify, and assess related re-search literature
  5. formulate sound and valid arguments in written form
  6. provide constructive feedback on writ-ten report
  7. prepare and orally present and discuss scientific work
  8. moderate oral academic discussions
MaterialDescription:
The Sustainable Development Goals Report of the current year (e.g., unstats.un.org/sdgs/report/2023/)

Research articles will be announced in the first meeting.

All reading materials will be available on OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription:
For this course, you will be asked to read re-search papers, actively participate in the online and in-class discussions, write research motiva-tion statements, and give an oral presentation.

This course is held on-site, and the complete attendance of all slots-except of extenuating circumstances-is required to pass the course.


The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription:
This seminar will explore connections between research topics in Computer Science and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) defined by the United Nations. Students will learn about SDG, how computing helps or hinder progresses towards some of the SDG, and what connections remain under-explored.
The course materials will consist of research papers and a set of reference book chapters in the field of Computer Science as well as in adjacent fields.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Course evaluation will have three main components:

- Two assignments, to be completed within two weeks after each lecture block
o First assignment based on the first lecture block (a longer one) (15%)
o Second assignment based on the last lecture block (a shorter one) (10%)

- Either a coding project or a review of a revenue management or pricing journal article (25%)
List of suitable articles for a review will be provided. The review (3-4 pages) will need to explain the gist of the problem considered and provide reviewer's opinion about its relevance. This work is due within two weeks after the last lecture block, but an even earlier submission is encouraged.

Examples of what a project could look like:
o Write a program implementing a single-leg optimization method
o Write a program applying principles of dynamic programming to solve a problem
o Write a program that estimates or optimizes a simple offer set problem

- A midterm and final exam, both written, use of Excel tools provided in the course is allowed:
o Midterm (25%): Thursday, 12.09.2024: 11:15-12:15 pm (60min)
o Final (25%): Saturday, 23.11.2024: 11:15-12:15 pm (60min)

 If a student is officially excused on the day of the midterm or of the final exam, arrangements will be tried to take the exam within the following three days. If that is not possible, please contact Darius Walczak (dariusmarian.walczak@uzh.ch) to arrange another time for a remote oral exam that will be held within two weeks after the last lecture block ends.
PrerequisitesDescription: The course is self-contained and students should be able to fill in gaps from the references provided in the course, if necessary.
PrecognitionDescription: Advanced calculus, basic probability theory, familiarity with basic optimization concepts as well as basic statistics.
ObjectiveDescription:
In the course we will focus first on the basics of RM including concepts and overview of the most popular fields of applications. Then we will explore the science behind most popular techniques used there. Therefore, a level of quantitative background will be required (OR, STEM). Next, we will focus on dynamic pricing, where firms seek to find the best price to offer a client when capacity constraints may not be relevant.

The students should gain understanding of the three main aspects of the subject matter:

  • Time dynamics (customer demand comes over time and present decisions affect what can be done in the future) and, therefore, why it may make sense to reject a request for a discount ticket that comes earlier
  • Network effects (products using different resource bundles affect each other) and why it may make sense to reject request for a multi-flight itinerary in favor of multiple single-flight requests arriving later (and vice-versa)
  • Price-sensitivity and the basics of customer choice: how price sensitivity affects what customers will buy and, more generally, how a product purchase decision depends on what other products are in the offer.
MaterialDescription:
The course is self-contained but references to several textbooks available (in English) on the subject will be provided, as well as copies of journal articles for additional reading, as needed. Below is a short list of textbooks and a book chapter that are relevant:

  • Chapter by A. Boyd et al. in C. Barnhart & B. Smith, 'Quantitative Solving Methods in
    the Airline Industry' (www.springer.com/us/book/9781461416074).
  • R. Phillips, 'Pricing and Revenue Optimization,' Stanford 2005.
  • Talluri & van Ryzin, 'The Theory and Practice of Revenue Management 2004.
  • G. Gallego, H. Topaloglu, 'Revenue Management and Pricing Analytics,' Springer 2019.
CommonDescription:
Ever wondered why airfares change? Why a person in the seat next to yours got a better deal or perhaps why you were able to fly to your desired destination for pennies? And, why airlines often ask whether you are willing to take another flight in exchange for a voucher?

The above are just one sort of examples where prices for travel services seem to change for reasons that are not immediately clear. People have been intrigued about these practices and with the advent of the already ubiquitous e-commerce prices that change dynamically are part of everyday life. Revenue management ('RM') and dynamic pricing are the science engines that power that dynamic.

The course will explain the main concepts of revenue management and dynamic pricing - the practice of finding a scientifically sound answer to the question of what product a firm should offer to a customer at any given time, given capacity constraints and, possibly, some other information. This problem has often been paraphrased as 'selling the right product to the right customer at the right price'and became acute in thin-margin industries such as airlines (after deregulation in the 70's), where even a small improvement in revenue implies a major improvement in profit. Other industries with similar features, e.g., hotels, cruise lines, and car rental companies, followed shortly and also continue to use the revenue management and pricing techniques.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The students are graded on the project which they develop during the block course. The students must hand-in a report summarizing the developed system within a week after the course ends. Deadline 16 September 2024.

Criteria:

  • 50% performance of the developed system
  • 50% report
PrerequisitesDescription:
Due to the challenging nature of this seminar, interested students should send their transcripts via e-mail to Leonard Bauersfeld and Angel Romero (bauersfeld@ifi.uzh.ch,roagui@ifi.uzh.ch) such that we can ensure that all prerequisites are met and the students have sufficient background knowledge to pass the course. We will reply on a rolling basis until August 27 with a decision if the prerequisites are met in case of an allocation to this seminar. In general, we expect a strong background in machine learning and computer vision.
Students must have attended the lecture on UZH - Vision Algorithms for Mobile Robotics (or similar courses, e.g. ETH - Computer Vision or ETH
- Image Analysis and Computer Vision). Furthermore, for the background in machine learning should have at least attended UZH Advanced Topics in Artificial Intelligence (or similar). Finally, students must be comfortable programming in C++ or Python and working in a Linux-based software environment and should be familiar with a Linux shell.
PrecognitionDescription: Python or C++ programming skills are re-quired (depending on which task a group chooses).
ObjectiveDescription:
The students get hands-on experience working on drones and learn

  • apply machine-learning techniques to physical robots
  • plan, conduct and analyze real-world experiments to verify the performance of the developed system
  • collaboratively work on a larger soft-ware project
FurtherInfoDescription:
The practical project will be done in groups of up to 5 students. The project consists of two parts, and a group can choose to work on either part. One part revolves around getting a reliable drone detection pipeline from monocular images and the other part is concerned with developing a tracking controller via reinforcement learning.

Most parts of the course will be taking place at the drone test facility of the Robotics and Perception Group in Winterthur.

***************************************************************

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

***************************************************************

Due to the challenging nature of this seminar, interested students should send their transcripts via e-mail to Leonard Bauersfeld and Angel Romero (bauersfeld@ifi.uzh.ch,roagui@ifi.uzh.ch) such that we can ensure that all prerequisites are met and the students have sufficient background knowledge to pass the course. We will reply on a rolling basis until August 27 with a decision if the prerequisites are met in case of an allocation to this seminar. In general, we expect a strong background in machine learning and computer vision.
Students must have attended the lecture on UZH - Vision Algorithms for Mobile Robotics (or similar courses, e.g. ETH - Computer Vision or ETH
- Image Analysis and Computer Vision). Furthermore, for the background in machine learning should have at least attended UZH Advanced Topics in Artificial Intelligence (or similar). Finally, students must be comfortable programming in C++ or Python and working in a Linux-based software environment and should be familiar with a Linux shell.
CommonDescription:
Autonomous drones are ubiquitous across different industries, from inspection and mapping to search and rescue applications. In those scenarios, vision-based autonomy is vital as a drone must be able to perceive and react to its environment. This task is very challenging because the real world is inherent-ly unpredictable and difficult to capture in mathematical models.
Combined with the strict real-time requirements when controlling a drone, these requirements make deep-learning solutions the ideal choice for percep-tion and control. In this course, the students will get hands-on experience in autonomous vision-based flight. We consider a Holly-wood-inspired setting where a camera drone needs to track an "actor drone." The students will design a perception module to detect and track other drones and train a reinforcement learning (RL) controller to track the actor drone. The developed pipeline will be de-ployed in the real world on physical hard-ware.
For the control task, the students will be pro-vided with an RL environment in which they can integrate their controllers. Similarly, the students will have a software framework to integrate their work into the perception mod-ule. For the final deployment, drones will be provided so that students can focus primarily on their algorithms.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Presentation: 30%
Discussion & Participation: 20% Final paper: 50 %
SmText: Recent Developments in Empirical Economics of Crime (S)
PrecognitionDescription:
Sound knowledge of empirical and experimental methods. Students should have
visited courses covering methods of causal analysis and econometrics
ObjectiveDescription:
Students will gain insights into the economic approaches and methods employed to study questions related to the crime and criminal justice policies.
Furthermore, this seminar provides a platform for students to present economic papers, engage in critical discussions, and identify the limitations of existing studies and potential avenues for further research.
MaterialDescription: Selection of recent publications or working papers will be uploaded to OLAT
FurtherInfoDescription:
The seminar is limited to 18 participants (by application only).

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies.
Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

Please follow the instructions on our web-site: www.econ.uzh.ch/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad


Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the regular module booking period for lectures.

Kick Off Meeting, Wednesday 18.9.2024 10:00-11:30 (online)

Group presentation session 1: Tuesday 5.11.2024, 09:00-12:00 (in person) SOF-E-09

Group presentation session 2: Thursday 7.11.2024, 09:00-12:00 (in person) SOF-E-09

Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory.
CommonDescription: In this seminar, we study recent developments in the empirical economics of crime literature, recognizing its significance within society and its implications for policy-making. While the existing empirical literature largely relies on correlational patterns, recent studies have increasingly focused on establishing causal relationships through innovative methodologies such as natural experiments and randomized controlled trials. Through discussions of recent empirical papers, our course examines pertinent issues, including the effectiveness of criminal justice policies, such as incarceration and rehabilitation programs, and strategies for preventing criminal behavior. By applying economic methods to understand crime and its associated policies, this seminar aims to advance our understanding of this complex societal phenomenon.
AudienceDescription: Advanced MA students with a background in econometrics and causal analysis and interested in topics related to crime

TestsDescription:
Die Leistungsnachweise zum Modul bestehen aus einer schriftlichen Prüfung (Klausur) (60% der Gesamtnote) und zwei kurzen philosophischen Aufsätzen, welche als Vorbereitung auf die Prüfung dienen (je 20% der Gesamtnote).
Die Themen der Aufsätze werden zu Anfang des Semesters vergeben und sind im Semesterverlauf zu bearbeiten und schriftlich einzureichen. Die schriftliche Prüfung (Klausur) findet am 6.01.2025,14:00-16:00 Uhr (Prüfungsdauer 90 min) vor Ort statt.
SmText: Wissenschaftstheorie und Wissenschaftsethik (V) (Philosophy and Ethics of Science)
ObjectiveDescription: Siehe: www.business.uzh.ch/professorships/as.html
MaterialDescription: Siehe: www.business.uzh.ch/professorships/as.html
CommonDescription: Die Vorlesung führt Studierende in die zentralen philosophischen Debatten der Managementwissenschaften ein. Welche Realität untersuchen wir und gibt es nur eine davon? Was ist ein Unternehmen eigentlich und wie erforscht man es? Müssen Wirtschaftswissenschaftler und Wirtschaftswissenschaftlerinnen politisch neutral sein oder ist Forschung immer politisch? Wann wird die Nähe zur Privatwirtschaft problematisch? Um diese und weitere Fragen anzugehen, lernen Teilnehmende unterschiedliche wissenschaftstheoretische und wissenschaftsethische Positionen kennen. Für weitere Hinweise siehe: www.business.uzh.ch/professorships/as.html

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The following components comprise the final grade:

  1. Programming project I (25%): on-site, computer-based, BYOD format, bring a charger.
  2. Programming project II (25%): on-site, computer-based, BYOD format, bring a charger.
  3. Programming project III (20%): online
  4. Final multiple-choice exam on 22.01.2025 (30%): on-site, written examination, multiple choice format.

All assessments except the final exam (either on-site or online) are computer-based. Please make sure you have all necessary equipment.

Absence Policy for Programming Project I and II:

In the event that a student is unable to participate in either of the on-site programming projects (Programming Project I or Programming Project II) due to a valid medical reason, the student must promptly submit a doctor's certificate to the instructor (within one week of the missed assessment).

With a valid doctor's certificate, students are thus permitted to miss a maximum of one (out of the two) on-site programming projects. An on-site programming project missed under these circumstances will not be factored into the final grade calculation. Consequently, only the on-site programming project taken will contribute to the final grade. If any further programming project is missed, this will be graded as "1".

Failure to provide the necessary documentation within the stipulated one-week period will result in the missed assessment being graded with a "1" and counting towards the final course grade.

This policy does not apply to Programming Project III and the Final Exam.
SmText: Introduction to programming for Marketing Analytics (R or Python) (S)
ObjectiveDescription: Understanding fundamental programming concepts that are essential for most real- world marketing analytics applications. These include loading external data (from csv files); manipulating data (merging, aggregating, and selecting observations), simplifying complex and repetitive tasks (writing loops and conditional statements) and automating code (writing functions).
MaterialDescription: All materials will be made available on OLAT.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This module is part of a pilot project for a series of hybrid courses addressing fundamental concepts in data science.

We would like to invite students who participate to provide us detailed feedback. This will help us understand how the concept is received and what are important areas for improvement.

The number of participants is limited to 65 students. To apply, please send an email to mingmin.feng@business.uzh.ch with the subject "Application Programming Intro HS 2024". It is enough if the email contains just a brief sentence expressing your intention to participate.
Places will be allocated on a first come first served basis.

The application deadline is Friday, September 6th, 2024 at 23:59 CEST. The application results will be communicated on Friday, September 13th.

Students who have taken either Python - A non-technical introduction with applications to Marketing (MO0076) or Introduction to R for Marketing Analytics (MO0207) are not permitted to book the current module.
CommonDescription: The module is designed to equip students with the fundamental programming skills needed to collect, clean, and organize data. We use a non-technical approach to deliver the content. We start every unit with "real-world" questions and explain key programming concepts "on the way" while discussing the solutions to these questions. Students will be offered the possibility to choose between learning to program in R or Python. The content of the lectures, exercises and evaluations will be very similar in both cases. We do not require any programming experience as we start from the very beginning. However, we do require the willingness to actively participate and contribute to the class.
AudienceDescription: Master level students with no previous experience with coding.
AppointmentsDescription:
18.09.2024, 14:00-16:00h: Kick-Off (mandatory, on-site, room TBA)

19.09.2024 - 22.10.2024: Learn the fundamentals of programming for marketing analytics I (online, asynchronous)

23.10.2024, 14:00-18:00h: Programming project I (mandatory, on-site, room TBA)

24.10.2024 - 03.12.2024: Learn the fundamentals of programming for marketing analytics II (online, asynchronous)

04.12.2024, 14:00-18:00h: Programming project II (mandatory, on-site, room TBA)


05.12.2024 - 20.12.2024: Programming project III (online)

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Seminar presentation (50%)
Short paper (25%)
Participation in discussion (25%)

Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory.
PrerequisitesDescription: Solid knowledge in microeconomics and statistics at the master level. Basic knowledge in environmental economics (at the Bachelor level)
ObjectiveDescription: The participants should be able to develop the skills to understand, present and critically discuss research work in environmental economics.
MaterialDescription: Papers will be provided closer to the beginning of the course.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The seminar is limited to 24 participants.

Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory.

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.econ.uzh.ch/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html

Application for this seminar is via the module booking tool studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the regular module booking period for lectures.

Important: When applying, please upload a recent transcript of records and/or proof of successful completion of an Environmental Economics course on BA level. If there are more applicants than places, students who have successfully completed a BA course in Environmental Economics will be assigned preferentially.

More detailed information on the seminar can be found in the syllabus on OLAT: lms.uzh.ch/url/RepositoryEntry/17550738194
CommonDescription: The seminar deals with recent research papers in environmental economics. The relation between policy, innovation and the environment will receive particular attention
AudienceDescription: MA students in economics and related fields

September 19, 14.00-15.30

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Mid-term (50%), Group presentation, 31.10.2024 (in class 10:15 - 12:00), open book, group grading, development of firm theory (re-examination in the following week in case of justified absence)

Final exam (50%), Individual essay take home, max. 5 page, submission by
10.01.2025, open book, empirical tests for the developed firm theory
ObjectiveDescription:
Understand how to develop rigorous firm theories via specifying constructs, relationships, and boundary conditions.
Understand how to translate firm theories into testable hypotheses. Know how to implement experiments and related methodologies to evaluate and verify these hypotheses or overarching firm theories.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The seminar is limited to 20 participants.

Students need to submit their transcripts (Bachelor's and Master's level) showing all the courses taken and grades obtained prior to this course. 

 Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool :studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription:
In this course, we delve into recent advancements in strategy, employing a scientific approach to formulate and validate firm strategies. Using the 'theory-based view,' we perceive strategy as a tailored plan comprising hypotheses about a firm's resources, activities, competitive position, and means to attain superior returns. The latter part of the course focuses on utilizing empirical methods like experiments to refine and test these theories.
With the abundance of data in business, such methods offer robust evidence on strategy effectiveness. This scientific approach is gaining traction, particularly in tech-focused firms, reflecting the evolving nature of strategy as a more precise and evidence-driven discipline.
AudienceDescription: Master students with a basic understanding of the domain of strategy and who want to learn more about the latest advances in the field (incl. the use of experiments or scientific methods to solve strategy questions).

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Assessment will rely on a graded presentation on a specific topic on dates to be individually agreed with the students.
PrecognitionDescription: Though not strictly necessary, familiarity with discrete-time models as well as with some measure theoretic probability theory will be useful.
ObjectiveDescription: The student will gain a working knowledge of the principles of Stochastic Finance. This should put the student in a position to understand finance literature using continuous-time models.
MaterialDescription: Slides will be provided. A literature list will be provided in due time.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Further dates in November, taught in a blocked mode by Prof. Cosimo Munari (Verona University), will be announced as soon as possible.

Thursday 31 Oktober 09:00-12:00 (Room: PLM F-103/104) Thuesday 5 November 14:00-17:00 (Room: KOL-F-104) Thursday 7 November 09:00-12:00 (Room: PLM F-103/104)
CommonDescription: This course is an introduction to continuous time models. We will focus on markets with a finite time horizon and a finite number of traded securities.Uncertainty will be driven by Brownian motion. Next to the classical arbitrage pricing topics (Fundamental Theorems of Asset Pricing, completeness, etc), we intend to cover other selected topics such as dynamic program-ming with applications to finance.
AudienceDescription: PhD candidates in Finance and related disciplines

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Oral presentation (40%) and written report (40%). Participation and discussion (20%)
PrecognitionDescription: Basic knowledge of econometrics and time series analysis is an advantage but not essential.
ObjectiveDescription: This course aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of macroeconomic forecasting methods and the exploration of a variety of applications of practical forecasting problems. It will also help to refine skills in presenting data and reporting the results of forecasts to superiors.
MaterialDescription: Will be provided via OLAT
FurtherInfoDescription:
The seminar is limited to 20 participants.
Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory.

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies.
Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.
More information on the process can be found on our website: www.econ.uzh.ch/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html


Application for this seminar is via the module booking tool studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the regular module booking period for lectures.
CommonDescription:
In this seminar we will explore the methods, tools and challenges involved in forecasting the future path of macroeconomic variables.
Participants will gain an insight into the key economic indicators, statistical models and data analysis techniques used by professional forecasters. We will review key time series techniques and discuss common challenges in macroeconomic forecasting. We will then introduce univariate and multivariate forecasting models and consider various issues such as forecasting evaluation and combination. We will also cover variable selection, hierarchical forecasting and trend cycle decomposition. All topics will be illustrated with real-world empirical applications.
AppointmentsDescription:
• Kick Off Meeting: online via Zoom Friday, 20.9.2024: 4.00-4.30 pm
  • Introductory Lecture: Friday, 4.10.2024: 8.15-12.00 am (SOF-E-09)
  • Student Presentations: Tuesday, 19.11.2024: 8.15-12 am (SOF-E-09) and Thursday 21.11.2024: 8.15-12 am (SOF-E-09)
  • Deadline for report, 15.01.2025

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
• Group paper presentation (30%)
  • Group research proposal (30%)
  • Feedback on other research proposal (20%)
  • Class participation (20%)
PrerequisitesDescription: Completed BA degree in Business Administration, Finance or Economics.
ObjectiveDescription:
By the end of this seminar, participants will be able to:

  • Understand the economics of ESG Reporting comprehensively
  • Evaluate potential solutions for sustainable growth
  • Think ahead and contribute to the existing body of research on ESG reporting
MaterialDescription: Slides introductory lecture; list of references from the syllabus. See www.business.uzh.ch/macc
FurtherInfoDescription:
Participation is limited to a total number of 25 students. Interested students can apply for participation using the application form to be found on the webpage of the chair until Sunday, August 18, 2024. The allocation of seminar places will be finalized until September 10, 2024.
Applications via email are not accepted. Please note that the module can only be booked after the allocation of seminar place! Accepted applicants must book the module immediately after the seminar place has been confirmed!
CommonDescription:
This seminar provides a deep dive into the current landscape of ESG reporting, unraveling the complexities of integrating sustainability into the core of business strategies. We will explore the challenges and opportunities presented by ESG reporting, delve into the implications for management compensation, financing, and supply chain operations, and examine forward-looking solutions for carbon accounting and leakage mitigation.
Through a mix of state-of-the-art theoretical frameworks, empirical studies, literature reviews, and opinion pieces, you will gain a multidimensional understanding of how ESG considerations are transforming the economic and business landscapes.
AppointmentsDescription:
On Wednesday, September 18, 2024, there will be an introductory lecture that provides an overview of academic research and current topics in ESG reporting. Presentations of research papers will be scheduled on October
4. Presentations of research proposals with feedback will be held on November 8.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: The grade will be determined by group presentations (100%). The grade consists of preparations + slides (50%) and presentation + Q&A (50%)
PrerequisitesDescription: Bachelor's degree in economics, business administration or in banking and finance
PrecognitionDescription: This seminar is for Master students.
ObjectiveDescription:
1. Students have a good understanding of how various levels of government affect real estate markets and in particular prices and rents.
  2. Students can explain how demand and supply interact in land and real property markets to determine prices and how, why, and when property price cycles (and 'bubbles') emerge.
  3. Students have a good understanding of the determinants of homeownership and of the welfare implications associated with homeownership (financing) subsidies.
  4. Students can apply theoretical concepts and build on empirical evidence to discuss how specific policy interventions including land use regulations may affect land and real property markets.
MaterialDescription:
A topic-specific reading list of journal articles will be provided.
Students are additionally expected to conduct online investigations and data collections to inform their group presentations.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The number of participants is limited.
For details on the application process, visit: www.df.uzh.ch/en/studies/lectures/seminars.html.
The seminar will take place from September 9 to 13, 2024.
CommonDescription: The course aims to provide students with a theoretical and empirical understanding of the functioning of real estate markets with a particular focus on the price determination in land and real property markets. Topics covered include: Housing demand and supply; the role of the government in real estate markets; the economic impact of land and housing market regulations (land use planning) on housing market outcomes; estimating supply and demand price elasticities, real estate cycles; the role of credit conditions; price vs. rent dynamics; commercial vs. residential real estate cycles, determinants of homeownership; externalities of homeownership; policy evaluation of mortgage subsidies.
AudienceDescription: Master students interested in Real Estate Economics.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Students are expected to give individual presentations on selected papers as well as to prepare an individual research proposal on a topic related to the course.
SmText: Doctoral Colloquium in Corporate Finance II (S) HS24
PrerequisitesDescription: Attended "Corporate Finance (L)" (DFOEC007).
ObjectiveDescription: The objective of this course is to develop and to strengthen our ability to conduct high quality research.
FurtherInfoDescription:
This course takes place onsite. PhD Students of the chair have priority.
Information and Registration for participants with: secretariat.nyborg@bf.uzh.ch.
Deadline for registration: September 9, 2024
CommonDescription:
This seminar will focus on the role of money and central banks in financial markets. There is growing recognition that central banks play an important role in financial markets and the financial system, not only in terms of setting short term interest rates, but also derived from the role of central bank money (reserves, liquidity). The overall objective of this course is to enhance students' understanding of this emerging topic and to stimulate to research. To that end, we will study papers that shed light on the role of money in the financial system, the functioning of the market for liquidity, how it interacts with the broader financial markets, and the impact of central bank policies, including collateral policy. Class sessions will focus on selected empirical and theoretical papers and also introduce relevant institutional material.
Students are expected to give individual presentations on selected papers as well as to prepare an individual research proposal on a topic related to the course.
AudienceDescription:
For Internal and other PhD students. PhD students of the chair have priority.
This seminar is also open to masters students who have taken the seminar "Monetary Policy and Financial Markets" in the fall.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
•    In person presentation of at least 10 minutes per person (60%)
  •    Written paper (40%)
PrecognitionDescription: Basics of informatics, information management, knowledge of process modeling
ObjectiveDescription:
•    Students are able to outline and describe the basics of innovative IT-supported business models, the key techniques for their creation and creativity techniques.
  •    Students are able to describe methods for evaluating business innovations and apply at least one evaluation method.
  •    Students are able to critically  analyze real-world scenarios.
  •    Students are able to develop and communicate their own problem-solving concepts for business innovations.
  •    Students are able to create simple prototypes.
  •    Students are able to exchange ideas on their own and others' solution concepts.
MaterialDescription: Slides, Script und list of literature
CommonDescription: This module shows how companies use information technology to drive digitalization and innovation. Students master essential frameworks for business modeling and innovation methods and apply these directly to real-life scenarios. The module concludes with a joint project in which students tackle an industry-relevant challenge and develop an original business concept from the idea to a presentable prototype.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Presentation: 30%
Discussion: 30 %
Research Proposal: 40 %
ObjectiveDescription: In this class students are introduced to some topics of Gender Economics, with a focus on Gender Norms. After a short introduction on gender inequality, this class covers some of the most well-known but also other more recent papers on gender norms, particularly in Development Economics. The class also focuses on the empirical strategies used in these papers to address specific research questions, which will help students to develop their own research proposal as part of the assignments. Students also learn how to summarize, present and critically assess academic papers.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The seminar is limited to 12 participants.

Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory.

This seminar is held by a PhD of the Department of Economics.

The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

Application for this seminar is via the module booking tool
https://studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the regular module booking period for lectures.

The seminar takes place at SOF-E-09.
CommonDescription: Gender discrepancies persist in many areas of society. While much research has focused on the economic determinants of observed gender gaps, this class will first analyze the role of gender norms and cultural barriers in women's educational attainment and labor market participation. Additionally, we will explore gender norms that influence many other aspects of women's lives, particularly in developing countries where harmful practices such as female genital cutting and child marriage remain prevalent. The course readings will primarily consist of empirical studies.
AppointmentsDescription:
Kick-Off (online): 18.9.24 2 pm

25.9.24: 9-12 am: introduction session
11./18./25.10.2024: 9-12 am

Deadline paper: 20.12.24

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
•    presentations (30%)
  •    projects (60%)
  •    participation (10%)
PrecognitionDescription: Programming experience (language agnostic), web scraping experience is helpful, knowledge of the scientific process is also helpful, a background in foundational statistics will be helpful.
ObjectiveDescription: This course will provide students with an understanding of and how to conduct algorithm auditing. This includes knowledge of digital experiment planning, conducting experiments, web scraping and digital system measurement, and statistical decision making of experimental outcomes.
MaterialDescription: Peer reviewed research articles and some shared programming syntax will be the primary learning materials.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.  

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.  

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription: Algorithms increasingly govern what we see and our access to opportunities. In this seminar we will explore this topic and learn ways to understand if specific systems are functioning fairly within society. You will learn how to audit societal facing algorithms with experimental approaches, then using statistics draw scientific conclusions.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Mid-term (30%) 5. November 2024, 8:00-10:00 Final written exam onsite on (70%) 14. January 2025, 16:00-18:00
PrerequisitesDescription:
• Proficiency in Python
  • Calculus, Linear Algebra: you should be comfortable taking derivatives and understanding matrix vector operations and notation.
  • Basic Probability and Statistics: You should know basics of probabilities, Gaussian distributions, mean, standard deviation, etc.
  • Foundations of Machine Learning
PrecognitionDescription: The lecture includes a mixture of calculus, analysis and statistics, so a good understanding of math is required. The exercise will use the Python programming language, which is content of AINF1166: Informatics I.
ObjectiveDescription:
By the end of the course, students will understand the key concepts of Reinforcement Learning (RL). Specifically, students will be able to:

  • Define the key features of RL that distinguishes it from the other fields in Machine Learning
  • Implement common RL algorithms in code.
  • Describe various criteria for analyzing RL algorithms and evaluate them based on metrics such as regret, sample complexity, computational complexity, empirical performance, and convergence, as assessed through assignments.
  • Formulate and solve sequential decision-making problems using relevant RL tools.
CommonDescription: This class offers a comprehensive introduction to the field of Reinforcement Learning (RL). Students will explore the core challenges and various approaches within RL. By the end of the course, students will be well-versed in the key concepts and techniques essential for mastering Reinforcement Learning.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: Class participation (50%) and contributions in written form (50%, see "general description")
PrerequisitesDescription:
Interest in economic theory

Admission by the instructor (for Master’s students only)
PrecognitionDescription: Microeconomics for Research Students II (or equivalent)
ObjectiveDescription:
1) Ability to indentify and select contributions from the existing literature that are related to the research question at hand;

2) As a result of 1, knowledge of the related literature; 

3) Ability to extract the relevant information from related contributions and to condense the information;

4) Ability to derive solutions to examples of a given theoretical model either by hand or using software;   

5) Ability to draft paragraphs in concise scientific style that summarize insights obtained as in 3 and 4 for a demanding and sceptical readership;

6) Ability and willingness to constructively discuss in class the related. literature, preliminary results, and the exposition of research findings
MaterialDescription: Journal articles, working papers, and monographs in economic theory, downloaded by the students from electronic libraries according to instructions provided
FurtherInfoDescription:
Venue: SOF-E-09
Except: 4-25 October: SOF-J-26
CommonDescription:
We will jointly prepare and submit a research paper in game theory (broadly understood). The probability of a successful publication depends on the motivation and capabilities of the participants. Typical tasks for the students are:

(i) literature search via google scholar

(ii) preparation of lines of input (e.g., drafting a sentence summarizing a related paper and clarifying its relationship to the research question)

(iii) solving examples (numerical, analytical,...) 

(iv) comments on intermediate versions of the paper

The research topic will be selected jointly in the first session, where the instructor will make at least one specific proposal.
AudienceDescription:
- motivated Ph.D. students
- excellent students at the Master's level (as an exception only).
Partof_1_ScText: Master of Arts UZH in Business and Economics (RVO22)
Partof_2_ScText: Master of Arts UZH in Business and Economics (RVO22)
Partof_3_ScText: Master of Arts UZH in Business and Economics (RVO22)
Partof_4_ScText: Doctorate Business and Economics (B, PVO13)

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
The final grade will be based on a weighted average of your performance in your
presentation (30%), your moderation of and participation in the discussions (20%),
and your seminar essay (4-5 pages, 50%).
SmText: Gender inequality and the labour market (S)
PrecognitionDescription: Knowledge of econometrics and in particular quasi-experimental methods approximately at the level of Empirical Methods
ObjectiveDescription: Students will familiarize themselves with the latest research in Gender Economics. Students will also learn about different empirical strategies used in this literature. In addition, students will sharpen their research skills by identifying methodological issues and potential avenues for future research.
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in Economics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.

More information on the process can be found on our website:
https://www.econ.uzh.ch/en/study/undergraduate/ma/seminar.html

Application for this seminar is via the module booking tool
https://studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad

Please be aware that the periods for booking and un-booking seminars differs from the
regular module booking period for lectures.

The seminar is limited to 12 participants.

Personal attendance at all sessions is compulsory.

The seminar is held by two PhD students from the Department of Economics.

The seminar takes place at SOF-E-09.
CommonDescription: This seminar focuses on differences between women and men in the labour market. Beginning with a descriptive examination of the evolution of gender gaps over time, we then turn to possible reasons for why gender gaps persist in the labour market today. We pay particular attention to the division of household labour, the “child penalty”, and the role of social norms. We will also examine discrimination against women and violence against women at work.
AppointmentsDescription:
Kick Off Meeting 18.9.2024:  9-10 am (online)

Introductory session: 2.10.2024 9-12 am

Presentations:
16./23./30.10./6.11.2024: 9-12 am

Deadline Paper: 30.11.2024

The seminar takes place at SOF-E-09.

TestsDescription: Gruppenseminararbeit und kurze Präsentation der Arbeit
ObjectiveDescription:
Während des Seminars sollen den Studierenden die folgenden Lernziele vermittelt werden. 

  •    Erarbeitung einer Übersicht über den Immobilienmarkt in der Schweiz, über die Immobilien als Anlagevehikel und über die Megatrends in der Immobilienbranche (CH und EU)
  •    Erlernen der Grundtechniken mittels einr geführten Case Study in den bereichen Deals und Transactions, Immobilienbewertung, buchhalterische und regulatorische Vorgaben bei der Prüfung und steuerlichen Aspekten in der Immobilienbranche

Die Studierenden wählen anschliessend ein vorgegebenes Thema im Zusammenang mit den obigen Themen für die Seminararbeit aus. Nach Abschluss der Seminararbeit soll diese kurz präsentiert werden.
MaterialDescription: Unterrichtsmaterialien werden durch den Veranstalter zur Verfügung gestellt.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Die Veranstaltung findet vor Ort bei PwC in Oerlikon statt. 

Die Bewerbung ist ab Oktober möglich, weitere Informationen werden auf der Website des Instituts für Finance publiziert.

Marc Rüttimann und weitere Mitarbeiter von PwC
CommonDescription:
Das Seminar soll den Studierenden eine Übersicht über die Anlageklasse Immobilien in der Schweiz bieten. Folgende Punkte werden während dem Seminar behandelt: 

  •    Übersicht über den Immobilienmarkt in der Schweiz
  •    Immobilien als Anlagevehikel
  •    Aktuelle Trends in der Immobilienbranche (CH und EU)
  •    Deals und Transactions in der Immobilienbranche
  •    Buchhalterische und regulatorische Grundlagen bei der Prüfung von Immobilienanlagevehikeln
  •    Grundlagen der Immobilienbewertung
  •    Steuerliche Aspekte in der Immobilienbranche
  •    ESG in der Immobilienbranche
  •    AI in Real Estate

Nach Abschluss des theoretischen Teils sollen die Studierenden eine Gruppenarbeit schreiben und diese in einer kurzen Präsentation vorstellen.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
•  Creation and evaluation of a prototype (30%): Students will independently or in small teams develop a prototype based on prompt engineering that addresses a user-centered innovation; both the technical and conceptual aspects of the prototype will be assessed.
  •  Composition and presentation of a scientific paper (50%): Each student or team will write an 8-12 page scientific paper in ACM format detailing the development process, technical implementation, and user focus of the prototype.
  •  10-minute presentation of the paper and prototype (20%).
SmText: Seminar: Prompt Engineering: Innovation Through Generative AI (BSc)
PrecognitionDescription: Basic programming skills in Python and an understanding of machine learning are helpful but not mandatory.
ObjectiveDescription:
Upon completing the course, students will be able to:

  •    Explain developments, basic principles, and technical mechanisms of NLP and Large Language Models.
  •    Practically implement the use of prompt engineering to control generative AI models in various application areas.
  •    Design creative and effective prompts to craft innovative solutions for specific tasks or problems.
  •    Critically analyze ethical, legal, and social challenges of AI technologies and promote responsible AI applications.
  •    Document the entire development process of an AI-supported project clearly and structured in a scientific paper according to ACM format.
  •    Effectively integrate prompt engineering into existing structures to enhance operational efficiency and innovation capacity.
  •    Apply research methods and techniques for critical analysis and evaluation of generative AI models and their applicability and impacts.
MaterialDescription:
Selected Papers:

  1. Training Language Models to Follow Instructions with Human Feedback (2022) by Ouyang, Wu, Jiang, Almeida, Wainwright, Mishkin, Zhang, Agarwal, Slama, Ray, Schulman, Hilton, Kelton, Miller, Simens, Askell, Welinder, Christiano, Leike, and Lowe
    arxiv.org/pdf/2203.02155.pdf
  2. Fine-Tuning Language Models from Human Preferences (2020) by Ziegler, Stiennon, Wu, Brown, Radford, Amodei, Christiano, Irving arxiv.org/abs/1909.08593 ;
  3. Learning to Summarize from Human Feedback (2022) by Stiennon, Ouyang, Wu, Ziegler, Lowe, Voss, Radford, Amodei, Christiano  arxiv.org/abs/2009.01325
  4. How Close is ChatGPT to Human Experts? Comparison Corpus, Evaluation, and Detection by Biyang Guo1†∗, Xin Zhang2∗, Ziyuan Wang1∗, Minqi Jiang1∗, Jinran Nie3∗ Yuxuan Ding4, Jianwei Yue5, Yupeng Wu6 arxiv.org/pdf/2301.07597v1.pdf
  5. Language Models are Few-Shot Learners by Tom B. Brown et al arxiv.org/pdf/2005.14165.pdf
FurtherInfoDescription:
The allocation of students to this seminar will be done through the department via the new module booking tool. If there is a shortage of seats, we will give preference to students that are majoring in informatics and have not yet attended a seminar and are already far in their studies. Please note that we cannot guarantee a spot.  

More information on the process can be found on our website: www.ifi.uzh.ch/en/studies/seminar.html.  

Application for this seminar is via the new module booking tool: studentservices.uzh.ch/uzh/launchpad
CommonDescription:
Organizations unable to recognize and leverage the potential of generative artificial intelligence (AI) will increasingly experience competitive disadvantages. Understanding and implementing AI systems is crucial, but integrating these systems intelligently and user-centrically into products and services to drive innovation and develop future-proof solutions is paramount.

This course bridges the gap between traditional machine learning and the advanced techniques of generative AI, particularly in natural language processing and large language models (LLMs). Through targeted use of prompt engineering, specific AI outputs tailored to the needs and challenges of users, customers, and modern organizations can be generated.

The course provides an in-depth introduction to the mechanisms and applications of prompt engineering, supported by practical examples and projects that students can directly apply to their ideas. Initially, the course covers the basics of natural language processing and the construction and deployment of LLMs. Participants will learn how to effectively utilize these technologies through prompt techniques to create user-centric innovations.

- Course Content and Methodology:

  1.    Foundations and Principles of NLP and LLMs: o    Understanding the technical foundations and evolutionary development of NLP and LLMs.
    o    Detailed examination of the architectures and functionalities of leading language models like GPT and BERT.
  2.    Introduction to Prompt Engineering: o    Learning the principles and techniques of steering AI model performance through specific inputs (prompts).
    o    Analysis of use cases where prompt engineering is effectively employed for business innovation.
  3.    Scientific Application and Prototyping: o    Developing prototypes demonstrating the application of prompt engineering in real scenarios.
    o    Conducting scientific projects in teams to promote collaborative and practical experience.
  4.    Legal, Ethical, and Social Aspects of AI Use: o    Discussion on data privacy, responsibility in AI deployment, and avoiding biases.

Participants will not only acquire theoretical knowledge but also develop practical skills enabling them to consciously and effectively utilize generative AI technologies. The goal is to empower students to fully exploit the opportunities and challenges of AI technologies for innovative business solutions through a combination of theoretical understanding and practical application.
AudienceDescription: BA students, especially those interested in Information Systems and Computer Science.

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription: One presentation of a paper project, conference presentation, or research design.
SmText: Doctoral Seminar for Empirical Software Engineering
ObjectiveDescription:
Throughout this seminar, students should be able to:

  1.    Critically assess recent research developments, understanding methodologies, findings, and implications to contribute effectively to the field.
  2.    Improve presentation abilities through rehearsals, communicating research findings clearly and engagingly to diverse audiences.
  3.    Stay updated on field advancements, incorporating new knowledge into personal research projects.
  4.    Participate constructively in academic discussions, providing and receiving feedback.
FurtherInfoDescription: Registration via Email to: bacchelli@ifi.uzh.ch
CommonDescription: The primary purpose of the seminar is to facilitate a thorough review and discussion of current research progress, paper projects, and research designs initiated by students within the department. The seminar incorporates various components, including presentation rehearsals, where students practice delivering their research findings to improve their public speaking skills. Furthermore, the seminar includes conference reports that highlight recent developments in the field and upcoming opportunities, helping students stay abreast with the latest in academia. Through its multidimensional approach, the seminar aims to foster an environment that encourages intellectual growth and academic collaboration.
Events_1_EStext: Doctoral Seminar for Empirical Software Engineering

ObjectAttributes: Target Group: Suitable for English Speakers
TestsDescription:
Participants will complete in-class exercises during the seminar.

Students who attend the entire workshop and who complete all in-class exercises will pass the course.
ObjectiveDescription: Participants will develop a deeper understanding of how to develop high-quality questionnaires using best practices, as well as how to analyze questionnaire data. After this workshop, participants should be able to apply the insights about questionnaire design and analysis to their own research and academic manuscripts.
FurtherInfoDescription:
Lecturer: Prof. Jon Krosnick (Stanford University)

This module is planned to take place onsite.

Interested doctoral students are kindly asked to register for the course by sending an email to Glenn Hauser (Glenn.Hauser@business.uzh.ch) no later than October 7th, 2024.
CommonDescription:
The most popular tool for collecting social science data used by governments, industry, and academics is the questionnaire.  Asking people to describe their past behaviors, their attitudes and beliefs, their behavioral intentions, and much more via standardized sets of questions has yielded countless valuable insights into the human experience.
 
The structuring, wording, and ordering of questions has traditionally been viewed as "an art, not a science", in the words of Princeton University psychologist Hadley Cantril over five decades ago.  And in his 1951 book, The Art of Asking Questions, Stanley Payne cautioned that "the reader will be disappointed if he expects to find here a set of definite rules or explicit directions. The art of asking questions is not likely ever to be reduced to some easy formulas (p. xi)."  Thirty years later, Sudman and Bradburn (1982) agreed, saying that "no codified rules for question asking exist (p. 2)."
 
In recent years, it has become clear that this is an antiquated view that ignores a huge accumulation of knowledge throughout the social sciences about effective question-asking. The findings of thousands of studies do in fact suggest formal rules about how best to design questions.  However, this work has been scattered across the publication outlets of numerous disciplines, and this literature has not yet been comprehensively and integratively reviewed in a central place.  Doing so has been a life’s work for Jon Krosnick during the past 20 years, and he will present his findings during this workshop.
 
Primarily by experimentally manipulating question format, wording, or ordering, the studies to be reviewed have illuminated how people go about answering attitude questions and how different question formulations can produce quite different answers.  The literature supports numerous clear and practical recommendations regarding how best to construct questionnaires, and it also reorients the entire conceptual approach questionnaire writers and analysts bring to their tasks.  The workshop will be helpful to anyone who designs questionnaires or who analyzes data collected via questionnaires.
 
__________________________
About the guest professor:
Winner of the American Association for Public Opinion Research’s Lifetime Achievement Award for outstanding research, and the Nevitt Sanford Award from the International Society of Political Psychology, Jon Krosnick is Frederic O. Glover Professor in Humanities and Social Sciences at Stanford University, Professor of Communication, Political Science, Sustainability, and Psychology, director of the Political Psychology Research Group there, and a Research Psychologist at the U.S. Census Bureau.  His publications include 10 books and more than 170 articles and chapters, Dr. Krosnick conducts research in three primary areas: (1) attitude formation, change, and effects, (2) the psychology of political behavior, and (3) the optimal design of questionnaires used for laboratory experiments and surveys, and survey research methodology more generally.  Dr. Krosnick received a B.A. degree in psychology from Harvard University and M.A. and Ph.D. degrees in social psychology from the University of Michigan.  He has taught courses on survey methodology around the world at universities, for corporations, and for government agencies, has provided expert testimony in court, and has served as an on-air election-night television commentator and exit poll data analyst.  He was co-principal investigator of the American National Election Study, America’s preeminent academic research project exploring voter decision-making. Dr. Krosnick was elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and his scholarship has been recognized by the Phillip Brickman Memorial Prize for Research in Social Psychology, the Midwest Political Science Association's Pi Sigma Alpha Award, the Erik Erikson Early Career Award for Excellence and Creativity in Political Psychology, and a fellowship at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences.
